webTitle: Lone parents: Child support still not child's play

fields.headline: Child support still not child's play
fields.standfirst: Changes at the CSA may make claims simpler, but justice may be more elusive.  Margaret Dibben  explains why
fields.trailText: Changes at the CSA may make claims simpler, but justice may be more elusive. Margaret Dibben explains why.
fields.body:
The Child Support Agency has more foes than friends among both people claiming maintenance and those paying it.

The formula for calculating child support payments is complex and can include up to 144 separate computations. Philip Rutter, matrimonial partner with solicitor Collyer-Bristow, says: 'The formula is so complex that well over half the assessments are wrong.'

They also take a long time: 'At present, the average delay between applying to the CSA and an assessment being raised is nine months. This is outside the targets set by the Government,' Rutter says.

From April 2002, the law will change with the intention of simplifying the system, but it is already being criticised. The lawyer says: 'For some people it is a good thing. For others it is going to be a nightmare and create greater inequalities than there are at present.'

The new formula, like the old, works on the basis that one parent has care of the children and the other does not. Parents without care of a child will have to pay 15 per cent of their net income to the other parent for one child, 20 per cent if they have two children and 25 per cent for three or more. There is a ceiling on income of £104,000, so there could be an assessment of £15,600 a year for one child.

But, says Rutter: 'While the new formula sounds sens-ible, it is too simple. It does not take account of the income earned by the parent with care, making a mockery of the established principle that both parents should make a financial contribution to the upkeep of their children if they can.'

A mother with care may earn more than the father, yet her income will not be taken into account: 'She may end up with the lion's share of the capital because she will have the children most of the time, and he is stuck with a bit of capital but having to fund a large mortgage so he has a home big enough for himself and for the children to visit.'

Rutter says the new formula:

 Precludes formal private arrangements between parents - forcing them eventually to go to the CSA, and unravelling existing binding court orders.

 Reduces the amount of support when the child stays overnight with the paying parent, possibly leading to custody battles.

 Does not take into account any childcare costs or school fees that a paying parent may already make.

 Will not take into account a paying parent's major expenses, such as mortgage, commuting or the costs of a new family (although having other children will mean a slight reduction).

 Does not take into account the capital resources of either parent, so that someone can have vast investments but pay nothing if they have no job.

He concludes: 'While the new formula may be far simpler, there is no guarantee that the efficiency of the CSA will improve, and it may be that there will be the same backlog of assessments and inability to collect child support, particularly for those people that really need it.'

It's great to work - if the kids are all right

After the lack of money, the biggest problem for lone parents is childcare. Apart from the lucky few with parents who have time to spare and live nearby, childcare costs money.

Before a lone parent can even think about taking a job, the salary has to be high enough to pay for childcare, tax, travelling to work and leave enough money over to make it worthwhile financially. Many lone parents are prepared to compromise on the financial reward because they want to work as an interest outside the home or to keep in touch with their profession.

To help, the Government has introduced New Deal for Lone Parents for those on income support with at least one child under 16. Joining is voluntary, but it is more complicated than simply claiming money. Contact your JobCentre, where you will be allocated a personal adviser who gives help on jobs, training, benefits and childcare.

Joining New Deal for Lone Parents leads to help with the cost of childcare, up to £60 a week for one child or £100 for two, while you train for a new career or attend job interviews. The childcare scheme must be registered; you will not get help with the cost of nannies or au pairs. You can also claim towards the costs of attending job interviews and fees for training courses, provided this is approved beforehand by the personal adviser.

The next hurdle is finding affordable childcare, and here the web is proving useful. Local and national organisations are putting detailed information about their services on websites, with addresses of registered childminders. One is ChildcareLink, developed by the Department for Education and Employment, the Department for Social Security and the Scottish Executive. It is organised by Opportunity Links, based in Cambridge. (see contacts)

A solution to childcare problems could be to become a childminder yourself. Child minders who are lone parents can often claim benefits however many hours they work. You are treated as self-employed and taxed. However if you do this, you cannot claim the childcare tax credit that comes with the working families' tax credit and disabled person's tax credit.

Help with childcare costs is available through: local authority subsidised places; some employers; working families' tax credit; disabled persons tax credit.

fields.headline: What does it all mean?
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley gives a basic guide to the terminology of tax-free savings products
fields.trailText: Jill Insley gives a basic guide to the terminology of tax-free savings products.
fields.body:
Additional voluntary contribution (AVC) - Contributions you choose to make to top up your company or occupational pension scheme.

Annuity - A regular income, usually paid monthly, payable for a set period or life, depending on the annuity's terms. Most of the proceeds from your pension scheme must be used to buy an annuity by your 75th birthday.

Basic rate taxpayer - A person whose top rate of tax is 22 per cent.

Capital gains tax (CGT) - Tax on gains made from selling or transferring assets, applied in the tax year when the gains are realised. Few people exceed the capital gains tax allowance (an allowance of £7,200 this tax year), and therefore most avoid paying CGT.

Chargeable gains - A gain which is potentially liable to CGT, but which may avoid tax once allowances have been applied.

Company or occupational pension scheme - A pension scheme run by an employer for the benefit of its employees. The employer will normally pay the running costs of the scheme and make contributions on the employees' behalf. Employees are usually required to contribute.

Dividends - Income paid out by shares.

Execution-only service - A financial service that carries out deals on the instruction of a client but without giving any financial advice to that client.

Friendly society - A mutual organisation, similar to an insurance company, which is able to offer savings plans with special tax breaks, known as friendly society bonds (see below).

Higher rate taxpayer - A per son whose top rate of tax is 40 per cent.

Income tax - Tax charged on most of the income you receive, such as earnings, investments and pension annuities. You can earn £4,385 before paying any income tax.

Independent financial adviser - Someone who must consider the full range of products and companies when giving you advice.

Individual savings account (Isa) - A tax efficient savings scheme introduced in April 1999 to replace personal equity plans and Tessas. Isas can be used to protect a wide range of investments from tax - cash deposits (see page 20), stocks and shares including investments (see page 23) such as unit trusts and OEIC shares, and insurance linked investments. You can invest a maximum of £7,000 in the current tax year. You can invest the full allowance in a maxi Isa, putting the entire amount into stocks and shares, or you can combine the different types of asset, putting up to £3,000 into cash deposits, up to £1,000 in insurance and the remainder in stocks and shares. Alternatively you can open separate mini Isas for each component.

Inheritance tax - Tax charged against your estate when you die. The first £234,000 of your estate is free from inheritance tax; any amount above this will be taxed at 40 per cent.

National Savings - Deposit based investments issued on behalf of the Government.

Non-taxpayer - A person whose taxable earnings are exceeded by tax allowances.

Personal equity plan (Pep) - A tax-efficient savings plan, withdrawn from sale in April last year. Peps set up before that date can continue running indefinitely until the investor withdraws his or her money or dies.

Personal pension - A private pension scheme sold by insurance companies to people who are unable to, or who have chosen not to, join an occupational pension scheme.

Stakeholder pension - A new type of pension scheme which will go on sale from 6 April next year. To qualify as a stakeholder, a pension scheme must be flexible and have low charges - no initial charge and annual charges of 1 per cent or less a year.

Starting rate taxpayer - A person who pays a top income tax rate of 10 per cent.

Taxable gain - The gain that is left after you have taken all your allowances into account.

Taxable income - Income that has been paid without the deduction of tax, but which is liable for tax unless you have allowances which can be set against it.

Tax Exempt Special Savings Account (Tessa) - A tax-efficient deposit account, withdrawn from sale in April 1999. Tessas mature after five years, so many people still have accounts earning them tax-free interest.

Tax year - Runs from 6 April to 5 April.

Tessa-only Isa - An Isa that can accept up to £9,000 in capital (but not interest) from a maturing Tessa.

Venture capital trusts - A savings scheme with generous tax advantages designed to encourage investment in small unlisted companies.

webTitle: Property: Are you selling? Call the doctor...

fields.headline: Are you selling? Call the doctor...
fields.standfirst: The US trend of consulting specialists to maximise your house price has arrived here, says  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: The US trend of consulting specialists to maximise your house price has arrived here, says Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
We all know the obvious clichés involved in selling a house - who has not heard the classical music and caught the smell of percolating coffee while looking around Acacia Avenue or Railway Cuttings?

But sometimes more subtle work is required to maximise a property's sale price - and the owners are not always in a position to know what to do.

House doctors have sprung up in the US to advise sellers how to spruce up their homes to make them sell quicker and at a higher price. They insist that their business is as much about telling sellers what not to do, as what to do.

US house doctors advise abandoning plans to fit a new kitchen before selling because you just won't get the money back. A house doctor's magazine in the US recently calculated the return on $1,000 spent on major works before a sale (see table).

The fledgling house doctor industry in this country agrees. 'It is just as important to know when to stop spending money as when to start,' says one of Britain's few house doctors, Daphne Leck, who has been running Property Presentation Services for three years.

Leck will survey a property to be sold, give the vendor a written report highlighting strengths and weaknesses of the house, and offer recommendations on changes. 'We don't want to run a building company so we don't do the work ourselves - what we do is advise on fabrics, colours, space and so on.'

Leck says that the work she recommends could cost from £500 to £10,000 to carry out, including her own fees, but that the aim of the changes would always be to make more money from a sale.

'In the present market sellers will have estate agents telling them to drop the house price by £10,000 to get a quick sale. I'd say why not spend £2,000 on making it look better and then achieve the original asking price - and you'd be £8,000 better off,' she suggests.

'Most of our business comes from London, where the sellers are more sophisticated and where people will get substantially more return from their investment if the value of the house goes up after taking our advice. Frankly, if someone is selling a house in a northern town for £30,000 then work of this kind may not be cost-effective,' says Leck, whose consultation fees start at around £125.

Needless to say there is now an online house doctor in the form of The Wow Factor, a similar service available through a website run by Pamela Hadaway.

You can email or post pictures of your house, along with a description, and Hadaway will advise on changes at a fee of £50 per room. Her at-house service costs £20 per hour and includes assessments of colour, lighting, space and maintenance.

'The biggest problem by far is clutter - there's simply too much of it. If you're selling your home people walking around it don't want your family's photographs on the mantelpiece, don't want pets' bedding in the living room, and don't want your kids' bikes in the hallway,' she says.

But sceptics who think house doctors are unnecessary because sellers have a vested interest in making their home presentable should talk to estate agents. Some sellers simply refuse to take obvious steps.

Stewart Chipchase from FPDSavills' Cambridge office was asked to sell a house in the city in the mid-1990s. 'There were 16,000 books on the upper floors and every single inch of the house was cluttered with grass cuttings, broken lawn mowers, Sainsbury's baskets of unopened packets and tins and dog poo,' he says.

'The owner even admitted that she herself hadn't taken a bath for seven months. I obtained a quote on her behalf for a serious make-over and professional scrub, but the cleaning company turned the work down,' he recalls. Amazingly, the house still sold within three weeks.

Keith Rigby of west London agent Leslie Marsh & Co last year pleaded with owners to clear a house which had so much furniture stored in it, some rooms were completely inaccessible to potential buyers.

'They refused point blank to clear it. After three months the property did eventually sell at the asking price of £500,000. But if the vendors had been prepared to do some clearing and cleaning, I have no doubt the property would have sold much more quickly and possibly would have achieved a further 10 per cent above the sale price,' he says.

In the end it boils down to impressing the potential buyer - so back to the classical music and the percolating coffee.

And just in case you thought America had a more sophisticated approach to house selling than the UK, this advice from a US house doctors' website should put you right: 'Bake bread or cookies or boil cinnamon sticks in water on the stove to give your home a welcoming aroma.'

Give your home seller-appeal

British property website www.rightmove.co.uk offers a guide to making your house look its best, including tips for each area.

Outside

 Sweep pathways and drive.
 Repair fences and window sills.
 Mow the lawn and trim the hedges.
 Add tubs or hanging baskets.

Reception rooms

 Tidy, no clutter, well lit.
 Place fresh flowers in the room and turn the TV off.

Kitchen

 Keep tidy and put away the washing-up.
 Get rid of stale cooking smells.
 Make sure the taps don't drip.

Bedrooms

 Make the beds.
 Open windows and place pot pourri.

General

 No loose doormats.
 Wash light switches, door knobs and handrails.
 Keep pets out of the way - and don't let them smell.
 Keep surfaces clear to create a feeling of space.

Contacts

www.propertypresentation.co.uk

www.the-wow-factor.com

www.audrie.com

fields.headline: Widowers in payout fight
fields.standfirst: Bereaved men want equality, reports  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Bereaved men want equality, reports Jill Insley.
fields.body:
Three widowers are seeking the right to state bereavement payments in a test case that could cost the Government £120 million.

The three men, one in his nineties, another in his eighties and a third who has teenage daughters still at school, will lodge complaints at the European Court of Human Rights this week to determine whether the Government is guilty of discrimination by refusing them payments equivalent in value to the widow's bereavement allowance.

Although governments have allowed widows to claim tax relief following the deaths of their husbands, men have never been entitled to the same. But last year the Government paid £575 plus costs in an out-of-court settlement to Christopher Crossland, whose wife died six years ago.

However the Revenue has rejected claims from other widowers on the grounds that Crossland's case was not heard in court: there was no ruling and therefore no precedent set. A spokesperson says: 'Mr Crossland was paid compensation by the UK Government rather than bereavement allowance by the Revenue.' It says its case is strengthened by the fact that widow's bereavement allowance was abolished on 6 April.

Barrister Philip Baker says the Revenue has discriminated against the widowers in two ways: sexually, by giving the allowance to women but not men, and between Crossland and his clients, by refusing them a payment the other man received.

webTitle: Employees should help with the design and decor of their offices

fields.headline: All things bright and beautiful
fields.standfirst: Employers are realising that their workforce will be happier - and more efficient - if they can contribute to the design and decor of their offices, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Employers are realising that their workforce will be happier - and more efficient - if they can contribute to the design and decor of their offices.
fields.body:
You could be forgiven for thinking that the offices of the Financial Ombudsman Service would be traditional, conformist and dull. When you collect together 400 workers who specialise in handling complaints about pension sales and other financial transactions, you probably do not expect the emphasis to be on brightness, vivacity, fun and individuality. But, in fact, the ombudsman's offices at South Quay Plaza, near Canary Wharf in east London, are lively, colourful and stimulating.

It is not that the FOS is run by wild party animals. It is more that organisations are starting to realise that human beings tend to work better when they can express some individuality through their surroundings. Put a team in an office with grey walls and little natural light and they will probably be less happy (and less effective) than another team which has colour, big windows and attractive views. The FOS development is a good example of what the modern workplace will look like; it is an example which is likely to be followed in hundreds of others offices and buildings over the next few years.

The move to South Quay Plaza came about after the Government decreed that eight different financial services sector ombudsman schemes should be merged. Its office building was therefore going to be important not just as a place to house the staff but as the environment where eight different cultures would meld into one. Under a more traditional approach - where office managers design floor layouts with little thought as to how staff meet and communicate - the different teams could have been thrown together without ever really getting to know each other.

The FOS has, in fact, tried throwing the odd staff party so that teams could meet, and publishing friendly newsletters, but the best results have been achieved through the physical layout. Office designer DEGW deliberately groups the communal facilities together - photocopier, fax machines, coffee dispenser and toilets - so that staff can amble round these different points and talk to each other. Most people find it easier to ask an unknown colleague 'How does this fax work?' than to say 'May I join you?' to a stranger at a party.

The office design was worked out in consultation with a group of 30 employees. DEGW nearly always uses this method and finds that it produces sensible but lively results. 'You sometimes get disruptive people,' says spokeswoman Beth Morgan 'but usually the group can deal with it. If not, we'll arrange a one-to-one meeting and that nearly always sorts the problem. Often a problem lies with other issues like they've seen this sort of thing before and it hasn't worked out.'

People's desire for originality seems to be more deep-rooted than most office designers and managers have ever appreciated. A very traditional company in the oil and gas sector has, by the same route, designed rather an outlandish (though still functional) structure which includes relaxation areas resembling tree houses and a video lounge with a range of audio-visual facilities. 'Their overriding priority was to stimulate fun and creativity,' says Morgan. The development of a 'fun' atmosphere is now a common requirement, particularly in the dotcom sector, and is generally seen as a fast route to promoting creativity.

In the Egg call centre in Derby and the Capital One call centre in Nottingham, the managers face the constant challenge of retaining staff. Competition from other employers and the stress of hitting customer-handling targets lead to high turnover rates at call centres generally. But both these organisations have improved staff retention by paying great attention to office design. They let their staff work in small teams, giving them a set amount of money each week to spend on whatever they want, from tenpin bowling to buying a coffee maker. A lot of the money goes on decorating their part of the office.

More new offices will - like the FOS - be open-plan, but open-plan with a difference. No one in this part of South Quay Plaza has their own office or any piece of furniture which denotes authority. Walter Merricks, the Ombudsman, says: 'We wanted to send out a message that there wouldn't be privileged people around with thick pile carpets and drinks cabinets. There has to be a management hierarchy, but it doesn't have to express itself in this way.'

Quite right, says DEGW. Many egalitarian and team-working ideas behind open-plan offices are corrupted if the top dogs decide to retain their own offices or other physical manifestations of power.

The FSO offices have three differently coloured floors - mustard, loganberry and fuchsia. But the colour schemes, occasional soft sofas and other signs of informality have not produced the bad effects that traditionalists might fear. In fact, the comfort seems to have improved communications - useful for an organisation in the complaints-handling and communications business.

webTitle: Agony aunt: I've been passed over for 24 years

fields.headline: I've been passed over for 24 years
fields.trailText: I have been passed over for promotion on numerous occasions. Although I have been a loyal and effective employee here for 24 years, I am now seeing younger, far less experienced people get jobs that I could do well. I think that they do not want 'free thinkers' here, and that the boss prefers his own drinking companions and friends. Do I have any legal redress - or should I just turn my back on 24 years of service and walk away?
fields.body:
I have been passed over for promotion on numerous occasions. Although I have been a loyal and effective employee here for 24 years, I am now seeing younger, far less experienced people get jobs that I could do well. I think that they do not want 'free thinkers' here, and that the boss prefers his own drinking companions and friends. Do I have any legal redress - or should I just turn my back on 24 years of service and walk away?

Your opportunities for legal redress are limited. If, however, you can prove a case of race, sex or disability discrimination, you could be awarded damages through an industrial tribunal claim.

But you would need a particular kind of evidence, such as statistics to show that all or most of the people promoted were female and that you were therefore discriminated against because you are a man. Another theoretical possibility is to start a grievance proceeding against your boss. But this is not very likely to work. Companies are allowed to make subjective decisions about who they promote. Perhaps you could benefit by looking for another job - but do not be bitter in any job interviews. Attacking your present employer is not a way to find a new one.

 Legal advice from Keoghs of Bolton

Problem at work?
Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Insurance: Look behind the bonus promises

fields.headline: Look behind the bonus promises
fields.standfirst: Weak companies may mean poor returns, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Weak companies may mean poor returns, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
Look at the financial strength of an insurance company before you buy a with-profits investment, warn the authors of a new survey. If you pick a weak company, bonuses on your policy may not be as high as you expect.

The authors of the report, consultants KPMG and industry newspaper Money Marketing , say consumers thinking of buying a with-profits bond, endowment or pension from a company whose financial strength is ebbing away need to ask questions. Only a handful of life assurers became weaker between 1998 and 1999 according to the survey, but it warns that other providers could be strapped for cash in future.

The survey of 38 insurers measures financial strength using something called the free asset ratio, taken from returns to the Financial Services Authority, the chief financial regulator. It is calculated as the free assets a life assurer owns as a proportion of its total assets - and it is regarded as the acid test of financial strength for with-profits business (see box).

Seven companies experienced drops in their ratios between 1998 and 1999 according to the survey. They were Britannic Assurance, CGU Life, Royal Liver, Scottish Friendly, Sun Life, Sun Life Financial of Canada and Teachers Provident.

Nick Bamford, managing director of financial advisers Informed Choice, says a financially strong life office is able to invest more of its with-profits fund in equities and that this strategy leads to the maintenance of good future bonus rates. A fall in the ratio indicates that the life office is less able to maintain high future bonuses.

The editor of the survey, Sandra Grandison, says: 'People who can spot their provider among the handful of companies who have experienced a worsening of their financial strength should be asking questions.' She says consumers need to establish why their insurer's fortunes have dipped, particularly as it bucks the general trend. If they do not like what they hear they should consider going elsewhere. Mergers make it difficult for investors to track the ownership of funds they are invested in. Merged groups may contain funds from previously independent groups where the free asset ratios will be different, as in the case of CGU Life and Norwich Union (see table). Investors may need to ask which fund they are in and what it's status is.

Most companies appear stronger in 1999 than in 1998, a massive increase on the year before. Royal London showed the biggest increase of all. Its free assets ratio jumped nearly 15 per cent, but the basis on which it is calculated has changed. The smallest leap was made by Standard Life, at 0.4 per cent.

Even if your provider is not experiencing a downturn, it does not mean you can afford to be complacent. The 1999 ratios were buoyed by the excellent performance of equity markets that year. But next year several factors are poised to drag down the industry's average free asset ratio.

The House of Lords' judgment on the Equitable Life case is likely to take its toll on many companies' financial strength. Equitable had tried to wriggle out of paying guaranteed annuity rates on pensions but the Lords ruled this unlawful, a decision which will cost the life office billions of pounds. Some companies have adopted a similar policy to Equitable and could have to pay up too.

In addition there is the strain from the financial outlay providers have to make to prepare for stakeholder pensions, the Government's pension initiative for people on lower earnings. And changes to the regulations on how life companies bal ance their books will add to the burden.

Headline bonus rates may seduce you into buying a with-profits policy - but it is wise to look closely at the insurance company behind the offer. Bamford says that financial strength, a crude measure at the best of times, should not be considered in isolation. Past performance, charges and service are also important.

The survey is available on 020 7292 3730.

What is the free asset ratio?

Free assets are the capital an insurer has that is surplus to its liabilities and the minimum required to run its business. Free assets finance new business, meet unexpected claims and provide backing for its investment activities. The free asset ratio is the figure for free assets expressed as a proportion of total assets.

 From Money Marketing

webTitle: Disgruntled staff will always take revenge on uncaring employers

fields.headline: We're not happy, you're for it
fields.standfirst: Management: Whether at the coalface or the interface... disgruntled staff will take revenge on uncaring employers, warns Enid Mumford
fields.trailText: Management: Whether at the coalface or the interface... disgruntled staff will take revenge on uncaring employers, warns Enid Mumford
fields.body:
Many new web companies know nothing of business history and have little management expertise because they are new to the game. But their predicted future of challenge, excitement and innovation should not blind them to lessons of the past. An important one is that if you don't give your employees job satisfaction, they will find their own - perhaps with disastrous economic consequences.

Working on the docks or in a coal mine 20 years ago wasn't much fun. The work was hard, monotonous and dangerous. The miners had to avoid life-threatening hazards such as gas, explosions and roof falls; the dockers were subject to serious injury from loose cargo. Most dockers had a few fingers missing - or worse.

The car industry was little better. While the risk of injury was less than in the docks and the mines, the work was monotonous and there was the added stress of being forced to match the pace of a moving production line, which was never allowed to stop, even when there was a serious production problem. A one-time British Leyland foreman told me his ideal worker was a man who, when he arrived at work, put a metaphorical black hood over his head and stopped thinking. He only removed the hood when he went home. Zombies were the preferred employees.

None of these people got much, if any, mental stimulation from work. Morale should have been at rock bottom, yet this was often not the case. All three groups of workers were strong trade unionists who had learnt the power of unofficial 'wildcat' strikes. Mental energy was stimulated and sustained through a largely successful war against management.

Job satisfaction was created and kept high by joint decisions and agreement on the next strategy by which to attack the hated bosses.

Pay disputes often provided a splendid opportunity for this warfare, as wage rates used to be agreed before a job began. However, unanticipated problems would often cause the work to be more dif ficult than expected. This put production targets out of reach and required overtime to be worked. This then provoked fierce arguments over how much extra pay was appropriate.

If the workers' claims for overtime pay were not met, there would be an immediate strike, giving them the pleasure of confronting, and usually routing, members of the gaffer class.

On the docks and in the mines and car plants, the cry, 'Everybody out', was a regular event.

Even now, if employers do not provide job satisfaction, employees will find it on their own. This is more easily done when people have the mutual support of working in teams, which is the predicted work structure of the future. The fact that dockers, miners and car workers took action collectively, rather than as individuals, gave them considerable power, which lone workers usually lacked.

The unhappy individual worker was restricted to looking for another job, going home sick, slowing down his work effort or deliberately producing poor-quality work. Today, if computer literate, that dissatisfied worker may be hacking into the company computer and changing or removing data.

History, then, provides two powerful messages. First, if employers do not provide job satisfaction, their employees will seek and find their own - even if this is directly opposed to management interests.

Second, team working and group autonomy, although desirable, increase local power, and this can be used in ways that work against management and reduce its control. Yet managers may not even know that these negative attitudes exist.

This is not to suggest that workers in the new web firms will go out on strike. But there are other ways of showing dissatisfaction and lack of commitment. These are all the more powerful in their effects when it is groups rather than individuals that are angry and fed up. They can destroy a small firm.

So what can companies do to prevent this kind of undesirable behaviour occurring?

First, it is important to recognise that all employment relationships are an implicit contract, even though this contract is not always written down. The employee agrees to act in the employer's interests provided the employer takes account of his or her needs. Some of these will be economic. Clearly, the employees want to receive an equitable financial reward for their knowledge and effort.

Other, equally important, factors will be psychological. Research has shown that one of the most important sources of psychological satisfaction concerns relationships. Employees want to know that they are valued, that their needs are understood and respected and that they can trust their bosses to behave ethically.

This requires employers to create relationships based on concern and trust - reflected in good communication, a willingness to discuss problems and an open-door policy. The result is job satisfaction. But it must never be forgotten that there can be also the opposite: negative job satisfaction, the powerful buzz, pleasure and stimulus that comes from fighting or causing trouble for a boss who is neither respected nor liked.

Keeping people happy by ensuring that their jobs are comfortable, fulfilling and rewarding is not a new management concept, but it is more important than ever, when the price of not doing so so can be the destruction of the company.

The best 'people' management tends to come from experience and to be based on mutual respect and understanding. Unfortunately, many of the new e-commerce companies do not have this experience. They will have to learn fast.

This requires employers to create relationships based on concern and trust - reflected in good communication, a willingness to discuss problems and an open-door policy. The result is job satisfaction. But it must never be forgotten that there can be also the opposite: negative job satisfaction, the powerful buzz, pleasure and stimulus that comes from fighting or causing trouble for a boss who is neither respected nor liked. Keeping people happy by ensuring that their jobs are comfortable, fulfilling and rewarding is not a new management concept, but it is more important than ever, when the price of not doing so so can be the destruction of the company. The best 'people' management tends to come from experience and to be based on mutual respect and understanding. Unfortunately, many of the new e-commerce companies do not have this experience. They will have to learn fast.

webTitle: Tax-free investments: Give yourself a break

fields.headline: Give yourself a break
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  kicks off eight pages on how to pay less to the Revenue
fields.trailText: Jill Insley kicks off eight pages on how to pay less to the Revenue
fields.body:
No one likes paying tax. So why do so few of us make use of tax-efficient savings schemes and tax breaks to reduce the amount we have to pay to the Inland Revenue?

Data gathered for IFA Promotion found that 24 million adults who held a savings or deposit account last year had not opened a Tessa. Likewise 9.6 million people owned shares but were not using a personal equity plan wrapper to protect them from tax. This year IFA Promotion estimates that more than 36 million people will waste £5.8bn on unnecessary tax - an average of £160 per person.

Amanda Davidson, of London independent financial adviser Holden Meehan, says that most people simply do not realise these tax savings are available. 'It's more a question of not knowing than not wanting to,' she says. 'Some people worry that tax avoidance is illegal. Others think that they are not wealthy enough for tax avoidance measures to work for them.'

But you do not have to be very wealthy before capital gains tax or inheritance tax kicks in. If you invested £6,000 in the Invesco European Growth fund five years ago, it would now be worth £28,014. Once you deduct your original £6,000 capital, plus your £7,200 CGT allowance, you would be liable to pay £3,259 in basic rate tax, or £5,925 if you are a higher rate taxpayer, according to Bath independent financial advisers Chase de Vere Investments.

And if you have owned a small, terraced three bedroomed house in London over the past five years, the increase in its value will already cause an inheritance tax problem for your estate. More than £1bn was charged in inheritance tax last year, money forfeited to the Inland Revenue because people failed to write insurance policies in trust, or make use of inheritance tax allowances or, worst of all, omitted to make a will.

Tax planning doesn't have to be complicated or risky. The starting point for most people should be a cash ISA, says Davidson. 'It's important to get your cash sorted out first. If you put your money into equities - into a stocks and shares Isa for example - you might need to get your money out at a time when the investment is not doing very well. A cash Isa will act as a safety fund, preventing the need to dip into your equity investments,' she says ( Cash Isas plus best buys, page 20 ).

National Savings also offers accounts that pay interest tax-free. But although National Savings offers the rock solid guarantee of getting your money back, Davidson says the accounts are insufficiently competitive to be worth considering at the moment.

While sorting out your cash accounts, make sure you are maximising the advantage of other tax breaks. If you are a non-taxpayer, register to receive gross interest on your accounts by completing an R85 form, available from your bank or building society. Likewise if your spouse is a non-taxpayer, or pays a lower rate of tax than you, transferring your money to his or her account could save up to 40 per cent in income tax.

Stocks and shares Isas are usually the next step once your cash fund is established. You can invest up to £3,000 in a mini stocks and shares Isa, or up to £7,000 in a maxi, provided you haven't taken out a cash or insurance Isa ( Maxi Isa advice, page 23 ).

But it is more important to get your choice of investment right than to maximise your tax savings. Even if you've used up your annual Isa allowance, a venture capital trust investment is not likely to be suitable unless you are prepared to tolerate high levels of risk and you are a higher rate taxpayer. 'Don't let the tax tail wag the dog,' says Davidson.

webTitle: Big unions try to strike pension deal

fields.headline: Big unions try to strike pension deal
fields.trailText: The leaders of Britain's biggest trade unions are locked in negotiations with ministers this weekend in a last-ditch attempt to strike a deal over state pensions and avert a major confrontation at Labour's conference in Brighton.
fields.body:
The leaders of Britain's biggest trade unions are locked in negotiations with ministers this weekend in a last-ditch attempt to strike a deal over state pensions and avert a major confrontation at Labour's conference in Brighton.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, head of the Unison public service union, Bill Morris of the 900,000-strong Transport & General Workers Union and John Edmonds of the GMB are attempting to wrest concessions from Chancellor Gordon Brown.

They want to see a major one-off increase in the £67.50 basic state pension, along with the restoration of the link between the pension and rises in average earnings abandoned by the Conserva tives in 1980.

Last week, Treasury plans for an increase in its minimum income guarantee from £78 to £90 were announced to head off a showdown.

However, union leaders have said the concessions are not satisfactory: they are demanding increases in the universal state pension, rather than the means-tested MIG.

Unison and the T&G have both tabled resolutions for next week's conference demanding increases and restoration of the earnings link. Negotiations this weekend will result in a statement from Labour's National Executive Committee on pensions. If unions are satisfied, they will withdraw their motions. If not, a bruising debate is promised.

Bickerstaffe told The Observer: 'The minimum income guarantee means people have to jump through hoops to prove their poverty in order to receive the £90 a week.

'We don't want an increase in the guarantee. We want a major rise in the pension by April next year. After all, if the link had not been broken, it would be £97 today.'

fields.headline: Long-term growth boosts grey power
fields.standfirst: Want to join the swinging oldies' party? It's never too early to review your retirement plans, says  David Hunt
fields.trailText: Want to join the swinging oldies' party? It's never too early to review your retirement plans, says David Hunt.
fields.body:
Don't you just love the way the retired population is represented in TV advertising. Virile, golf-playing, globe- trotting octogenarians who like nothing better than romping about with their energetic grandchildren. Even the Stannah stairlift lady looks as though she could take the stairs three at a time if she really wanted.

While this happy band may exist, the reality is often different. Retirement is not always one big party. Survey after survey reveals that most of us have little idea how much money we will actually have in retirement. When asked to guess, we are usually wildly optimistic.

Retirement planning is vitally important and becomes more so each year. Medical advance means a retirement that once could be expected to last five, possibly 10 years, can now easily stretch to 20 or 30. And the state pension, never particularly generous, is now barely even the safety net it purports to be. The earlier you plan for retirement the better, but whenever you start it makes sense to make full use of every tax benefit.

Numerous tax benefits have been eroded over the years, but pensions have remained largely intact as an efficient place to build a retirement fund. With tax relief on contributions and tax-free growth while the fund is building up, a pension fund, company or per sonal, takes some beating. So, first off, it makes sense to look at topping up pension contributions; addi-tional voluntary contributions (or buying added years) in a company pension scheme, or paying in extra to a personal pension.

Pensions shouldn't be relied upon completely, however. Stuart Bayliss, a director at IFA Annuity Direct, reckons that it's probably best to have a mix of assets.

For many people, part of this mix will be an Isa. Whereas pensions get tax benefits up front and then the money is taxed on the way out, Isas work the other way round, and you don't have to wait to retirement date to get at your money. 'I would suggest maximising Isa investment as a first step, on the basis that most people are still paying some tax in retirement,' says Jo Smith, a partner at Pretty Technical Partnership.

Kevin Minter, of the David Aaron Partnership, believes pensions should still play a major role, as government is less likely to meddle with their tax benefits.

Most people only need an income from their investments in retirement. Before this, it makes sense to invest for growth; to build up the biggest fund possible that can be converted into income when needed.

At retirement, tax brackets and allowances are likely to change, so it's an ideal time to reassess the overall position. Age allowance - the increased personal allow-ance available to those aged 65 or over - is a case in point. Age allowance is only available in full if an individual's total income does not exceed £17,000a year. For a married couple, where one partner is over and one under this level, it makes sense to transfer income-producing assets so that both end up below the £17,000 level.

Or some income could be 'lost' by transferring it into a tax-sheltered home such as an Isa, or converting it into capital via a single premium insurance bond or some other growth investment. Single premium insurance bonds allow investors to take up to 5 per cent each year, with no tax for basic taxpayers and tax deferred until all the capital is withdrawn for higher-rate taxpayers.

Going the growth investment route allows investors to cash in investments each year to provide an income and, as long as these fall within the annual capital gains exemption (£7,200 a year), there would be no tax implications.

fields.headline: Myths that explode
fields.standfirst: If you invest offshore it does not mean you'll escape the taxman, says  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: If you invest offshore it does not mean you'll escape the taxman, says Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Contrary to popular belief, you cannot avoid tax on your savings just by investing them offshore. Some UK investors may gain a tax advantage by using offshore investment bonds to defer tax but those who stand to benefit most from offshore investment are 'expats' or 'non-domiciled' foreign nationals living in the UK. Moira Elms, of accountants Pricewaterhouse Coopers, says: 'People assume that because the interest on offshore savings accounts is paid without tax deducted, it is tax-free. They do not realise that the interest is reportable on UK tax returns.'

Savers who use an offshore bank or building society may gain a marginal tax flow advantage because of the delay between receiving interest and having to fork out the tax. There can also be an attraction if interest rates offshore are higher because this would mean that the net returns would be better. But at present the reverse is the case. For example, the best rate Nationwide is offering through its Isle of Man offshore subsidiary is 6.3 per cent and to get that return you need to have £250,000 invested with three months' notice for withdrawals. By contrast, onshore investors with access to the internet can earn 7 per cent from Nationwide's e-Savings account with deposits of as little as £1 and have instant access to their money.

UK investors who have kept quiet about offshore savings could soon face discovery. Greater co-operation is likely between the Inland Revenue and offshore locations such as the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man following a report by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) on tax havens. The report criticised the tax regimes of 35 countries, including the three Crown dependencies, which it said harmed trade and investment. There is already some co-operation with the UK tax authorities. Nigel Smith, of Royal & Sun Alliance International Finance Services based in the Isle of Man, says: 'Since last July we have had to report to the Inland Revenue if an investment bond worth more than £56,800 is surrendered where we believe the investor is a UK resident.'

Offshore investment bonds sold by insurance companies are a quite legitimate way in which UK citizens can defer and potentially reduce their tax bills. No tax is levied on the investment income and capital gains within the bonds while they are in force so investors can benefit from the tax-free roll-up of returns. No tax is payable by investors either as long as their money remains in the bonds but a tax liability does arise when the bond is cashed and the money brought back into the UK.

However, a saving can still be made because it enables higher rate tax payers to put off paying any tax until they are subject to a lower rate, such as after retirement. UK investors who want an income can also withdraw 5 per cent a year from their bonds without incurring any immediate liability to tax.

For UK citizens who are living or working abroad and not paying UK tax, offshore savings accounts and investments in the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man can be attractive both from a tax point of view and because of the familiarity of the institutions and their proximity to the UK. Anybody who has come from abroad to live or work here could consider putting their investments offshore in order to avoid incurring UK Inheritance Tax on them. Although once someone has been in the UK for 17 out of the last 20 years they are regarded as domiciled here, any assets that have been placed in a trust offshore before that time can be deemed 'excluded property'.

fields.headline: Shopping around for an Isa made easy
fields.standfirst: Rebates are an attraction for investors, says  David Budworth
fields.trailText: Rebates are an attraction for investors, says David Budworth.
fields.body:
Fund supermarkets have made buying an Isa almost as easy as popping to Sainsbury's for the shopping.

Fund supermarkets allow you to compare funds from a variety of providers, and most have discounted charges as they rebate most or all of the upfront fee. On Fidelity's Funds Network almost all funds have initial charges of 1.25 per cent or less. If you bought these funds direct from the provider you could pay 5.25 per cent.

Other supermarkets offer equally attractive savings. The Interactive Investor International (iii) supermarket offers funds for an initial fee of between 0 per cent and 3 per cent, and none of the funds offered on Virgin's supermarket has an upfront charge.

The convenience of being able to compare a range of funds is the other plus. But none of the supermarkets scores full marks in this respect as choice remains limited. The biggest choice is provided by Fund Store from Inter-Alliance, which offers more than 2,200 funds from around 300 providers.

The big advantage that Fidelity and egg have is that they can offer multi-Isas, which let you spread your yearly Isa allocation around different fund managers as well as funds.

We asked three financial advisers to allocate this year's £7,000 Isa allowance using egg's supermarket. Egg Invest offers just under 200 funds from 17 investment groups but customers must open a savings account (minimum investment £20) with the bank to qualify.

Income investor

Picking an income fund is not just about identifying the fund that has the highest yield. You also want to ensure that a fund can provide a decent level of capital growth.

Colin Jackson, at Croydon-based Baronworth Investment Services in Ilford which specialises in income funds, recommends splitting the £7,000 equally between Invesco GT Income and Deutsche UK Equity Income. They are not the highest yielding unit trusts but both have been good long-term performers.

But his choice was limited by the choice of funds on egg Invest. If unconstrained, he would have recommended ABN Amro Equity Income.

Medium-risk investor looking for growth

Look overseas, says Linda Eyton, an analyst at Leeds-based Bates Investment Ser vices. She recommends investing £3,000 in the Henderson European fund. Over five years it would have tripled your original investment and she believes it will continue to perform well.

Eyton recommends investing the other £4,000 in the Save & Prosper Equity Growth Fund. She says: 'This fund has benefited from the high levels of growth that have been experienced in the technology, media and telecoms sector. Over five years the fund has grown more than 120 per cent.'

High-risk growth

Investors with an appetite for risk can tap into more exciting areas: biotechnology, smaller companies or even volatile technology stocks. Alan Durrant, of Bristol-based financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown, recommends a four-way split of funds - that's £1,750 each - between Framlington Health, Gartmore European Selected Opportunities, Invesco GT Global Dynamic Themes and Jupiter UK Spe cial Situations. The real emphasis in Durrant's Isa is on getting as wide a spread of investments as possible. Framlington Health invests in biotechnology and medical services while Jupiter UK Special Situations invests in undervalued companies. The Gartmore and Invesco GT funds give the Isa an international bent.

The advantages of Isas

The great advantage of an Isa is that returns are completely tax-free. There are two types of Isa - mini Isas and maxi Isas - and three different components - stocks and shares, which includes unit trusts and investment trusts, cash and insurance.

A maxi Isa must include a stocks and shares component and can include one or both of the other components. This tax year's Isa allowance is £7,000.

In a maxi Isa you can invest up to £3,000 in the cash component, £1,000 in insurance and the remaining balance up to £7,000 in stocks and shares.

A mini Isa invests in just one component. You can invest up to £3,000 in a mini stocks and shares Isa, £3,000 in a mini cash Isa and £1,000 in insurance.

fields.headline: Critical time for sickness insurance
fields.standfirst: Cover for severe illness can cost a fortune. But do you really need it, asks  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Cover for severe illness can cost a fortune. But do you really need it, asks Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you consult a financial adviser, the chances are that you will be advised to take out critical illness cover. Unless you are made of money, you will probably be rather taken aback at the cost, which could easily be £50 a month, depending on your circumstances. But some of the arguments in its favour sound persuasive - certainly persuasive enough to encourage 780,000 people to start paying for this cover in 1999, according to insurer Swiss Re.

You could well be quoted horrible statistics. 'One in four men will suffer a critical illness by the time they reach pension age,' says Peter Kelly of Allied Dunbar, which last week announced a tie-up with charity Imperial Cancer Research on its critical illness cover. 'One in five women will suffer a critical illness. That could be a heart attack, for instance, cancer or a stroke.' He adds that a 40-year-old man is 2.5 times more likely to suffer one of these serious medical conditions than he is to die.

Researchers are also increasingly detecting a link between excessive working hours and critical illnesses. Basing their argument on this sort of data, many financial advisers are promoting critical illness cover just as heavily as life cover. Kevin Morgan, medical cover specialist at financial adviser Litecastle, says: 'Single people or young couples probably have little need for life assurance. But there is now a great deal more interest in critical illness cover than life cover. People are surviving illnesses that even a generation ago would have killed. And if you buy critical illness cover, you get the benefit of it yourself - unlike life cover.'

The insurance entitles you to a tax-free lump sum payout on the diagnosis of one of these nasties. So if you suffer a stroke, for instance, you could spend the money on adapting your home so you can live there more easily. An industry-wide agreement, unveiled last year, has introduced standard terms and definitions, making it easier for people to know what they are buying and their position if they need to claim. You can spend the money from a claim on whatever you want. One Allied Dunbar customer who suffered a brain tumour spent some of his cash on a fitted kitchen and also set part of it aside to cover future tax bills. But since the vast majority of buyers take it when they get a new mortgage, most policyholders seem to want it to pay off their mortgage and other financial commitments.

Against this kind of argument, however, you could say that people who look after themselves well are less likely to suffer from these conditions. 'Smoking causes almost one in five coronary heart disease deaths,' explains the British Heart Foundation on its website. 'If you are under 50 and smoke, your risk of heart attack is up to ten times that of a non-smoker.'

And if you keep your salt intake down, do not get overweight, eat your fruit and vegetables, drink sensibly and take exercise, you are less likely to be one of the 300,000 people a year who suffer a heart attack (of whom about half survive).

It is also impossible to predict the future incidence of these conditions. About 100,000 people a year have a first stroke, according to the Stroke Association. Survival rates could increase substantially, according to its research, if, for instance, the Government sets up more Stroke Units, teams which can provide specialist emergency and rehabilitation treatment. Similarly, your likelihood of getting a heart attack could be reduced if, for example, more money is put into prevention, screening and earlier diagnosis.

However, it has to be said that more of us could suffer these illnesses as medical and pharmaceutical treatment improves, and our life expectancy increases. In a 1998 report for the Stroke Association, Professor Nick Bosanquet of Imperial College concluded: 'Numbers of patients with strokes needing longer-term support are increasing. We are achieving health promotion targets in reducing immediate mortality from stroke, but there is a new challenge of longer-term disability.'

Thinking about these risks, you may conclude that you would buy the insurance if you could easily afford it. But, as Charles Levett-Scrivener of financial adviser Towry Law says, the premiums can be quite substantial: 'The people who really need critical illness cover are parents and other people with dependents. But parents don't have a great deal of spare income, and they have other insurances to deal with, life cover and saving for retirement.'

On top of this, critical illness is a new kind of product - developed only in 1986 in South Africa by Dr Marius Barnard, brother of heart transplant pioneer Christian. This means that insurers have only 14 years of experience on claims. It could be that some of them have been over-cautious and have charged more than they needed to. Morgan, however, estimates that premiums have come down by about 10 per cent in the past year - 'mostly because of competition'.

Customers are also often given a better deal if they buy a critical illness policy on top of another product. Most sales used to be on the back of mortgage endowment policies, but since far fewer of these are now being sold, insurers are increasingly selling them in conjunction with more straightforward 'term' and 'whole of life' insurance policies. For instance, a 45-year old non-smoking woman paying for cover of £100,000 from Allied Dunbar would pay £57 a month for a combined critical illness and term assurance plan. If she bought the two products separately, she would pay 30 per cent more.

But you may still decide that the premiums are just too expensive. After all, as the Allied Dunbar statistics imply, the majority of people, at least 75 per cent of them, look unlikely to contract one of these illnesses until after pension age.

By that time, they have probably paid off their mortgage and have fewer financial commitments. And if you had put the money you could have spent on premiums into a pension, you could have a tidy sum awaiting you.

Even if you did contract something unpleasant, you would have that extra pension money to draw on. You could have accumulated £60,000 by investing £50 a month over the past 20 years in a with-profits pension plan, according to Your Pension magazine.

Young, free and... healthy

'Young people need to think about critical illness cover because so many of them own their own homes,' says a spokeswoman for Scottish Mutual, one of the market leaders. Insurers and financial advisers are very eager to sell these policies to the young. But are the young pouring their premiums down the drain?

By and large, the medical statistics suggest the common-sense conclusion most of us would come to: your risk of contracting a critical illness grows as you get older. About 41 per cent of NHS hospital treatment is for people aged over 65. Research from the Stroke Association indicates that only 10 per cent of the people who suffer a first stroke each year in England and Wales are under 55. The incidence of heart attacks follows increasing age, according to the British Heart Foundation. Only 13 per cent of male heart attack sufferers are below 65 (7 per cent of female sufferers).

Of course, not all illnesses show this correlation. Aids, for instance, has been more of a young person's affliction (although it is usually excluded from critical illness policies). But - as the spokeswoman for Scottish Mutual suggests - although the risk for twenty- and thirty-somethings may be lower, they are probably more financially exposed than older people.

webTitle: Breaking out from the mortgage cage

fields.headline: Breaking out from the mortgage cage
fields.standfirst: Virginia Wallis steers you round the repayment pitfalls
fields.trailText: Virginia Wallis steers you round the repayment pitfalls.
fields.body:
Here is a crumb of comfort for the many thousands of people who have been told that their endowments are not on track to repay their mortgage loans: at least you know there's a problem.

If you have an interest-only mortgage backed by another sort of investment - such as a Pep, Isa or personal pension - you may be blissfully unaware that your situation could be equally bleak. But unlike people with endowments, who are all being written to, you will find out whether you face a potential shortfall only if you take steps to check for yourself.

So what, precisely, am I supposed to check?

That you are paying enough into your chosen investment to ensure having a big enough lump sum to pay off your mortgage.

But they worked all that out when the mortgage started, so I can't see that there's a problem.

When was that?

Ten years ago.

I'd get some up-to-date calculations done.

Why?

Two reasons: first, before 1995, figures illustrating potential payouts didn't have to include real charges; second, they were allowed to assume much higher growth rates than they are now. Unless you've been advised to increase savings, or your investment is worth what they said it would be, you're probably looking at a shortfall. What kind of investment are you using to back your mortgage?

A personal pension plan.

Do you get a lot of marriage proposals?

What's that got to do with anything?

Pension mortgages are only suitable for the seriously wealthy.

I'm not self-employed, I'm not rich and if you must know, I'm finding the £150 a month for my pension plan a bit of a struggle.

Does it help to know that with tax relief your £150 monthly contribution is worth nearly £200?

Not much.

How big is your mortgage?

£50,000.

So you'll need your pension fund to be worth £200,000 when you retire.

But that's four times the size of my loan.

It has to be because the Inland Revenue limits the amount of cash you can take from your pension to a quarter of the fund. The rest must buy an annuity. Do you know what your pension fund is currently worth?

Just under £40,000.

Well, the good news is that if you carry on putting £200 a month into your pension for the next 15 years and the fund continues to grow by 9 per cent a year, you won't be homeless in your old age.

And the bad news?

Given that 9 per cent is now the highest rate of growth pension companies can use when projecting future fund values, assuming that your fund will grow at that rate after charges smacks of wild optimism.

So I may not be able to pay off my mortgage. What should I do?

One option would be to convert your mortgage to a repayment for the remainder of the term. But your mortgage payment would have to go up. That would mean reducing what you pay into your pension.

Any other suggestions?

You could complain that you were given bad advice, on the grounds that a pension mortgage is unsuitable for someone who may lose their job or who could go to work for an employer who runs an occupational pension scheme. You would have an even stronger case if using a part of your pension to repay the mortgage means paying interest for longer than 25 years, or having to take your pension at an unsuitably young age. You could also complain if you were persuaded to surrender an endowment policy for a personal pension plan.

How do I go about it?

Complain to the company that sold you the pension and advised you to link it to your mortgage. If you reach deadlock, but want to take a complain further, phone the FSA Consumer Helpline (0845 606 1234) for advice on how to do this. Alternatively, ask the FSA Leafletline (0800 917 3311) for a copy of the FSA Guide to Making a Complaint.

fields.headline: Bonds to help pay for your children at university
fields.trailText: Providing cash to pay for education is no longer a matter of funding school fees until the age of 18.
fields.body:
Putting your child through education is becoming an extremely expensive business. Providing cash to pay for education is no longer a matter of funding school fees until the age of 18 - now many parents face the hefty cost of getting their children through university as well.

Although students are able to borrow up to £4,590 a year through low-charging student loans, many parents are reluctant to let their offspring build up a legacy of debt. The answer is to plan ahead to make sure that extra funds are available when they are needed.

As with any financial planning, the earlier you start saving the cheaper it will be.

John and Rosalind Atkinson (pictured with their family) decided to take out a tax-efficient friendly society bond earlier this year for their son, Owen, who was born in February 1998. They currently contribute £40 a month to the Tunbridge Wells Equitable University Bond, a plan designed specifically to help fund the costs of putting children through further education. 'We are hoping to send our son to university when he is old enough,' says Mrs Atkinson. 'The University Bond should be a good help towards the fees that will be payable.'

Friendly society bonds allow everybody - including children - to invest up to £25 a month in a tax-free environment, with the proceeds at the end of the term also being totally tax-free. The Tunbridge Wells EquitableUniversity Bond, which has a minimum investment level of £40 a month (£25 of which can be invested for tax free returns, with the rest going into Tunbridge Wells' taxable fund), is unique in that it will pay out a lump sum on either three or four occasions - when the child reaches the ages of 18, 19, 20 and 21.

David White, the chief executive of Tunbridge Wells Equitable, believes that this is the only package in the market designed specifically to provide funds for university fees. 'It has been designed to provide what a student needs, which is three or four years' consecutive payments,' he says.

The University Bond can be set up in either the name of the child or the parents. Each method has its own merits. If the policy is written in the name of the child, it belongs to the child although he or she cannot have control over the policies until the age of 16.

If the bond is written in the name of the parents, they retain control of the policies and the proceeds when they mature, but this means they will not be able to take out a plan for themselves, as you can only contribute to one friendly society bond at a time.

Mr and Mrs Atkinson have opted to keep the bond written in Mrs Atkinson's name. 'In this way we can be in control as parents,' says Mrs Atkinson. 'We liked the fact that the child has no access to the funds.' But what happens to the University Bond if Master Atkinson decides that, at 18, he does not want to go to university? That is no problem, says White. 'The money does not have to be used for university fees. The parents will have a choice of what to do with a significant amount of money over three or four years.'

The money could, for instance, be used as a deposit for Owen's first home, to buy a car or to travel round the world.

Tunbridge Wells Equitable has sold between 4,000 and 5,000 University Bonds, with the figure increasing all the time. The average premium size is £100 a month and bonds are, in general, being taken out for very young children.

According to White, saving for university fees is 'a long-term savings requirement'.

He says: 'The earlier parents start, the less pain there will be. And a bigger problem could be to tell a child that he or she cannot go to university because they cannot afford it.'

webTitle: Has M&S left it too late with its new look?

fields.headline: Sparks of hope but can they reignite Marks?
fields.standfirst: M&S has rung the changes with a new look but, says Heather Connon, the retailer may have left it too late
fields.trailText: M&S has rung the changes with a new look but, says Heather Connon, the retailer may have left it too late.
fields.body:
It was not easy to find among the litany of management departures, falling sales and rising costs, but there was some good news from Marks & Spencer last week.

Sales at its redesigned shops, dubbed concept stores, are 16 per cent ahead of last year. And turnover at those branches where it is testing 'local cataloguing' - corporate-speak for giving customers what they want - is, on average, 5 per cent ahead of comparable stores.

The trouble is, there are just three concept stores and only 31 with local cataloguing. The other 263 stores still look pretty much as they have for the past 10 years. Customers' attitudes to these stores are clear: group-wide, clothing sales in the past 24 weeks fell 1.4 per cent.

Rival Next, by contrast, is enjoying a 14 per cent sales increase. That, more than anything else, is the reason for the departure from M&S of chief executive Peter Salsbury. It is now more than two years since the boardroom ructions which marked the start of M&S's troubles, and seven months since Luc Vandevelde took over as executive chairman. Yet sales are still falling, new initiatives are only just starting to be rolled out and the company still seems to have no idea when the rot will stop.

Most observers - including Vandevelde himself - agree that Salsbury was doing the right things, but far too slowly. The concept stores are attractive. Clothes are displayed, rather than just stuck on rails, and arranged as outfits, rather than in rows and rows. The shops are more open, less stock is kept on the floor and more in the stockroom, making for less clutter.

Based on the success of the first three - at Sutton in south London, Fosse Park in Leicestershire and London's Kensington High Street - it will open a further 22 by the end of the year. Locations will include Liverpool, the Bluewater shopping centre in Kent, and Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire.

Nick Penny, head of marketing strategy, expects at least a further 50 conversions next year. After that? 'We need to look at resources,' he says. The budget for the first 25 is £60 million, an average of £2.4m each. On that basis, converting the rest would cost more than £600m.

Local cataloguing is less expensive but equally long overdue. Amazingly, M&S used to stock its stores according to their size, so Blackpool and Guildford would have exactly the same ranges. Following the trial, which started last spring, 60 stores are now stocked on the basis of what the customers there actually buy, rather than on how many of them there are. By next spring, the entire chain will have local cataloguing.

The initiative is based on an analysis of M&S's 4.5 million Chargecard holders, using questionnaires, focus groups and accompanied shopping trips. Some customers were even asked to photograph their houses and describe their holidays. This revealed 11 types of shopper, from family-focused mothers through 'shop-arounds' to the 'traditional brigade'.

The impact has been substantial. In the test stores, an average of a quarter of the stock has had to change. That has had a big impact on buying, too. Penny believes that when the change is complete next spring, about a third of the products the chain buys will change. 'But it should give us confidence to buy in more depth,' - leading to fewer mistakes and, he hopes, higher margins.

Will it work? A growing number of analysts doubt it. While M&S has struggled to reinvent itself, the rest of the high street has been changing rapidly. Discount chains such as Matalan have been growing fast. Indeed, Matalan announced last Friday that it is speeding up its expansion. Profits at traditional stores, from Debenhams to Dolcis, are being squeezed.

There is too much retail space in the high street, and M&S has much of it, thanks to a dash for growth by Vandevelde's predecessor, Sir Richard Greenbury. There are hints that a closure programme will be announced with the M&S results in November. That could be unpopular. Vandevelde could find that the threat of closing a local M&S is treated as a greater heresy than chopping a branch of Barclays.

But Vandevelde delayed too long in getting rid of Salsbury. He will not want to procrastinate again.
