webTitle: Internet shopping ends battling through crowded shops

fields.headline: From mousemat to the doormat
fields.standfirst:
A boom in internet shopping could mean an end to your weekly battle through crowded supermarkets. Jessica McCallin reports

Net news
fields.trailText: A boom in internet shopping could mean an end to your weekly battle through crowded supermarkets. Jessica McCallin reports
fields.body:
Grocery shopping over the internet is taking off fast, with figures from Tesco.com this week showing that it has signed up 750,000 customers and delivered its millionth order. And it's no longer just a pilot operation available from a few supermarkets; Tesco says it now covers 90% of the UK, a level not seen anywhere else in the world.

It's not just big-name supermarkets that are using the internet to sell groceries. Specialist grocers such as Simply Organic Food, which boasts more than 1,500 organic products ranging from fruit and veg to dog food, and Farmers Market Direct, a group of UK farmers who will deliver fresh meat and farm produce to your door, are also seeing business boom.

With this trend in mind Jobs & Money decided to investigate how easy online grocery shopping really is. The good news for supermarket phobes is that early gremlins in the systems have been cleaned out, and the supermarkets' sites are fairly straightforward to use. It varies somewhat between store groups - and Safeway is notable by its absence from the virtual world - but, broadly speaking, a first-time shopper need only log on to the supermarket's website and type in their postcode.

This is the first step. Not all supermarkets deliver nationwide, so putting in your postcode will establish if your chosen store operates in your area. It will also pinpoint which branch will do the delivery and make sure you only get that branch's shopping list - avoiding a situation where you merrily pick products stocked in the out-of-town hypermarket only to discover that the inner-city branch which will be serving you has only a quarter of the goods in stock.

You then go into the supermarket's lists and click on the items you want. Once you've finished, just enter your delivery details and choose a time for the goods to be dropped off.

It's at this stage that the service varies from store to store. With Sainsbury's, for example, you can enter your credit card details while you are ordering. But with Asda, you pay the driver who delivers your goods. There are also slight variations on the delivery times offered by each supermarket. Most have an order deadline ranging from noon to 4pm for next day delivery. Some charge £5 per delivery and others £3 or even nothing.

Some will deliver between 9am and 9pm, others between 8am and 10pm. Some work seven days a week, while others are shut on Sundays. Most will ask you to choose a two-hour time slot on a delivery day when someone will need to be at home.

However, some, such as Simply Organic Food, will leave your order in the garden shed or with a neighbour. All you have to do is leave special instructions for the driver when you are processing your order.

The more specialised the company, the more likely it is that you will have to be flexible on delivery times. If you're ordering pork from Farmers Market Direct, for example, and have just missed out on one batch of pigs being slaughtered, you may have to wait a few days for the next batch to go. The pay-off is that the meat is guaranteed to be British, from the same source you bought it from last time, and reared in accordance with the RSPCA's Freedom Food Welfare Scheme.

Whoever you shop with, you should be able to save your shopping list file, so you don't have to scour the website for your most popular buys each time you place an order - supermarkets offer around 25,000 products, but most customers buy only 250 different ones in a year. You should also be able to save delivery and payment details, lessening the amount of time you spend online each time you order. Similarly, most of the nationwide supermarkets let online shoppers collect points on their store loyalty cards, although at present you have to redeem them in one of the shops.

The main downside of online grocery shopping is that if you log on during the peak evening and weekend times, or have a slow modem on your computer, you may find yourself sitting in front of your monitor for several hours, wondering whether the queues at the check-out could possibly be worse.

In addition, the delivery slots are allocated on a first-come first-serve basis. So it's not a good idea to process an order on December 24 and expect the delivery any time before the New Year. Other than that, you'll have to rely on the initiative of the supermarket's packers if one of your orders is not in stock. It's up to them to choose the closest substitutes.

But if that sounds like a small price to pay for never having to set foot in a supermarket again, give it a try.

Whoever you shop with, you should be able to save your shopping list file, so you don't have to scour the website for your most popular buys each time you place an order - supermarkets offer around 25,000 products, but most customers buy only 250 different ones in a year. You should also be able to save delivery and payment details, lessening the amount of time you spend online each time you order. Similarly, most of the nationwide supermarkets let online shoppers collect points on their store loyalty cards, although at present you have to redeem them in one of the shops. The main downside of online grocery shopping is that if you log on during the peak evening and weekend times, or have a slow modem on your computer, you may find yourself sitting in front of your monitor for several hours, wondering whether the queues at the check-out could possibly be worse. In addition, the delivery slots are allocated on a first-come first-serve basis. So it's not a good idea to process an order on December 24 and expect the delivery any time before the New Year. Other than that, you'll have to rely on the initiative of the supermarket's packers if one of your orders is not in stock. It's up to them to choose the closest substitutes. But if that sounds like a small price to pay for never having to set foot in a supermarket again, give it a try.

webTitle: Sad history of a bad product

fields.headline: Sad history of a bad product
fields.trailText: Endowments were widely sold as a mortgage repayment vehicle from the early 80s until the mid 90s. But their projected returns rely on investment assumptions at the policy's outset lasting until the plan matured - usually 25 years.
fields.body:
Endowments were widely sold as a mortgage repayment vehicle from the early 80s until the mid 90s. But their projected returns rely on investment assumptions at the policy's outset lasting until the plan matured - usually 25 years.

Now, with lower inflation and lower likely investment returns, those assumptions - based on annual gains of up to 13% - have had to be questioned. The Financial Services Authority has ordered all endowment providers to look again at progress of the plans.

But this time, they must project on rates of 8%, 6% and 4% - with the middle growth level seen as the most important - for the remainder of the policy.

Most endowments are "front-end loaded" which is to say, investment growth in the first years goes largely to sellers and insurance companies, so even plans which were taken out in the early 90s have reaped little of the high returns of the past. Insurers are now sending out letters with new investment forecasts based on these rates.

Policies that will show a shortfall at 8% are classed "red"; those that that fail at a growth rate of between 6% and 8% are in the amber category, while plans that will succeed on 6% or below are labelled "green".

As at the end of August 2000, 3.8m re-projection letters had been sent. According to the Association of British Insurers (ABI) 57.5% were green, 29.9% amber, and 10.4% red. But these first letters went to those with older plans, most of which have performed well.

More recent policies present more problems. Of the 6m still to receive re-projection letters, the ABI estimates 60% will fall into the red or amber category.

But these consumers should not expect FSA sympathy or compensation. It says: "Holders of endowments have enjoyed returns which mean they have fared at least as well as they would have done with a repayment mortgage. There are therefore no grounds for an industry-wide review."

Shortfall victims who believe they were led into an endowment by extravagant promises must firstly protest either to the insurer or the sale operation. Only when they have been refused help - known as "deadlock" - can they turn appeal to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

 There are consumer help leaflets on www.fsa.gov.uk

fields.headline: Only connect
fields.standfirst:
Labour's challenge next week

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Just for once the biggest headache at the Labour party conference won't be the Labour party. For leaders past, the challenge of the annual seaside conference came from restless delegates and frustrated activists, spoiling for a fight. That probably won't be the case at the gathering which starts in Brighton tomorrow. There had threatened to be a couple of showdowns on pensions and asylum seekers, but both those grievances ought to be seen off before they erupt into all-out floor fights. No, the real problem this time is not inside the hall: it is outside.
fields.body:
Just for once the biggest headache at the Labour party conference won't be the Labour party. For leaders past, the challenge of the annual seaside conference came from restless delegates and frustrated activists, spoiling for a fight. That probably won't be the case at the gathering which starts in Brighton tomorrow. There had threatened to be a couple of showdowns on pensions and asylum seekers, but both those grievances ought to be seen off before they erupt into all-out floor fights. No, the real problem this time is not inside the hall: it is outside.

The party gathers at its lowest ebb since Tony Blair became leader. The polls show the Tories ahead, for the first time since 1992. The once all-conquering team of Mr Blair and Gordon Brown now appear unfamiliarly defensive: the former wobbling during the fuel crisis, the latter forced to tour the TV studios to prove that he did not lie over the Bernie Ecclestone affair three years ago. The problems have piled on at merciless speed, with the first signs of panic beginning to spread to the backbenches. Even loyal Blairites have begun to think the once unthinkable: what about... defeat? More worrying, too many Labour advocates have floundered in recent days. In TV debates they have seemed barely able to defend the government against the now-cliched charges of arrogance and incompetence. Instead, they have looked shell-shocked, befuddled by the depth of hostility towards the government they serve.

The leadership has to turn that situation around. Not just Mr Blair, though he needs to deliver the speech of his life on Tuesday, but Mr Brown and the rest of the heavy hitters. The party needs to be cheered up, certainly, but the chief task is to dispel once and for all the spreading notion that a Labour party which once had such a canny feel for the public pulse is now out of touch. It is a tall order. For how can a politician simultaneously convey that he is listening and that he is strong, unswayed by the mood swings of the focus groups? How can he be both in touch and principled, both servant and leader, at the same time? Yet this is what the Britain of the petrol blockades seems to want from its governors.

Perhaps the best course will be for Labour to keep its head on the substance - where, broadly, its record remains good and its programme sound - but strive hard to find a language that connects and stirs. Labour has done it before - quite recently. This week it must do it again.

fields.headline: Brown's worst week
fields.standfirst:
Hero to zero: the chancellor knows he must come out fighting after an avalanche of adversity buried the summer's plaudits

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The case for: he is the intellectual driving force behind the government and New Labour's master strategist. He is the country's most successful post-war chancellor and will ride out the storms.
fields.body:
The case for: he is the intellectual driving force behind the government and New Labour's master strategist. He is the country's most successful post-war chancellor and will ride out the storms.

The case against: he is too clever by half, his arrogant mistakes have badly damaged Labour, and he will not be able to escape responsibility for Labour falling behind the Tories in the polls.

Both descriptions could be heard about Gordon Brown over recent days as friends and foes took up positions to attack or defend the chancellor.

Besieged on three fronts, he has just endured his worst week at the Treasury, eclipsing even the single currency fiasco when the government's euro policy was announced across the road in the Red Lion public house.

The most vocal critics have been the Tories, with their newfound trucker allies. Yet as Labour prepared for tomorrow's start of its conference in Brighton, the enemy appeared at times to be "colleagues" seizing the opportunity to settle more than a few scores.

Cabinet ministers, MPs and some in No 10 blame him for the petrol crisis, complaining he failed to spot it coming and provoked the protesters and public by taking a tough line against cuts in duty.

Barbara Castle and Jack Jones, formidable champions for higher pensions, were at his Monday night wedding reception demanding not champagne but the restoration of the link with earnings.

And then Brown was accused of lying in Labour's biggest sleaze scandal.

This was avalanche politics. He had gone from hero to virtually zero within two months as the man lauded in July for a £43bn vote-winning spending spree was being accused in September of risking electoral defeat.

Brown's package for pensioners, his TV interviews, and yesterday's decision to risk the wrath of europhobic newspapers by propping up the euro, suggest he knows he must come out fighting.

At stake are his belief in higher public spending over tax cuts, and ultimately his ambition to succeed Tony Blair, which would almost certainly require him to remain chancellor after the next election with Blair stepping down mid-way through the parliament.

Close aides concede Brown has felt under pressure but insist he has not panicked, juggling the three problems in the search for solutions.

The only time he was angry, they maintain, was on Wednesday, when ITN's 6.30pm news ran with the Tory charges that he had run away to Malta to escape.

"He was really annoyed," said the aide. "Gordon had got up at 5.30am, flew to Malta for a Commonwealth finance ministers' meeting, and got back in the Treasury at 5.20pm, less than 12 hours later. No wonder he was annoyed."

But the chancellor's enemies complain that he is never at the scene of the crime when things go pear-shaped, leaving others to face the flak. His friends ask where is the long queue of virtuous ministers, snaking around Westminster, volunteering to take the blame whenever anything goes wrong?

Brown's survival instincts are strong, however, and in the fall-out over controversial cuts in single parent benefit he backed shortly after Labour's May 1997 win, a hapless Harriet Harman was left to carry the can.

Some of those closest to him whisper conspiratorially, however, that in the strange case of Bernie Ecclestone, Brown not so much fled the scene of the crime but was fitted up - thrown the £1m in the back of the prime minister's car so his fingerprints were left all over the cash.

According to those peddling this line, Blair showed what a consummate operator he is by leaving Brown in no position to push him under one of Ecclestone's F1 cars.

"Gordon should have told Blair's driver to stop the car, jumped out and walked back to the Treasury," said an associate. "But what could he do when Tony asked his advice? By even knowing there was a problem he became part of the problem. He's still kicking himself."

Brown's George Washingon defence - "I would not lie" - was bolstered by Andrew Rawnsley misquoting the chancellor in his book Servants of the People. Brown was not so much angry as furious that he was put in the frame for Ecclestone and, as his aides admit, when mud is thrown some always sticks.

If Blair and Brown recognise they sink or swim together, Brown and Peter Mandelson remain at daggers drawn and the briefing and counter-briefing will continue. A No 10 "poison" squad has been blamed for the Ecclestone allegations.

Petrol is Brown's biggest problem and he is going out of his way last week to stress he has a driving licence and owns a car to counter claims he is anti-motorist.

Demonstrators are clamouring for his head - Michael Portillo made a mistake demanding his resignation over the Ecclestone charges rather than fuel; he ensured Brown was safe - and Labour MPs echo the complaints of constituents that prices are too high.

Brown may be playing the old trick of publicly offering little while privately planning to pull something rout of the bag in November's pre-budget statement if oil prices continue to rise. Defying the petrol demonstrators' 60-day deadline is risky; to offer the drivers nothing would be extremely dangerous.

As a Northern MP put it: "He has got more cash coming in then he knows what to do with it so why jeopardise a second term for 3p a litre? We are stuck in a cul-de-sac over fuel and we have to reverse our way out."

He will be in Brighton next week for barely 12 hours for the second year running, flying into Britain from the IMF in Prague, making his speech then flying back to the Czech capital.

Yet with the chancellor under fire on three fronts and Labour slipping behind in the polls, Brown showed no signs of the stress as he cracked jokes with guests in London's trendy Jerwood Space gallery at the reception on Monday night to celebrate his marriage to Sarah Macaulay. Master strategist or too clever by half? Is he damaged permanently or will he recover? Will he ever be Labour leader?

We will find out some time after the next election.

fields.headline: Short shrift
fields.standfirst:
If only others had such candour

Special report: in power
fields.trailText: She is off again. On Question Time the other night Clare Short said what they all believe but cannot bring themselves to say out loud. The Millennium Dome is a flop, a disaster, and the government should get free of it as quickly as possible. Saying that causes no more damage than has been inflicted on the Blairites' reputation since that fateful evening last December 31. Good old motor mouth.
fields.body:
She is off again. On Question Time the other night Clare Short said what they all believe but cannot bring themselves to say out loud. The Millennium Dome is a flop, a disaster, and the government should get free of it as quickly as possible. Saying that causes no more damage than has been inflicted on the Blairites' reputation since that fateful evening last December 31. Good old motor mouth.

She is right and, as a West Midlands MP, has every reason to feel miffed about a project given to London rather than Birmingham having gone belly up. That is not the point. She has been wrong before (her defence of globalisation) and used inappropriate language (Montserrat). What is at stake here is more than the earthy candour she often brings to public affairs. It is about the conduct of public life, its "discourse". Wouldn't public disaffection with politics be less if the cabinet had a few more characters?

Of course Labour needed to fit itself for office by sloughing off the petulant and self-indulgent sniping that had characterised its leadership for too long - and which was on daily display in the 90s from the Major cabinet. But reasonable togetherness should not mean draining all colour and vivacity from public utterance. Pollsters say the public dislikes strife among political leaders; but it also appreciates sincerity and the self-confidence to speak your mind. Big hitters of the Healey, Clarke, Heseltine mould succeeded by talking in their own terms, in their own tone.

The lack of response yesterday to Ms Short may merely have been a sign that pumps and polls have left No 10 punch drunk. Let's hope, however, that it was a sign of an administration that is maturing, that can distinguish solidarity of purpose from note-perfect harmony. Clare Short's husky alto adds to the chorus. The bum note - the Greenwich dome - was not hers. If only Tony Blair could bring himself to admit as much next week.

fields.headline: Making pensions add up
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee (Targets for pensions, September 22) echoes the view that the pension fund is a pot of money that can be redistributed as politicians please. One hears all the time that the government is "giving" the pensioners such and such, that the pension should not go to those who "do not need it". We are being brainwashed into regarding the state pension as a charity.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee (Targets for pensions, September 22) echoes the view that the pension fund is a pot of money that can be redistributed as politicians please. One hears all the time that the government is "giving" the pensioners such and such, that the pension should not go to those who "do not need it". We are being brainwashed into regarding the state pension as a charity.

State pension contributions are compulsory, the pension one receives is not a handout that should eventually disappear except for the very poor (a view that has been floated by both major parties and is being implemented by stealth).

The alleviation of the scandal of poverty among pensioners in Britain has to be addressed, but not by misappropriating the contributions of those who have an additional pension but are far from well off.
David Andrews
Glasgow andrews@oslo.fsnet.co.uk

Polly Toynbee urges the government to introduce a minimum £90 pension in April. This is the level the basic National Insurance pension would have reached if the link with earnings had been sustained. Moreover among couples in which the wife had a full contribution record (including up to 20 years looking after children) each would be getting £90. However, the Minimum Income Guarantee only provides couples with 160% of MIG. Evidence from research on pensioners' income and expenditure by the Basic Income Group shows that apart from housing costs, an adequate income for couples is close to twice that of single pensioners. Many poorer pensioners receive housing benefit.

I hope Polly Toynbee continues to urge the government to "promise a £100 for every pensioner for 2002" even if she does not accept that the best way to achieve this is by restoring the earnings' link for the basic state pension.
Hilary Land School for Policy Studies, Bristol
Hilary.Land@bristol.ac.uk

Polly Toynbee misses the point. There are two principal ways to achieve a redistribution of income: progressive taxation and means testing. The problem is that while most people are in favour of a more equal society, both taxes and means testing tend to be unpopular. Despite this, the left have hitherto favoured the former and the right the latter. Restoring the pensions- earnings link need not redistribute from poor to rich, provided the rich are taxed more progressively. A more generous MIG may limit inequalities at the bottom of income distribution, while leaving them intact at the top. It is only because New Labour has foresworn the possibility of higher taxes on higher incomes that it must resort to means-tested assistance for the poorest.
Prof Hartley Dean
University of Luton
hartley.dean@luton.ac.uk

Polly Toynbee is wrong to claim that the minimum pension is no more charity than the state pension. The National Insurance pension is the right of every working person. The government claim that higher income pensioners do not "need" their NI pensions is nonsense.

As for the MIG, all means-tested benefits which claimants experience as administrative discretion risk being felt as "state charity" and rejected by some eligible people. The government is incapable of solving this problem, and why should it? If it wants to be inclusive, it ought not to use means tests to solve the problems of poverty.

If the government wants to deal with the problem of higher income pensioners having too much money because they contributed both to occupational as well as NI pension schemes, and may have other income creating assets, then they should tax more heavily at higher income levels. At the very least, they should increase the NI pensions to decency levels at the Family Budget Unit recommendations and "clawback" the increase from richer pensioners to arrive at the desired outcome that low total income pensioners get more benefits by right and higher ones get it but don't keep it. It is far more efficient and effective than means testing.
Prof John Veit-Wilson
University of Newcastle upon Tyne

Polly Toynbee's endorsement of Gordon Brown's charity-case approach to pensioners is not acceptable. Mr Brown takes every opportunity to say that he does not believe in fudges and quick fixes, but this is all that pensioners are presented with. If we are a problem, it is essential that the resolution of the problem starts from the right position. The link to earnings is not just a bee in Barbara Castle's bonnet. Its (re-)acceptance would signal once and for all that our due place in society is acknowledged in terms of respect and the material dividend.
Bernard Hrusa-Marlow
Morden, Surrey

Hilary Land School for Policy Studies, Bristol Hilary.Land@bristol.ac.uk Polly Toynbee misses the point. There are two principal ways to achieve a redistribution of income: progressive taxation and means testing. The problem is that while most people are in favour of a more equal society, both taxes and means testing tend to be unpopular. Despite this, the left have hitherto favoured the former and the right the latter. Restoring the pensions- earnings link need not redistribute from poor to rich, provided the rich are taxed more progressively. A more generous MIG may limit inequalities at the bottom of income distribution, while leaving them intact at the top. It is only because New Labour has foresworn the possibility of higher taxes on higher incomes that it must resort to means-tested assistance for the poorest. Prof Hartley Dean University of Luton hartley.dean@luton.ac.uk Polly Toynbee is wrong to claim that the minimum pension is no more charity than the state pension. The National Insurance pension is the right of every working person. The government claim that higher income pensioners do not "need" their NI pensions is nonsense. As for the MIG, all means-tested benefits which claimants experience as administrative discretion risk being felt as "state charity" and rejected by some eligible people. The government is incapable of solving this problem, and why should it? If it wants to be inclusive, it ought not to use means tests to solve the problems of poverty. If the government wants to deal with the problem of higher income pensioners having too much money because they contributed both to occupational as well as NI pension schemes, and may have other income creating assets, then they should tax more heavily at higher income levels. At the very least, they should increase the NI pensions to decency levels at the Family Budget Unit recommendations and "clawback" the increase from richer pensioners to arrive at the desired outcome that low total income pensioners get more benefits by right and higher ones get it but don't keep it. It is far more efficient and effective than means testing. Prof John Veit-Wilson University of Newcastle upon Tyne Polly Toynbee's endorsement of Gordon Brown's charity-case approach to pensioners is not acceptable. Mr Brown takes every opportunity to say that he does not believe in fudges and quick fixes, but this is all that pensioners are presented with. If we are a problem, it is essential that the resolution of the problem starts from the right position. The link to earnings is not just a bee in Barbara Castle's bonnet. Its (re-)acceptance would signal once and for all that our due place in society is acknowledged in terms of respect and the material dividend. Bernard Hrusa-Marlow Morden, Surrey

fields.headline: Just say no
fields.standfirst:
A civil war within unionism is under way

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: This has been the naysayers' week in Northern Ireland. On Tuesday, the MI6 building in central London came under attack, perhaps from a rocket launcher stationed less than 500 yards away. Police detected the hand of the Real IRA, the men of violence who Scotland Yard believe staged two previous bomb attacks on the capital earlier this year.
fields.body:
This has been the naysayers' week in Northern Ireland. On Tuesday, the MI6 building in central London came under attack, perhaps from a rocket launcher stationed less than 500 yards away. Police detected the hand of the Real IRA, the men of violence who Scotland Yard believe staged two previous bomb attacks on the capital earlier this year. The Real IRA are avowed rejectionists who have never believed in the Good Friday agreement nor in the very notion of compromise which brought it about.

In the early hours of yesterday morning, the naysayers won a second victory. This time the rejectionists were not armed, nor were they republican - but they were intransigent. They made their stand in the parliamentary seat of South Antrim, where the voters bellowed a loud, throaty no to the peace process and to the agreement of 1998. By 822 votes, they rejected the Ulster Unionist party which had held the seat for generations, and chose instead one of Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionists: the sometime gospel singer, the Rev William McCrea.

The voters' message could not have been clearer. The DUP's signature tune is no: no to accommodation, no to power sharing with Sinn Fein, no to anything other than the old unionist hegemony. Not that the alternative on offer to the voters of South Antrim was some lily- livered moderate, preaching peace. On the contrary, the UUP candidate was the PR executive David Burnside, the same man who has repeatedly challenged David Trimble's cautiously pro-peace leadership. Presented with a choice of two rejectionists, one hardline, the other even harder, the voters chose the man who would say no the loudest.

What explains this shift? Mr McCrea clearly struck a nerve with his message that unionists had given too much for almost nothing in return. He argued that the early release of terrorist prisoners and the presence of Sinn Fein in government were both unacceptable sacrifices in the absence of the actual handover of IRA guns. The voters seem to have agreed. The trouble is, so did Mr Burnside. His campaign was almost indistinguishable from Mr McCrea's in its hostility to the Good Friday agreement. And this may explain the UUP's problem in South Antrim: in a contest of rejectionists, voters will always choose the real thing over the paler imitation. By trying to out-DUP the DUP, Mr Burnside was almost bound to fail. The pro-Trimble Ken Maginnis may have put his finger on it when he told colleagues yesterday that they had paid the price for their "ambivalence": they have not been as loud and clear in favour of the peace process as their enemies have against it.

The immediate concern is for the progressive, Trimble-ite wing of Ulster unionism. The leader may well face a challenge before the party's conference next month, if not sooner: he only narrowly survived when last taken on in March. The party itself could face a fresh offensive from the DUP, which has scented blood in a clutch of vulnerable UUP seats, including Mr Trimble's own. The civil war within unionism is under way.

But the greatest fear has to be that this battle does not stay bloodless. It is hard to see how long Northern Ireland's new dispensation can survive if one of the province's two traditions refuses to support it. If unionism is moving away from the agreement, then the agreement cannot stand indefinitely. Everyone knows what will fill the vacuum should the settlement collapse: violence. It is a dread prospect designed to cheer only Tuesday's bombers - and their allies.

fields.headline: Seeds of a new protest
fields.trailText: Your editorial on genetically modified crops (September 22) rightly pointed out that the government's whole position is built on the flimsiest of voluntary agreements with the biotech industry. But it is still perfectly possible for the government to regain control of events, by blocking all regulatory routes towards full commercial approval.
fields.body:
Your editorial on genetically modified crops (September 22) rightly pointed out that the government's whole position is built on the flimsiest of voluntary agreements with the biotech industry. But it is still perfectly possible for the government to regain control of events, by blocking all regulatory routes towards full commercial approval.

At present, only one crop in the farm scale trials has a commercial marketing consent - fodder maize. Before this can be sold to farmers it has also to be placed on the National Seed List. The first GM seed to be proposed for the list is none other than the fodder maize being used in the trials.

Over 200 people and groups have objected to this listing and a full hearing of evidence will commence in London on October 2 and in Manchester on November 13.

At the end of the hearings, the Ministry of Agriculture has to decide whether to allow listing. This is a crucial opportunity for the government to exert some control over the biotech industry.
Peter Riley
Friends of the Earth peter@foe.co.uk

Donald Reid's understanding of what GM actually means is fundamentally flawed (Letters, September 21). Yes, Lord Melchett's crops will indeed have been "genetically modified by years of selective breeding", but then so are all breeds of dog, which have, over millenia, been selectively bred for their desirable traits from one common source - the wolf.

The difference with GM is that a gene from one group of organisms may be inserted into a completely different set of organisms. That is what this "direct action" was all about, and we should be applauding them.
Stephen Potter
St Leonards-on-sea, E Sussex s.potter@usa.net

fields.headline: A measure of success
fields.trailText: Kwasi Gyan-Apenteng (Letters, September 22) is only partly right. The Olympics are an unequal contest, but not only between rich and poor. Size also matters. Equatorial Guinea is not only extremely poor but also extremely tiny.
fields.body:
Kwasi Gyan-Apenteng (Letters, September 22) is only partly right. The Olympics are an unequal contest, but not only between rich and poor. Size also matters. Equatorial Guinea is not only extremely poor but also extremely tiny.

Larger African countries, such as Kenya and Ethiopia, have made themselves forces to be reckoned with, at least in low-budget sports, partly thanks to having a large pool of potential athletes.

Conversely, Luxembourg is a very rich country with about the same population as Equatorial Guinea. It has all the facilities money can buy but it has not won an Olympic gold medal since 1952. A 10th place in the Triathlon last week was a matter for national rejoicing.

Britain, on the other hand, is a medium-to-large rich country, and our position in the medals table is at last starting to reflect that.
Henry Wickens
Waldbillig, Luxembourg HWickens@europarl.eu.int

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Blair faces defeat on Lords, about the results of an ICM poll, page 9, yesterday, we said that the survey found that Labour party members were overwhelmingly opposed to Mr Blair's decision to reject a fully elected House of Lords. We went on to say that 83% of Labour party members believed that at least half of the members of the reformed upper house should be elected. In both   of those statements we should have said Labour voters, not Labour party members. The response from Labour voters closely mirrored that from the electorate at large, of whom 78% said that at least half of the membership of the Lords should be elected.

fields.headline: Pass at red
fields.standfirst:
Safeguarding train commuters is expensive. So we'll just cut corners

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The joint inquiry into train protection systems opened this week and began the process of trying to assess how financially worthwhile it is for rail operators to stop killing the public.
fields.body:
The joint inquiry into train protection systems opened this week and began the process of trying to assess how financially worthwhile it is for rail operators to stop killing the public.

The current cost benefit analyses used by the rail industry shows the value of a human life going up. Until last year, it was hovering around the £2.7m mark, but it seems to have risen to £5.5m. The government's education policies must be working, as the value added seems remarkable. It is good to know that we are worth so much more than we were. We must have turned round our IT skills no end. We are also better at cricket and the less athletic Olympic events such as Cluedo and bar billiards.

Of course it is all based on perception, which means focus groups. Academics conduct surveys on what is called "Willingness to Pay". People are presented with questionnaires, with questions phrased in certain ways, tastefully of course. A professor doesn't ask people to make judgments about the attractiveness of people on trains, how worth living their lives are, how many are first class or how much they spend in the buffet. Well, I don't think he does anyway. I believe the general thrust of these surveys is to ascertain how much people are prepared to pay collectively for safe travel. What they are not told is that, until they collectively reclaim the railways from the privateers who took them, it is the shareholders and not the public who hold the purse strings anyway.

Of course, much depends on one's concept of a lot of money: £5.5m is a great deal of money, unless it is your annual bonus. These things are relative, so focus groups look at the different things money can be spent on. People are asked to compare the importance of rail safety to that of road safety, which immediately creates a false antithesis in the mind of the subject, as though somehow the victims and bereaved of Southall and Ladbroke Grove are advocating the scrapping of the speed limit and that traffic cops should be serving drinks on the hard shoulder.

Of course, there are many more deaths on the roads, partly because there are many more people on the roads. And to tackle road safety, we have to influence the behaviour of thousands of individuals. To tackle rail safety, we simply have to bring a few charges for corporate manslaughter, if we are not going to take the railways back into public ownership.

Once people get behind the wheel of a car, they know, if they remember their basic training, that what they are doing is very dangerous to themselves and others if they are not vigilant. Rail travel is not like that. Most of us are passengers. Part of what we are paying for is the fact that we can drink Stella, read the paper and feel able to assume that we are not a split second away from death.

Once you have taken your seat on a train, safety is completely out of your hands, unless you are the overtired, underpaid person whose job it is to spot all the signals cleverly hidden in the overhead gear. That one driver has responsibility for hundreds of lives, although overall responsibility lies with the executives who, broadly speaking, are better off the more negligent they are.

Some rail companies don't want to install Automatic Train Protection (ATP) for the simple reason that it is the safest available system, and therefore more expensive than the alternative. The Train Protection Warning System (TPWS) is cheaper because it is not as good. To most of us, the cost of ATP would seem a price worth paying for an end to fatal rail disasters, but most of us are not directors or shareholders in rail companies, so it is easier for us to say. We could, I suppose, do a more elaborate utilitarian costing than the ones they use. We could factor-in things like the loss of working days after rail crashes, the cost of public inquiries, the loss of prestige to our public transport system and our country, but there is no way around the fact that crappy, dangerous technology is quite cheap and advanced technology isn't.

We could say that if we spent a hell of a lot more on rail generally, as we should, it would take traffic off the roads, making them safer. But as more people travel on the railways, we are asking them to put their trust in operators who clearly don't deserve it. And a freight train isn't a passenger train but it can certainly crash into one.

To be fair to TPWS, it isn't too bad at stopping trains that aren't going very fast. Unfortunately, it is those pesky high-speed collisions that for some reason make a mess of the punters. And as we get more and faster trains on to the rails we can expect more deaths, so the casualty figures coldly used in cost benefit studies are all going to be out of date anyway.

But profiteers are shortsighted, and they will pass that signal when they come to it.

fields.headline: Making war
fields.trailText: If civil war doesn't immediately follow the election in Serbia (Milosevic tightens grip as support swells for rivals, September 22), it could break out later - especially if Milosevic fuels one in Montenegro.
fields.body:
If civil war doesn't immediately follow the election in Serbia (Milosevic tightens grip as support swells for rivals, September 22), it could break out later - especially if Milosevic fuels one in Montenegro.

He started his first in Slovenia. Next came Croatia, then Bosnia, then Kosovo. Next on the list seems to be be Montenegro. When that's over, unless Slobo turns his attention on Macedonia, Serbia itself will be next. Montenegrins are Orthodox and Slav like the Serbs themselves. So what is to stop the tyrant and his followers eventually turning on his own people - especially now that the majority of Serbs will not vote for him?
Clare Hartley
London

fields.headline: Abolition and the IMF
fields.trailText: George Monbiot kindly refers to our recent critique of the democratic deficit at the IMF and World Bank as "devastating" (Helping the poorest to get poorer, September 20). But he seems disappointed that we merely conclude that a new constitutional settlement for the world economy needs to be grown from the roots up, and that we need to force financial institutions through a process of fundamental democratic reform.
fields.body:
George Monbiot kindly refers to our recent critique of the democratic deficit at the IMF and World Bank as "devastating" (Helping the poorest to get poorer, September 20). But he seems disappointed that we merely conclude that a new constitutional settlement for the world economy needs to be grown from the roots up, and that we need to force financial institutions through a process of fundamental democratic reform.

Having criticised virtually every aspect of the IMF and World Bank, to stop short of calling for their outright abolition is made to appear to be arguing in their favour. I'd like to thank George for giving me the vicarious thrill of ideological cross-dressing.

Just because the fund and bank are not doing their jobs (or because they are doing the wrong job) doesn't mean that we don't need international institutions to iron out the vast inequalities of the global economy. Or agencies to prevent any further meltdowns in the anarchic financial markets, and the human misery they produce.

Economic policies should be shaped at the local level using initiatives such as citizens' juries and issue forums. At the World Bank they know that only genuine local participation makes projects and policies work - yet all the big decisions are still taken by an aristocratic economic minority on their board.

Economic democracy has become one of the central struggles of our time. The fund and bank's limited and misguided economic mission should take a back seat to the environment and human development targets agreed internationally.

If the global economy was an ungoverned free-for-all the poorest people would suffer most. The answer to many of our problems, as we say in the title of our report is: It's democracy, stupid. All we are doing, of course, is asking for the moon. But it is preferable to jumping into a black hole.
Andrew Simms
Head of the global economy programme, New Economics Foundation

fields.headline: Full house at the dome
fields.trailText: Clare Short showed her usual refreshing honesty in calling for the early closure of the Millennium Dome (Short pours scorn on dome 'flop', September 22). Before this happens, could she possibly arrange for some of her ministerial colleagues - especially Peter Mandelson - to come to the dome and apologise? This would guarantee a rare full house.

fields.headline: Computacenter hit
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: It has not been a great few weeks for Computacenter, which yesterday took the full force of the technology slide sparked by Intel's profits warning.
fields.body:
It has not been a great few weeks for Computacenter, which yesterday took the full force of the technology slide sparked by Intel's profits warning.

Last month the company posted halved pre-tax interim profits and warned of sustained pressure on margins.

Yesterday its share price dropped by 17.5p to 372.5p, having been one of the biggest fallers in early trading.

Although the fallout from Intel was felt across the sector, analysts said that Computacenter was harder hit because of its earlier warning.

But the prospects for technology firms do not bode well in light of the US corporation's opinion that demand for personal computers was not growing at the expected rate.

Observers say that the next few months should show whether this is likely to be a long-term issue for the industry to tackle or just a temporary setback.

webTitle: The era of them and us is now in the past

fields.headline: The era of them and us is now in the past
fields.standfirst: Michael Pounsford, chief executive of Banner McBride, looks at leadership in the 21st century and how skills vital for survival can be nurtured
fields.trailText: Michael Pounsford, chief executive of Banner McBride, looks at leadership in the 21st century and how skills vital for survival can be nurtured
fields.body:
What kind of business leadership is required in the era of e-commerce? Is it more of the same, or is a different style required to create and sustain companies that are flatter, faster and focused?

Some of today's new economy organisations are growing at breathtaking speed and rely on responsiveness to individual customer needs. There are no clear precedents and little chance to refer to some higher authority for guidance.

In start-up organisations motivation and emotional engagement are not the issue. People have sacrificed job security for high-risk ventures in the anticipation of big returns. And where the new business is the spin-off from a traditional organisation, they need to understand that the old ways of working will not lead to success.

Already there is another category of organisation emerging: the post-boom dot.com, where initial enthusiasm and hype have given way to falling share prices and where retention of staff is emerging as an issue.

Companies that survive will be those that recognise the need for effective leadership. In the past 100 years, leadership has changed. In the early part of the 20th century, the style was often paternalistic. Communication was top-down, with little opportunity for the grassroots to contribute. A clear distinction existed between "them" and "us": workers and management. Employees were told what to do and not valued as having a contribution to make to the business. It was unnecessary for them to understand their organisation's vision or values.

Today's workforce is a totally different entity. People are expected, and want, to use their own initiative. Within dot.coms, decisions have to be made in a fast-moving environment without reference to anybody else. People are very often managing themselves. There simply isn't the time to wait for their line manager to provide direction. So they need a clear framework of criteria that should be applied to decisions they make. Good leaders will provide this. It's not enough to manage - they have to lead.

In the last 30 years organisations that have been successful have leaders who recognise that their people are their single greatest asset. They have used effective communication to ensure that their people have a greater understanding of how the leader wants to grow the business, what the goals are, and how they can contribute to achieving them.

Good leaders are those who provide vision, motivate their people, generate enthusiasm, celebrate success, provide a focus for the organisation and clarify future direction. These qualities are still important in today's e-commerce environment and one person has to provide them; it can't be shared. While leadership skills can be encouraged, leadership itself is not a team effort. Clear direction must come from the top.

Companies such as Virgin with Richard Branson, Tesco with Terry Leahy, Southwest Airlines with Herb Kelleher, and BP Amoco with Sir John Browne are all excellent examples. They have key features in common. They all share a belief in the value of their people; they all regard internal communication as a business investment and believe it's what you do, not what you say, that counts.

Terry Leahy, Tesco's CEO, when asked to prioritise press versus staff, chose staff as the more important audience. BP Amoco's Sir John Browne believes that their strongest asset is the quality of their people and discusses performance issues with all staff via the internet and email. Herb Kelleher publishes the home phone numbers of every officer and director to all staff.

We have seen a rapid growth in dot.com businesses and some spectacular failures. It is interesting that dot.coms proving successful are those that already had an old economy, non e-commerce background such as Tesco and First Direct.

Both have leaders who understand the importance of sharing vision, communicating internally, demonstrating how their people can deliver. They decided not to go "live" on their e-commerce offer until they were sure their people understood the reasons for the move and their roles in making it successful.

The next 20 years will be interesting. The twin challenges of globalisation and the speed of change must be met head on. But leaders of any business still need to balance confidence and urgency, recognition and reprimand, inspiration and pragmatism. The leader will still need to call the shots on the decisions that shape the ultimate success of the business- key decisions about who gets hired, who gets fired and who needs to get inspired. Some things will not change.

 Michael Pounsford can be contacted at Banner McBride on 0207-845-5710 or by email michael.pounsford@bannermcbride.com.

fields.headline: Plotting a course to get into print
fields.standfirst: Publishing
fields.trailText: If you were to believe the hype of lurid posters promoting the next literary bestseller which cry out for attention at every Underground station platform and bus shelter, or newspaper stories shrieking about the massive advances for first novels from unknown authors, you would think that writing a book was a fast train to bonanza town.
fields.body:
If you were to believe the hype of lurid posters promoting the next literary bestseller which cry out for attention at every Underground station platform and bus shelter, or newspaper stories shrieking about the massive advances for first novels from unknown authors, you would think that writing a book was a fast train to bonanza town.

Even experts in the industry are bullish: Richard Beswick, editorial director at Little, Brown & Co, a publishing house known for promoting first novels, would argue that writing talent is being snapped up. "It is not very difficult to get published. If you are a good writer, if your novel has a good narrative with good characterisation and a good plot, you will be published."

But the reality behind the glamour is that, although fulfilling in terms of creativity and self-expression, writing is rarely financially rewarding and can be a solitary lifestyle peppered with rejections.

Literary agent Hannah Griffiths of Curtis Brown says that agents can go for eight months without hitting on a sample chapter suitable to show to a commissioning editor. Real spine-tinglers, books she thinks will change the reader's life and the shape of literary history, are even more rare. In her eight years as an agent she has found just three such manuscripts. At the time of this interview she had 17 novels on her desk waiting to be read.

And even when a commission is bagged, the prizes are hardly glittering. A Society of Authors report published earlier this year showed that 50% of writers earn less than the minimum wage and just one in 10 earns a living from writing. The reality is made more painful by inaccurate reporting of mass advances: Magnus Mills, the bus driver allegedly paid a £1m advance for his novel The Restraint of Beasts in fact received less than £10,000.

One essential detail is that the aspiring author will need to write him or herself into a second job, although this is not necessarily always negative: Philip Larkin and TS Eliot were salaried employees throughout their writing life. "Dead-end jobs bring you into contact with lots of interesting characters who can inspire your writing," says Cathy Rosario, who has been writing novels for two and a half years and has yet to be published. She adds that while these jobs do not sap her emotional energy they are low-paid and so consume time.

Most authors will tell you that finding an agent is as difficult as getting the green light from a publisher. Agents with well-known authors on their lists receive 10-20 synopses or full novels a week, while a smaller agent would expect to see between five and 10. This is a lot of reading.

"Writers often get a sense that they are being rejected out of hand, but often it is because they have not spent any time thinking about it. No one has time to read 400 pages a day, so your whole life becomes a decision of what to take home with you to read in the evening. And psychologically I am less inclined to start a 900-page manuscript.

"But if someone sends in a covering letter and a sample chapter of 10 pages I would have time to pick it up and read it in the 10 minutes before going into a meeting. It is much better to leave someone wanting more," says Ms Griffiths. She adds that letters should be addressed to specific agents - there are 13 at Curtis Brown - and not just the agency. The receptionist at an agency will advise authors which agent specialises in their genre.

And agents have their own reputations with publishers to consider. If they push a novel which will not sell the pubisher will be less likely to trust their judgment. Agents are listed in The Writers and Artists Yearbook.

If the work is accepted, advances vary wildly, but will usually be between £5,000 and £50,000. Royalties are traditionally 10% for a hardback and 7.5% for paperback - only if the work brings in more money than the advance - but this is changing as publishers face rising marketing costs.

Not all writers employ an agent, who will typically take between 10-15% of any of the (usually) painfully small amount earned. Ms Rosario says: "In some ways it gives you more freedom not to have an agent. If you have a very specific genre of writing then it may be better for you to research which publishers would be likely to be interested in that kind of fiction and write to them directly."

Agents will, however, deal with foreign rights and possible film deals, and have a kind of collective bargaining power with publishers which an individual author will obviously not have. There have been some attempts to subvert the traditional power structure in book publishing to give more power to the writer.

The Harry Potter series, famously, introduced the mass print-run for hardbacks. Citron Press, a collective founded in 1998 in an attempt to break the stranglehold of established publishers, took manuscripts which other mainstream publishers had rejected, published them in cheap editions and promoted them through its own book club, the internet and shops.

It reversed the old idea of the advance; the author stumped up £400 when his or her manuscript was accepted to help cover costs. But in spite of support from well-known authors such as Sheridan Morley and John Mortimer, Citron Press went out of business last month for the simple reason that it could not sell enough copies.

There are some internet publishing sites where writers can post samples of their work for the interest of publishers and agents. But this is in its early stages in the UK and Ms Griffiths says: "Although I think it is a great idea, at the moment I just don't have time to log on to the net to look at sample chapters when I am already inundated with paper submissions. Also it would not be cost-effective for us to download all work which authors want to be considered."

Getting poetry published does not involve the same hard slog - publishers keep a close eye on poetry magazines and competition winners tend to commission proactively rather than as a result of badgering - but nor does it involve much money. Christina Patterson, director of the Poetry Society, says that advances amount to no more than a few hundred pounds. Competitions are more lucrative, however.

The Society's own National Poetry Competition, entry for which closes on October 31, has a top prize of £5,000. As with most competitions, however, poets must pay to enter: Milton Keynes poet Kate Hunter says she would only bother to enter if she knew she was going to win. She has concentrated, instead, on getting published in specialist magazines, which include the Poetry Review and Ambit. Otherwise residencies and teaching opportunities pay reasonable rates, although work may be sporadic. For a six-month placement in a school or prison, the Poetry Society pays £5,000 for a two-day week, only one of which must be spent at the institution - the other may be dedicated to writing.

Although writing cannot really be learned, writing courses are useful. As Ms Rosario points out, you would expect a professional artist to have attended art college. Ms Griffiths says that courses, such as the MA in creative writing at the University of East Anglia, which has been taught in the past by literary luminaries such as Angela Carter, provide a filter - the assumption is that if you have been accepted on the course you must have some talent - and exposure to great mentors.

Non-fiction publishing can sometimes be more lucrative. The biggest advance in literary history went to Jack Welch, CEO of General Electric in the United States, for his autobiography. He was paid more than $7m upfront, and although this was an exception, if you write the college textbook for a branch of chemistry or accountancy and it makes it in the States you can expect rewards in the tens or even hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Mark Hammond, senior publishing editor at scientific, technical and medical publishers John Wiley, says that he will identify a gap in the market and approach a potential author himself, generally an academic or business person; rarely is it the other way round. Advances in non-fiction publishing are almost unknown and writers do it for the prestige and not the money.

But then, one of the most positive elements to being a writer is that all experiences are valid. Not being sucessful in commercial terms gives you the breathing space to create your own narrative voice. "In some ways it would be wonderful to have been published and paid a big advance, but in other ways that puts a lot of pressure on you to come up with the goods on time. Not having the confidence of being published has allowed me to develop a self-confidence in what I write which is not subject to the vagaries of editor or agent," says Ms Rosario.

 The Poetry Society: 020-7420-989 5

Tax and the writer

If you regularly write or gather material to write, you are classed and taxed as a professional. If you receive the odd payment for, say, isolated articles, this is considered an occasional activity. The onus is on you to decide which applies. If you get it wrong the price can be high in penalties and interest.

Your income includes fees, advances, royalties, commissions, sales of copyright. If your agent is taking in paid fees and advances on your behalf, the money is counted as yours, for tax purposes, from the day they receive it.

Writers can claim the following expenses: help with research, typing and proof-reading; costs for phone, fax and internet; books and magazines, rent, council tax, heating, lighting, cleaning and your agent's commission. You must keep detailed records of all expenditure on the above rather than just making rough estimates on your tax return.

 Information from the Writer's Handbook

webTitle: When For Sale boards aren't nearly enough

fields.headline: When For Sale boards aren't nearly enough
fields.standfirst: As the housing market cools agents and developers are resorting to shock tactics. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: As the housing market cools agents and developers are resorting to shock tactics. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.body:
When demand for property is high even sane people can be overcome by feelings of panic at the thought of not being able to secure their desired home. The most lacklustre properties will sell quickly; estate agents hardly need to lift a finger.

But when the froth has come off the market, agents and developers need to work harder to attract the attention of potential buyers.

This week a group of house hunters boarded a helicopter to be flown over the countryside around Beaconsfield in Buckinghamshire and gaze down on the site of a future development by Nicholas King homes.

Managing director Nicholas King says the company is targeting a specific group for an eight-home development called Curvare. "We are selling houses to people who are expecting to pay between £1m and £1.6m. These are likely to be highly successful individuals working for themselves or in companies. What they haven't got is time," Mr King explains.

"We thought the sensible thing would be to bring them to see the site in a helicopter - something people still find exciting. We see our eight houses as special and exclusive and wanted to treat people in such a way as to say we really value you and your custom."

Of course, the houses aren't there yet. The show home will be completed in January, so the ride was to whet buyers' appetites. The developer has only offered helicopter flights to people interested in the luxury home end of the market who were already registered with the two estate agents employed to market the properties.

Accountant Meyrick Vevers was among those who flew from Battersea to Curvare. He says the ride was more than just a bit of fun. "When you are on a building site it's quite hard to imagine what the development will look like when it's finished. Seeing the site from the air puts it in context."

When it came to launching a new-build apartment block into a lukewarm market, developer Saxon Homes opted for shock tactics. Estate agents FPD Savills joined forces with ad company ADC Blueprint and dreamed up a campaign that took property advertising in a whole new direction. Such was the impact of the series of ads for the Artilleries apartments in Westminster (pictured below) that one was even banned - of which more later.

"The first phase of the development, Artillery mansions, was on the market for some time. We thought a different image was needed for the next phase of one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments," says Edward Lewis of FPD Savills in Sloane Street.

However, like the Curvare development, completion was a long way off - in this case two years away. "One of the problems agents have is how to get across a product that hasn't been built. If you are selling off plan you have to work a little bit harder."

These days developers sell much more than bricks and mortar. Show homes are dressed up to the nines and house-hunters are invited to sign up for a lifestyle along with their en-suite and shiny cooker. And when it comes to lifestyles, who wouldn't want to be associated with the glamorous world of the supermodels - so Jodie Kidd and an LA-based fashion photographer were signed up to promote the Artilleries apartments.

"The development is priced realistically (from £245,000 to £1,450,000) and in a good location. It had a lot going for it we just needed to bring it to people's attention," says Peter Morley, managing director of the advertising firm. "We took eight or nine different sales points about the development and decided upon a radical photograph to go with each one," he adds.

The result - Ms Kidd clutching a saddle and bridle looming over a man on all fours - is accompanied by the caption, "great transport" and for stunning balconies the supermodel is showing off her cleavage. Not everyone was amused by the risque images. When the company tried to place an ad in the brochure for the Wimbledon tennis championships, the cautious people at the All England club declined in case the Duchess of Kent was embarrassed.

Estate agents Hamptons takes a more subtle approach to targeting potential clients - through catching them at play. The company sponsors equestrian events and staff are often to be found assembling a stand showing all the homes with stables the agents have on the market.

New approaches to selling property may be catching the public's eye or winning ad agencies awards (the Jodie Kidd campaign is in the running for a property award) but when it comes to payback time, does expensive marketing result in sales?

Mr Vevers says the helicopter ride made him and his wife take seriously a site they would otherwise have overlooked. For Artilleries, the ads have been a great success, says Mr Lewis. "We sold 81 units since the launch on June 8th. The campaign has delivered buyers in what the press says is a weak market place."

When the market is quiet buyers become increasingly discerning, says Mr Morley. But however good a job the ad men and women do, the product has to come up to the mark in the first place.

webTitle: Jobs and money : spending it: GPS

fields.headline: Know where you are at the touch of a key
fields.standfirst: The A to Z may soon be a thing of the past, replaced by satellite-linked Global Positioning Systems. Richard Nelsson reports
fields.trailText: The A to Z may soon be a thing of the past, replaced by satellite-linked Global Positioning Systems. Richard Nelsson reports
fields.body:
For centuries a map, compass and knowledge of the stars have been the tried and tested way to navigate.

But now hand-held receivers that pick up signals from a constellation of satellites are becoming increasingly popular with walkers, sailors and even car drivers lost in big cities.

The press of a button on a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver will tell you exactly where you are and how to get to your destination. GPS receivers, developed by the US military, listen to the signals transmitted from 24 orbiting satellites to calculate exactly where the holder is anywhere on the globe.

Naturally, the US military has kept its technology away from public use and, until recently, deliberately tampered with signals to civilian GPS units to keep their accuracy to no more than 100 metres. But in May this year they relented and President Clinton authorised the availability of GPS systems accurate to within just a few metres.

Most receivers will calculate the longitude, latitude and altitude for a user. Co-ordinates of your destination can be entered and the GPS will instantly calculate the distance and direction to be taken. The system works best in featureless terrain such as deserts and oceans . Remember, though, that GPS is dependent on the skill of the user. It would be foolhardy to rely on a receiver even with an accuracy of 10 metres while walking along a narrow mountain ridge and there are navigational "black holes" such as ravines where it is of no use at all.

Mike Rosser, executive secretary of the UK Mountain Training Board, which trains mountaineers, said: "Without a map and compass skills, a GPS is no good in the mountains. It gives a position but unless you know how to read a map in the first place and can interpret which way to walk in, it is of limited use. They can be useful but they're just one of a number of tools required for accurate navigation."

But it's a tool that many feel they cannot leave the house without. Not only are new stylish designs coming on to the market but there has been a dramatic fall in cost, with the price for a lightweight but reliable model starting at £130.

Magellan introduced the first hand-held GPS receiver in 1988 and produces a range to suit most activities. The recently launched GPS 315 (£170) has a built-in database of more than 15,000 cities, so it is intended to appeal to the urban navigator as well as the outdoor enthusiast. It will save up to 20 pre-planned routes (co-ordinates are entered before setting off) and there is storage for 500 "waypoints", where locations are given a name and symbol for easy identification while en route. It also has a high-resolution graphic display with nine navigation screens and two levels of brightness.

A similar but more affordable version is the GPS 310 (£135). While it has 20 continuous hours of battery use, five more than the 315, the unit can only store one route in its memory.

Another popular make is Garmin, who produce the eTrex (£136), the world's smallest and lightest handheld GPS. This is a stylish unit that has an in-built antenna and so is easier to fit into a pocket, with buttons on the side to allow more room for the front display. It is operated from simple menus. Like most GPS units, a car cigarette lighter adapter (£24) is available to save on the batteries. A more advanced model is the eTrex summit (£225) which also has a barometric altimeter and electronic compass.

A number of GPS receivers have features for marine navigation. The Lowrance Global 100 (£250) allows you to download marine charts from a PC and is waterproof. It is also incredibly versatile, with the capacity to store up to 99 routes.

A recent innovation comes from marine navigation firm Yeoman with its portable chart plotter. The Yeoman Sport (£410) is a hand-held mouse that can be moved around a paper chart even if balanced on the knee. It links to most models of GPS and senses your position as you move it over the chart. Indicator lights go out when you are at your location. It is claimed that this waterproof and unbreakable tool can be used by any crew member.

Of course for many, the most pressing navigational problem is how to get around an unfamiliar city. Most manufacturers produce dedicated GPS units for the urban landscape. Garmin's eMap (£245) is a hand-held moving map that shows detailed maps of cities and major roads as well as the facility to download addresses, while its StreetPilot (£623) is designed to fit on a car dashboard and will show you the way to any address that is entered.

Despite GPS units decreasing in size and weight over the past few years, the majority are still in a mobile phone format. Last year, though, Casio produced the Pro Trek Satellite Navi (£349), reputedly the world's first wristwatch carrying GPS navigational capabilities. A second generation version has just been launched which, unlike the original, can track 12 rather than eight satelllites and is water-resistant to 50 metres.

While perhaps a bit on the expensive side for its capabilities, this will appeal to those who have got to have the latest outdoor equipment as well as tapping into the current trend for sturdy multi-function watches.

Smaller GPS units are the way forward and, in a few years' time, satellite navigation will be incorporated as a matter of course into our mobile phones and palm-tops.

webTitle: Poll defeat leaves Trimble in crisis

fields.headline: Poll defeat leaves Trimble in crisis
fields.standfirst:
Unionist leader faces challenge after Paisley party triumph

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A wounded David Trimble was facing yet another challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists after the hardliner Willie McCrea early yesterday snatched the South Antrim constituency for the Democratic Unionist party in a critical byelection, delivering a devastating blow to the fragile Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
A wounded David Trimble was facing yet another challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists after the hardliner Willie McCrea early yesterday snatched the South Antrim constituency for the Democratic Unionist party in a critical byelection, delivering a devastating blow to the fragile Northern Ireland peace process.

Mr McCrea, 52, who had turned the bitter campaign in what was the second safest Ulster Unionist seat into a mini-referendum on the Good Friday agreement, overturned a 16,611 majority to squeeze home over David Burnside, the Ulster Unionist candidate, by 822 votes. He was jubilant, claiming it proved that Protestant opinion was now overwhelmingly against the accord, 30 months old.

The result sparked panic within the Ulster Unionists, long riven with divisions. Mr Burnside, 48, director of communications at British Airways during the dirty tricks war with Virgin, had tried to paper them over, but succeeded only in delivering a confused message.

The DUP did not bother to contest South Antrim in May 1997, when Clifford Forsythe held it for the Ulster Unionist party. But it had decided to contest the seat next time, even before Mr Forsythe, 65, who had a low profile at Westminster, died suddenly in April.

Mr McCrea, a preacher and highly successful gospel singer, was parachuted in from the neighbouring Mid-Ulster constituency. He was MP there when Martin McGuinness of Sinn Fein defeated him three years ago, and also represents Mid-Ulster in the assembly.

As Mr Trimble, the first minister, agreed with Mr Burnside in blaming the government's handling of policing reform, the dominant issue on the doorsteps, he vowed that there was no question of him resigning. He said: "We have had a setback but we are not quitters."

But Jeffrey Donaldson, the anti-agreement Ulster Unionist MP, immediately called for the party to pull out of the power-sharing executive at Stormont. He is seen as a future leader, particularly after Mr Burnside's failure.

Mr Donaldson said: "If the Unionist party doesn't get a message from South Antrim that it's time to draw a line then they will never listen to the people. We cannot sustain a position when we're sitting in government with Martin McGuinness and others who are linked to an organisation that refuses to decommission its weapons and is setting about removing our British identity in Northern Ireland."

That sparked an angry reaction from his fellow MP Ken Maginnis, a staunch supporter of the accord. He called Mr Donaldson's remarks irresponsible and utter nonsnese, so underscoring party divisions.

Martin Smyth, the veteran MP who polled 43% of delegates to the Ulster Unionist council when he challenged Mr Trimble for leadership of the party six months ago, was considering another attempt. He was taking a "pause for reflection" before deciding, but argued that Mr Trimble was out of step with opinion within his party.

Ian Paisley, leader of the DUP, was jubilant as his party again confounded critics who have written it off. He said: "The writing is on the wall for Trimble now. He must go and go quickly. I think he is finished, absolutely finished."

Mr McCrea, who officiated at the loyalist leader Billy Wright's funeral in December 1997, said: "The vast majority of the unionist population have made a judgment, a judgment upon the Belfast agreement - that iniquitous agreement that has been the destruction of democracy in our country."

The Northern Ireland Office was attempting to put as positive a spin on the result as possible. Sources close to Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, pointed out that votes for anti-agreement Unionists outweighed those for Unionist candidates backing the deal at the assembly elections in South Antrim in June 1998.

They also said Mr Burnside, although a supporter of the agreement at the referendum two years ago, was now in the anti-camp, disillusioned with RUC reform and the IRA's failure to begin decommissioning its weapons

One said: "Who was a pro-agreement unionist to vote for?" - although party insiders suspect that a strong supporter of the deal would have fared even worse.
