fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Ryanair upbeat on growth
fields.body:
Ryanair upbeat on growth

Irish budget airline Ryanair expects traffic growth in its second quarter to be 30% ahead of the same period last year. The upbeat prediction is due to the success of its 10 new routes this summer and to the continuing growth of its booking website Ryanair.com, the company said in its annual statement to shareholders.

Ryanair plans to buy three Boeing 737-800 next generation aircraft for delivery in 2002, bringing the total of 737 deliveries in that year to eight. The additional aircraft would enable it to maintain its 25% rate of growth in traffic, the country said.

Telco hit by free net access

Telecoms business Callnet has appointed BDO Stoy Hayward as its administrators after being hit by mounting debts on its unmetered internet access service. The administrators are now working to ensure the future survival of the business. BDO Stoy Hayward is continuing to run the business with the intention of selling Callnet as a going concern.

Callnet's unmetered internet access service has 100,000 users and its pay by the minute service has 210,000. BDO Stoy Hayward said it expects to see an end to the uncertainties facing Callnet shortly.

Irish aircraft leasing sale

Ireland's AerFi is in line to be taken over by German group Debis Systemhaus in a $750m (£513.45m) cash deal to create the world's third largest aircraft leasing company.

The deal is subject to approval of the competition regulators and AerFi Group shareholders. Deutsche Telekom has a 50.1% stake in Debis, with the remaining stake owned by DaimlerChrysler

Canary Wharf minus Enron

Property company Canary Wharf announced yesterday that US energy corporation Enron is not immediately proceeding with plans to take 30,000 sq m of office space at the Docklands development. Enron said the move did not mean it planned to cut any of its 1,900 staff in London.

But Canary Wharf has agreed outline terms with US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to lease out more than 46,000 square metres of office space. The bank already has an office in the area.

Thames Water wins Chile deal

Thames Water, facing a £4bn takeover bid thought to be from Germany's RWE, yesterday announced a $282.3m (£193m) contract in Chile.

The firm won an auction for the privatisation of 42% of Chile's third largest water utility, Essbio, which supplies drinking water to 350,000 clients in the Bio Bio region, located 520 kilometres south of the capital, Santiago.

Dealers believe a formal bid from RWE could come as soon as Monday.

webTitle: Surf's up on phoney reef for beach boys (and girls)

fields.headline: Surf's up on phoney reef for beach boys (and girls)
fields.trailText: The surfers of California are making waves - literally. They are also, in constructing the first artificial surf reef on the continent, stirring controversy during what is seen as a renaissance in surfing.
fields.body:
The surfers of California are making waves - literally. They are also, in constructing the first artificial surf reef on the continent, stirring controversy during what is seen as a renaissance in surfing.

Work began this week on the creation of a manmade surf reef at El Segundo, near Los Angeles airport on the Pacific coast. The aim is to recreate a surfing spot that was lost when Chevron oil built a jetty in 1984 to protect the pipeline from its rigs to its refinery. The breakwater effectively wiped out the waves in the area.

"We recognise quite humbly that we are not going to do as good a job as nature," said Christopher Evans of the Surfrider Foundation which represents the interests of surfers and those concerned with the coast of the United States and is overseeing the operation.

Chevron has agreed to pay around $300,000 (£210,000) for the construction of what will be known as Pratte's Reef. Work should be completed by the end of next week.

The project has raised a debate among surfers as to whether man should interfere with nature to such an extent. Some traditionalists say that part of the joy of surfing is its natural, unpredictable nature and building a reef runs counter to that.

But Mr Evans believes that the foundation is doing the right thing. He likens the scheme to the reclaiming of wetlands as an environmentally healthy exercise in that what had once existed was being respectfully replaced.

The foundation will monitor the effect the construction has on natural marine habitats and if damage is being done it will remove the new reef.

Mr Evans said there were two artificial reefs in Australia, but such a construction had never been attempted before in the US which, with an estimated 2m participants, has the largest surfing community in the world.

The new reef is being built at a time of renewed enthusiasm for the sport, not least with the arrival of more women surfers, many of whom had complained in the past of being made to feel unwelcome in a very male environment.

"There is a renaissance for surfing," Mr Evans said, "and more women are joining every day." He said that women now made up around 30% of the Surfriders' membership of 26,000.

The internet has also changed the face of surfing. In the old days, surfers used their instincts and knowledge of the seas and weather to choose where to go and when.

Now it is possible to get a surf report on the internet which accounts for the pre-dawn arrival of the wet-suited surfing fraternity on some top beaches, like Rincon Point south of Santa Barbara and Malibu.

Surfline.com claims to have 375,000 users of its information on waves which is gathered from tidal information, buoy readings and satellite wave height maps.

Some free-spirited traditions are being maintained, however, including the surfing community's avoidance of the Olympic Games despite attempts to include the sport as an exhibition event in Sydney.

In the latest Surfer magazine, Gina Makin spells out good reasons for non-participation. "During the opening and closing ceremonies, all Olympic athletes must march and we all know that surfers should never - will never - march."

It was nearly 40 years ago that the Beach Boys and Surfin' USA introduced the rest of the world to the names of the legendary surfing beaches of California - from Manhattan Beach and Pacific Palisades up to the Ventura County Line.

Now perhaps they will have to re-record the song and start looking for something that rhymes with Pratte's Reef.

webTitle: A divided nation - in a family's flat

fields.headline: A divided nation - in a family's flat
fields.standfirst:
The divisions of a nation - on show in a family's flat

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: She sits, stout and sure of herself, hair rollers gently cooking in a canary yellow hood, at Snezana's Hair and Beauty Boutique in the basement of our apartment block. There,   Milosevic's women are preparing for the election tomorrow with a wash and set.
fields.body:
She sits, stout and sure of herself, hair rollers gently cooking in a canary yellow hood, at Snezana's Hair and Beauty Boutique in the basement of our apartment block. There, Milosevic's women are preparing for the election tomorrow with a wash and set.

Milena Pantic is 66 and she has always voted for Slobodan Milosevic. "Who would have saved us from the Nato bombs if he wasn't around?" she says. "He rebuilt the country. Who would have stopped America from turning us into a colony? I went to see him on Thursday night in Novi Belgrade and he was magnificent."

She sits back satisfied, nodding to the other women in the salon for approval.

At the sink is the wife of a former diplomat. She looks weary and doesn't want to talk about her voting intentions. In halting, impeccable English, she says: "Madame, this is a place for women, not politics. We have come here to make ourselves beautiful - to escape."

There is a lot of escaping going on in this apartment block.

A 41-year-old scientist called Mira and her husband, a banker, share a three-roomed flat with his parents and their 12-year-old daughter. After ten years of war and economic sanctions there is an acute housing shortage in Serbia.

She waves her reading material in the air. "I am a scientist. I went to university but I need to clean my brain with this crap." She passes her romantic literature along the coffee table, translating the titles of the love comics into unsure English: "Blue-eyed Sorceress and the Mistress of Love" and "She is Made for Love".

"I feel now before these elections just like I did when they were bombing us," she says.

"I am trembling. The opposition will win but that bastard will do anything he can to stop them. He has destroyed my life."

Meanwhile her mother-in-law, another ardent Milosevic fan, absorbs the warnings about "Nato plots" and how "fifth columnists" disguised as opposition leaders are trying to defeat her President Milosevic.

In the flat, which is only twice the size of a British living room, they live in two worlds: Mira and her husband in one room listening to the Voice of America radio and their parents in the next, watching Mr Milosevic's television station.

But Mira will not protest on the streets if and when the government rigs the election: "I am 41 years old - too old to be beaten up by the police".

The pre-election battle has been raging all week in this apartment block. The most recent poll predicts a win for the opposition candidate but Belgrade is convinced Slobodan Milosevic will not go quietly.

On Monday, opposition stickers that read: "He's finished" appeared on the lift doors on each of the 15 floors and above all the shop doors in the basement.

By yesterday they had been covered over with posters of the smiling president. Underneath was written "For Yugoslavia" in stern white letters.

For the last month, Belgrade's food shortages have eased, with the shops receiving oil and sugar twice a day. "That will stop after the election," says Mira.

At the back of the building, near the towers of the electricity plant, a retired dentist of 59 is rummaging through the "market" that the local people call "Bangladesh".

It's a place where the poorest of almost 1m Serbs driven from their homes during the Croatian and Bosnian wars survive by selling what they find in other people's bins.

Yesterday, a slow, steady autumn rain soaked mud into the sodden carpets that make up their stall tables. There a false leg was for sale with a brown plastic moccasin still laced onto the foot. There were second-hand toilet seats, and half-empty jars of moisturising cream for sale.

The dentist was looking for clothes for her relatives, also refugees. She is voting for the opposition and despite fears that next week could bring violent confrontation between the people and the police, she says: "I can't wait."

In the afternoon the Milosevic-supporting women who have come for their wash and set are replaced by the younger generation: working women who finish at three.

"I am frightened that he will choke us. He will crush us", says a 40-year-old mother of two. "I will be on the streets on Sunday night. He has stolen ten years of my life".

But mostly the women are trying to ignore the election; escaping into Snezana's warm salon with its tinted coffee-coloured glass.

There they chain-smoke and wait their turn. They favour the henna hair colour of eastern Europe of the early 80s - even their hair colours are trapped in a time warp.

They will go out and vote on Sunday but nobody is confident there will be change.

Those that aren't standing by their man, President Slobodan Milosevic, are pretending this election is not happening - or they are trembling.

fields.headline: Kray 's freedom in £37 hotel room
fields.trailText: Reggie Kray, the once notorious East End gangster, tasted his first real day of freedom yesterday after 32 years in prison.
fields.body:
Reggie Kray, the once notorious East End gangster, tasted his first real day of freedom yesterday after 32 years in prison.

Kray, 66, who has inoperable cancer of the bladder, left Norwich and Norfolk general hospital by a back entrance yesterday morning with his wife, Roberta, who he married three years ago. His solicitor, Mark Goldstein, said his illness had stabilised, but it is expected to take his life in weeks rather than months.

"I would hope that the press and media for the next two or three days will give him some breathing space," Mr Goldstein said.

Kray was freed from prison on August 26 by Jack Straw, the home secretary, on compassionate grounds, in view of his deteriorating health.

After leaving hospital yesterday, he was driven to the Town House hotel in Norwich, where he was said to be resting in a £37.50 a night en-suite room. Visitors to the hotel were greeted by a number of burly men in dark suits.

One man, who gave his name only as John, said he handled security for Kray and added that it was hoped that Kray and his wife would stay at the hotel for several weeks.

John said Kray was celebrating his freedom with champagne and might speak to reporters next week. "Mr Kray is poorly. He's very tired. He doesn't want a media circus. He has made his funeral arrangements. He knows he is dying.

"We are hoping that without any pressure, this will give him longer to live. This is freedom for him. If he is strong enough we are hoping friends will come to see him."

On July 28 Kray was transferred from his cell in Norwich prison to the prison's healthcare wing. He had exploratory surgery on August 4 and was transferred to the Norwich and Norfolk on August 17.

Kray stabbed Jack "the Hat" McVitie to death in a flat in Stoke Newington, north London. He was convicted of murder at the Old Bailey in 1969 and sentenced to life imprisonment with a recommendation that he serve not less than 30 years.

His twin brother Ronnie, who was jailed for life for the murder of George Cornell in the Blind Beggar pub in the Mile End Road, died of a heart attack in 1995.

Their elder brother Charlie died aged 73, while in Parkhurst prison for drug offences.

fields.headline: Ministers break ranks on dome
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Downing Street faced fresh embarrassment over the Millennium Dome yesterday when two cabinet ministers registered their opposition to the Greenwich attraction, prompting accusations from the Tories that the government was playing the blame game.
fields.body:
Downing Street faced fresh embarrassment over the Millennium Dome yesterday when two cabinet ministers registered their opposition to the Greenwich attraction, prompting accusations from the Tories that the government was playing the blame game.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, reopened the controversy on Thursday night when she dismissed the dome as a "disaster" and a "flop".

Her cabinet colleague, the culture secretary Chris Smith, was put on the Today programme yesterday to calm the row. But he also raised doubts about the dome, saying that he had opposed it all along.

Mr Smith said: "It is very much on the record - indeed there is a book written about this - that when the decision to go ahead with it was made in June 1997, I argued for something rather smaller and rather more wholly focused on educational work."

The culture secretary made a half-hearted attempt to offer some support to the beleaguered dome minister, Lord Falconer, by saying Ms Short was wrong to describe the dome as a flop. "People who are dead set against it tend to be those who have not been."

Ms Short broke the convention of cabinet collective responsibility when she said that the government should shut the dome as soon as possible.

Speaking on the BBC's Question Time, she said: "It has been a flop. It was started by [Michael] Heseltine, it was taken on by our government, most people who haven't been think it is awful, it keeps losing money, we need to dispose of it as rapidly as we can, as cheaply as we can. At least the land in Greenwich was cleaned up."

Ms Short, who admitted her son had enjoyed the dome, said she regretted it had ever been built. "The thing is a disaster," she said.

"I regret that it happened but there it is. Thankfully, very soon it will be put out of its misery."

She winced as she said it was unfair to blame Lord Falconer for the fiasco, demonstrating the dwindling level of support for the dome minister.

Downing Street attempted to play down Ms Short's remarks, which were the latest "off message" remark from the international development secretary, who appears to have a licence to speak her mind.

"Clare has expressed her own, long-held views," a spokesman said.

"The dome is the most popular paying visitor attraction in the country. As Clare herself pointed out, those who go there like it."

Lord Falconer yesterday shrugged off Ms Short's criticsim of the dome and insisted that he would not resign. "I think it was widely known that was her view," he said.

"It was a view which had been expressed before, but it does not in any way detract from the fact that the government decided to go ahead with the dome and we are continuing to support it. The right course for me is to stay with the job to ensure an orderly conclusion is reached to the dome project."

But the Tories insisted that Lord Falconer should resign, as they seized on the criticisms from Ms Short and Mr Smith. Peter Ainsworth, shadow culture secretary, said: "Members of the cabinet are now playing the blame game. Clare Short has laid the blame for the dome fiasco at the feet of Peter Mandelson and Tony Blair.

"The government is in disarray. There is no room in Lord Falconer's political coffin for any more nails, but Clare Short seems to have thrown the first handful of dirt."

webTitle: Do come in, but it's rather a crowd

fields.headline: Do come in, but it's rather a crowd
fields.standfirst:
Architect ready for 1,000 guests as Open House scheme spreads

Architecture Week 2000
fields.trailText: When guests come round, the usual thing is to offer them a cup of tea and invite them to relax on your sofa.
fields.body:
When guests come round, the usual thing is to offer them a cup of tea and invite them to relax on your sofa.

But with more than 1,000 people arriving at architect Peter St John's Islington home tomorrow, the social niceties will have to be ditched.

The masses will descend on Mr St John as part of London Open House, when a vast and fascinating range of the capital's finest buildings throw their doors open to the public.

The annual celebration of architecture features both grand public offices and headquarters such as the Foreign Office and the Channel 4 building, and an extensive contingent of private homes such as Mr St John's.

The architect, of Caruso St John, designers of the Walsall Art Gallery, first invited the public to come and admire his decor two years ago.

"It is a kind of mad and slightly narcissistic thing to do," he admitted. "Deep down all architects have a deep need for people to look at and be interested in their work."

While he hoped it would encourage public appreciation of the "built environment", Mr St John conceded that it also appealed to "a natural fascination with what other people's houses are like".

With 40 people coming in every 15 minutes, it was exhausting but also a lot of fun, especially for his children who did a roaring trade selling biscuits.

As there is little of value to steal, he was not overly concerned about potential burglars. "We have a few friends standing around trying to make sure nothing disappears, but people were generally very well behaved."

Several other architects, including Nicholas Burwell, David Russell, Marcus Lee, and Tom Pike, are also opening up their homes.

Among the public buildings making their debut this year are the University of London's Senate House, the Royal Institute of International Affairs, popularly known as Chatham House, and Macks Mews, a 19th century paper factory converted for housing.

Many of the 550 buildings involved are normally closed to the public, or have very restricted public access.

For the Open House weekend, now in its eighth year, the buildings' owners allow visitors in free of charge.

In 1999, more than 450 buildings were open to the public and 320,000 visits were made over the 48-hour period. This year more than 500,000 are expected to take up the opportunity.

Some of the best-loved attractions include Imagination, originally an Edwardian school and now headquarters for a design and communications company in Bloomsbury; and Marlborough House, designed by Sir Christopher Wren and originally home to the dukes of Marlborough.

London Open House, which is sponsored by the Guardian, follows the Heritage Open Days last weekend when over 2,500 heritage sites across the country opened their doors to the public.

Mr St John's home, 11 Orleston Mews, N7, is open to the public on Sunday only, from 10am to 4pm. For details of other locations and times check the London Open House website at www.londonopenhouse.org.

But with more than 1,000 people arriving at architect Peter St John's Islington home tomorrow, the social niceties will have to be ditched. The masses will descend on Mr St John as part of London Open House, when a vast and fascinating range of the capital's finest buildings throw their doors open to the public. The annual celebration of architecture features both grand public offices and headquarters such as the Foreign Office and the Channel 4 building, and an extensive contingent of private homes such as Mr St John's. The architect, of Caruso St John, designers of the Walsall Art Gallery, first invited the public to come and admire his decor two years ago. "It is a kind of mad and slightly narcissistic thing to do," he admitted. "Deep down all architects have a deep need for people to look at and be interested in their work." While he hoped it would encourage public appreciation of the "built environment", Mr St John conceded that it also appealed to "a natural fascination with what other people's houses are like". With 40 people coming in every 15 minutes, it was exhausting but also a lot of fun, especially for his children who did a roaring trade selling biscuits. As there is little of value to steal, he was not overly concerned about potential burglars. "We have a few friends standing around trying to make sure nothing disappears, but people were generally very well behaved." Several other architects, including Nicholas Burwell, David Russell, Marcus Lee, and Tom Pike, are also opening up their homes. Among the public buildings making their debut this year are the University of London's Senate House, the Royal Institute of International Affairs, popularly known as Chatham House, and Macks Mews, a 19th century paper factory converted for housing. Many of the 550 buildings involved are normally closed to the public, or have very restricted public access. For the Open House weekend, now in its eighth year, the buildings' owners allow visitors in free of charge. In 1999, more than 450 buildings were open to the public and 320,000 visits were made over the 48-hour period. This year more than 500,000 are expected to take up the opportunity. Some of the best-loved attractions include Imagination, originally an Edwardian school and now headquarters for a design and communications company in Bloomsbury; and Marlborough House, designed by Sir Christopher Wren and originally home to the dukes of Marlborough. London Open House, which is sponsored by the Guardian, follows the Heritage Open Days last weekend when over 2,500 heritage sites across the country opened their doors to the public. webTitle: Shops war stirs storm in a D-cup

fields.headline: Shops war stirs storm in a D-cup
fields.trailText: Hundreds of generously-built Yorkshire women are in revolt against an upmarket shopping centre's reluctance to lease a prime site to a shop specialising in larger bras.
fields.body:
Hundreds of generously-built Yorkshire women are in revolt against an upmarket shopping centre's reluctance to lease a prime site to a shop specialising in larger bras.

Protest letters are flooding into the company from owners of size D to J cups, whose hopes of a local store face frustration by the landlord's preference for different cups; capuccino and espresso.

The row is risking the first venture outside London of a business which has tapped an unexpectedly large market ignored by conventional lingerie stores. It also centres on one of Britain's most successful shopping developments, the Victoria Quarter in Leeds, whose 19th century arcades first tempted Harvey Nichols and other prestigious names north

"We chose the Victoria Quarter after looking all over the country for our first shop outside London," said Sarah Tremellen, 34, who unlocked a long-frustrated market when pregnancy sent her two cup sizes up to 36E and a good range of bras was impossible to find. Her company, Bravissimo, has grown in five years from a mail order hobby based in her front room to an annual turnover of £4m.

"We like Leeds and we would fit comfortably into the Quarter," said Mrs Tremellen, whose customers are predominantly from the ABC1 social range. "We found a sports shop with four years left on a 15-year lease whose owners accepted our offer. Then we ran into a brick wall."

This was the Prudential, the Quarter's developer and landlord, which is applying for planning permission to turn the shop into a cafe. A spokesman denied opposition to a bra outlet in principle and said the decision to look for a catering outlet had been made before Bravissimo's interest.

But Leeds's ampler ladies have responded eagerly to a Bravissimo appeal sent to 900 local mail order clients. One emailed: "Perhaps we are in the realm of schoolboy giggles here. If so, I can assure everyone that Bravissimo sells its clothes in a straightforward and wholly tasteful way."

fields.headline: Friends deserting Mandela's heir
fields.standfirst: The fire ignited by President Mbeki's dismissive views on Aids is spreading. Even his South African business allies are edging away
fields.trailText: Little more than a year into his term as president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki is facing a crisis of public confidence few would have predicted when he won a landslide election victory.
fields.body:
Little more than a year into his term as president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki is facing a crisis of public confidence few would have predicted when he won a landslide election victory.

A rising tide of attacks from close allies have focused on Mr Mbeki's controversial questioning of the link between HIV and Aids, but this criticism reflects wider concerns about the president's market-oriented economic policies, his handling of the Zimbabwe crisis and what some see as his authoritarian tendencies.

Until recently, Mr Mbeki had to contend with little more than berating from the official opposition, the Democratic Alliance, a party mostly supported by whites and other minorities. Its attacks had little impact among the black majority. The ANC's allies rarely questioned the president, even if they had fundamental disagreements, for fear of being seen as disloyal to the liberation and black empowerment cause.

But in recent days, unparalleled criticism from friends - the unions, Desmond Tutu's successor as Anglican archbishop and figures in Mr Mbeki's own party, the African National Congress - has proved far more damaging to the president than anything the opposition could throw at him.

This week, South Africa's trade union confederation - a key ANC partner - said it had no doubt that HIV caused Aids and called on the government to stop speculating and to save lives by providing treatments. It then went on to give voice to other previously stifled criticisms including a long simmering belief that the government is in the pocket of big business.

On Wednesday, the Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, Njongonkulu Ndungane, described the government's Aids policy, including its refusal to supply drugs because their worthwas "unproven", as a crime against humanity comparable to South Africa's former white supremacist system

"We believe that history will measure this country's slow response to the pandemic in human, not statistical, terms and that the inherent injustices will be judged as serious a crime against humanity as apartheid," he said in a statement.

"What is becoming increasingly clear is the futility of looking to government for a solution. At the very least we need to apply pressure on our political leaders to change this situation."

But while the attack focused on Aids, some church leaders privately say they have long been disturbed by what they see as the government's lack of concern for the broad mass of poor black people. Mr Mbeki tried to portray established Aids theory as part of a conspiracy by foreign scientists and western drug companies to make the developing world pay for "worthless" treatments.

It has backfired because those worst hit by the pandemic, black people, are paying the price. The South African human rights commission, a statutory body, said this week it was considering taking legal action to force the government to supply drugs to HIV carriers.

Public opinion is also turning against the president. Nurses and doctors, many from poor rural areas, can regularly be heard on radio phone-ins denouncing the damage done by Mr Mbeki's stance to their efforts to persuade people to practise safe sex.

Even business, which has been so well served by Mr Mbeki's government, is becoming unnerved. Business leaders are unwilling to involve themselves publicly in the dispute, but privately one foreign banker said that Mr Mbeki had seriously undermined investor confidence because his position on Aids has been taken as a sign that he is not the stable technocrat many believed him to be.

Whilst there are no clear parallels between the conduct of South Africa's leader and his counterpart next door in Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, investors who see both as mavericks do not necessarily draw the distinctions.

President Mbeki tried to recover ground during a question time in parliament earlier this week but his responses drew further derision as he again resorted to verbal gymnastics to avoid directly saying HIV was the cause of Aids.

"Aids is acquired immune deficiency syndrome. I don't believe it's a sensible thing to ask: 'Does a virus cause a syndrome?' It can't. A virus will cause a disease," he said.

Public anger over the issue is not directed at the ANC but at Mr Mbeki. Indeed, much of the criticism of him comes from within the party, and so does the potential threat to his power. In August, a confidential national intelligence service report alleged that the party's former general secretary, Cyril Ramaphosa, was in a conspiracy with the US and Britain to replace Mr Mbeki.

Mr Ramaphosa - now a prominent businessman with interests in the media and manufacturing - denied the claim and said he had no intention of returning to politics. It is highly unlikely that if he were to do so, it would be at the behest of London or Washington. But for the first time in years Mr Ramaphosa is raising his public profile with newspaper interviews on issues such as black empowerment.

There are many in the ANC who would welcome his return to politics.

The peoples view

As a president, he has done a lot of damage. I challenge him to come to the Aids clinic or to visit the homes of these people - to see people dying in front of him like we do every day
Florence Ngobeni, Aids counsellor, Soweto

History will measure this country's slow response to the pandemic in human, not statistical, terms... the inherent injustices will be judged as serious a crime against humanity as apartheid
Anglican Archbishop Njongonkulu Ndungane

The link between HIV and Aids is irrefutable. Any other approach is unscientific and unfortunately likely to confuse people. It can undermine the message that all South Africans must take precautions to avoid infection
Willie Madisha, head of the trade union federation Cosatu

webTitle: Family sues drug firm over baby killing

fields.headline: Family sues drug firm over baby killing
fields.trailText: The family of a man who shot dead his baby daughter and tried to kill himself is suing a British drug company, alleging that an amphetamine-based drug given to him for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) caused him to become psychotic.
fields.body:
The family of a man who shot dead his baby daughter and tried to kill himself is suing a British drug company, alleging that an amphetamine-based drug given to him for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) caused him to become psychotic.

Ryan Ehlis, 26, from North Dakota, in the US, has been acquitted of the murder of his five-week-old daughter Tyra. The case was dismissed after psychiatrists for the prosecution and defence agreed that the prescription medicine he was taking for ADHD, Adderall, was responsible for the tragedy by inducing in him a temporary psychosis.

Yesterday his lawyers filed a civil suit in North Dakota against Shire Pharmaceuticals, based in Andover, Hampshire.

Adderall is the main rival to Ritalin in the US. Ritalin or methylphenidate, prescribed to more than 130,000 children with hyperactivity or attention deficit disorder in the UK, is a stimulant from the amphetamine family, while Adderall is a combination of four amphetamine salts.

Adderall had captured 28% of the US market by the end of last year and is one of Shire's biggest money-spinners, while Ritalin has a good safety record.

But there has been increasing anxiety in the UK about the burgeoning use of amphetamine drugs to treat children diagnosed as having ADHD. The National Institute of Clinical Excellence has been asked to look into the prescribing of Ritalin on the NHS.

In January last year, Mr Ehlis, who was diagnosed with ADHD as a child, went to see a psychiatrist after having difficulty with his college studies. The psychiatrist reconfirmed the ADHD diagnosis and gave him Adderall.

The Adderall he was given, the court papers claim, was twice as strong as the Ritalin he had taken as a child.

For a few days all was well, but then Mr Ehlis did as instructed by his psychiatrist and doubled the dose.

"He began to experience delusions and hallucinations... He felt 'wired', his pupils were dilated and his eyes were hurt by the light," according to the pleadings filed in North Dakota by the Texas law firm Vickery and Waldner.

Believing he had been instructed by God to send baby Tyra to heaven, Mr Ehlis shot his daughter with a 20-gauge shotgun and then turned the gun on himself. It was less than 10 days after he started the medication.

The judge at the murder trial agreed with the psychiatrists and the prosecutor that Mr Ehlis was no threat to anybody as long as he avoided amphetamines.

Andy Vickery, his lawyer, believes Adderall does not carry a sufficient warning.

"Shire knew that its drug could cause this kind of behaviour, and it is absolutely reprehensible that it failed to warn the public about it," he said.

A spokeswoman for Shire Pharmaceuticals said yesterday: "The safety profile for Adderall is extremely good. Out of 10m prescriptions to date, there have been only 14 incidents of psychosis and they were very mild. This is the only one that was serious.

"We are deeply saddened by the tragedy that took place, but we believe Adderall is safe."

Novartis, the maker of Ritalin, said its drug was a mild stimulant. "It has been used safely and effectively for more than 40 years with no association to violent behaviour. Some children, and probably some adults, with ADHD suffer from other conditions which may make their management more complex," it said in a statement.

fields.headline: A bit of lit crit
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... a literal misuse of the language
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... a literal misuse of the language
fields.body:
It is not a good idea to take too literally every word you read in the Guardian. One of the words that are not to be taken too literally is "literally", the use and abuse of which a reader drew to my attention this week. It did not take long to find examples that are, well, quite literally mind-boggling.

Just in the past two or three weeks we have told you that a search party was "literally heading for a cross on a map", that the world for one poor individual had "literally gone pear-shaped", and that "the pizza business in Britain is literally taking off". This last one was a reference to the Russian Proton rocket which made its journey to the International Space Station this summer with a Pizza Hut logo on its side. Literally, a rocket took off with a logo on the side. Figuratively the pizza business took off too.

Most of the guides to good English have something to say about "literally". The Teach Yourself Concise Dictionary of Correct English, for example, reminds us of the rigour of the literal definition. "Literally means 'exactly in accordance with the meaning of the word(s)' to which 'literally' is attached."

The author of this book, BA Phythian, by way of illustration, says it is only acceptable to say that a thief was literally caught red-handed if he had red hands. Literally, Phythian says, is often wrongly used in this way, merely as a means of emphasis, with some ridiculous consequences, "The players literally ran out of steam."

Godfrey Howard, in The Macmillan Good English Handbook, takes a more relaxed view. He says, "If a knife is literally as sharp as a razor, it should be possible to shave with it. But literally is so often used to mean, not in reality but in a manner of speaking: 'dinner at that restaurant literally costs the earth'."

He adds, "This use of 'literally' is far too common to make a fuss about it, but we might prefer to be careful ourselves to use 'literally' only when we mean in reality." One of the things for the writer to consider, he suggests, is whether the word could be left out altogether.

The best piece of advice, I think, is that given in The New Fowler's Modern English usage, but we shall come to that in a moment. The reader who (literally) started this train of thought, enclosed two extracts from the autobiography of the author Compton Mackenzie, who revealed in a letter to the Evening Standard in about 1928, "An amusement of mine for many years has been collecting 'literallys'" (My Life and Times, Octave 6, 1923-30).

Sir Compton offered a few items from his collection, including one from the Evening Standard itself "when a distinguished Admiral was said to have literally won his spurs at the Battle of Jutland," and another, from a court report in which the accused was said to have "literally gone to pieces after his arrest".

He concluded his letter to the Standard, "As I write these words I hear on the Wireless from Mr PF Warner that WG Grace 'literally' killed the fast bowlers of the last century, which must have kept his brother EM, the coroner, fairly busy" (ah, my Warner and my Grace, long ago).

Mackenzie thought it was much too kind to the culprits to excuse them simply for mistaking "literally" with "figuratively". "Are they not looking for one of those wretched augmentatives which, like inflated tics, batten on the language?" - an augmentative in this sense being a word whose purpose is to emphasise or reinforce the word or phrase to which it is attached. So "literally" sacrifices its own true meaning to lend its weight to all manner of outrageous statements.

The results, as we have seen are often so amusing that it seems a bit churlish to complain. We do not want to be spoilsports, do we? We knew exactly what Bel Littlejohn, a famously forthright columnist, meant when she wrote in her own vivid way, "I went into Melvyn's office unannounced and found him... sitting beneath a literally shattering new piece by Damien Hirst."

The reader, who raised "literally", by the way, also suggested that it had been joined by "famously" as what he called "the wretched augmentative of 2000". He quoted from our recent rerun of the Lady Chatterley trial when the prosecution counsel "famously" asked the jury, "Is it a book you would wish your wife or servants to read?" On Monday this week we used "famously" in 10 separate pieces, certainly qualifying the word as a cliche.

Now, the final word on "literally" from the New Fowler, which after an example from the Guardian, 1995, "They [the supermarkets] can literally play God, even to the point of sending food back to the genetic drawing board for a redesign,"concludes its discussion with the following words of advice, "It's a case of 'stop, look and think' before using the word in any manner short of its exact sense."

Precisely. Do that and we shall get along famously.

 Many thanks to Rod Prince for suggesting the subject of this column. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897.
Email: reader@theguardian.com.

The reader, who raised "literally", by the way, also suggested that it had been joined by "famously" as what he called "the wretched augmentative of 2000". He quoted from our recent rerun of the Lady Chatterley trial when the prosecution counsel "famously" asked the jury, "Is it a book you would wish your wife or servants to read?" On Monday this week we used "famously" in 10 separate pieces, certainly qualifying the word as a cliche. Now, the final word on "literally" from the New Fowler, which after an example from the Guardian, 1995, "They [the supermarkets] can literally play God, even to the point of sending food back to the genetic drawing board for a redesign,"concludes its discussion with the following words of advice, "It's a case of 'stop, look and think' before using the word in any manner short of its exact sense." Precisely. Do that and we shall get along famously.  Many thanks to Rod Prince for suggesting the subject of this column. fields.headline: The last word on   Mathematics
fields.standfirst: "If a man's wit be wandering, let him study the mathematics." -   Lord Bacon
fields.trailText: "If a man's wit be wandering, let him study the mathematics." - Lord Bacon "If a man's wit be wandering, let him study the mathematics." - Lord Bacon
fields.body:
With the school term now fairly underway, the great endeavour to foster interest in mathematics among the young has been resumed. Some take to mathematics naturally, but most find it difficult. Because our age prefers soft options, fewer are studying it at higher levels, which is a problem, because our age is also one in which mathematics is central. Not only should more people be studying it to higher levels, but adults should be returning to the classroom to improve their skills in it.

You can take a utilitarian view of mathematics - as witness Mae West's handy definition of one its operations: "A man has $100 and you leave him with $2, that's subtraction", or you can take a metaphysical view of it, as Pythagoras did, and regard it as the secret of the universe. If contemporary science is to be believed, he might be right.

Science has been the chief engine of progress in modern efforts to understand the universe, and it represents an extraordinary intellectual achievement. Central to that achievement is physics, the enquiry into the structure and properties of matter; and mathematics, the chief engine of scientific enquiry, is in turn central to physics.

Before Galileo, philosophers followed Aristotle's example in looking for causes and reasons in nature. Why do dropped objects fall to the ground, and why does smoke rise? Because, said Aristotle, everything has its resting-place - heavy objects at the earth's centre, light things in the sky. Such questions and explanations seem reasonable. But Galileo changed the approach. He did not try to explain why objects fall when dropped; instead he described the situation mathematically, by quantifying the relation between the distance an object falls and the time it takes to do so.

The amazing fact is that the physical universe, for all its great diversity, can be described with precision and power in terms of a small number of equations. Galileo himself called mathematics "the language of nature," and Sir Arthur Eddington remarked that a study of physics gives us a "knowledge of mathematical structures". Does this mean that reality is fundamentally mathematical? Is mathematics, indeed, reality?

This question immediately prompts others. Some philosophers argue that mathematics is the creation of mind. We define certain concepts - number, or set - and we define certain rules for working with them. All the truths that follow are the logical consequences of these definitions. A change of definitions produces a change in the resulting truths, as witness Alice's version of multiplication as she falls down the rabbit-hole. If mathematics is the product of thought, and if reality is mathematical in character, does this mean that mind is the ultimate reality?

Even if one takes the opposing view that mathematics exists independently of mind, and is not created but discovered by thought, the puzzle remains because the things referred to in mathematics - numbers, sets, operations, functions - are abstract entities, which means that if they exist at all, they do so in an eternal realm outside space and time. How can these transcendent entities constitute the ordinary solid objects of our world?

A solution is to recognise that in describing the world mathematically, we deliberately take account only of its measurable aspects, only of what can be stated in quantitative terms. The rest - the qualitative dimensions of things: how they appear to subjective experience in their moral, aesthetic or social significance - is ignored. If we choose to look at the world through mathematical spectacles alone, of course we will see it as a fundamentally mathematical realm: but that might leave out much that cannot be expressed in equations.

This argument has much plausibility. But a stubborn fact remains: that the mathematical picture of nature, in the form of an insistent group of equations describing atoms and stars, makes possible such things as electric light, the exploration of space, and the destruction of Hiroshima. This powerfully suggests that mathematics captures truths about the world, and that we would all do well to understand it better therefore.

webTitle: Time for England to gain its freedom from Scotland

fields.headline: Time for England to gain its freedom from Scotland
fields.trailText: I had a really good weekend in the Scottish borders. The scenery around the river Tweed is gorgeous. If it was in France, the entire population of Islington would decamp there for the summer. It even stopped raining for one day, and the countryside looked like one of those early American landscape paintings, a mythic Elysium bathed in golden light. Towns such as Peebles and Moffat are still largely unspoilt, and their broad, generous high streets have not yet been taken over by Dixons, Curry's and Superdrug. The food is much better than it used to be, and the people are as friendly as they always have been.
fields.body:
I had a really good weekend in the Scottish borders. The scenery around the river Tweed is gorgeous. If it was in France, the entire population of Islington would decamp there for the summer. It even stopped raining for one day, and the countryside looked like one of those early American landscape paintings, a mythic Elysium bathed in golden light. Towns such as Peebles and Moffat are still largely unspoilt, and their broad, generous high streets have not yet been taken over by Dixons, Curry's and Superdrug. The food is much better than it used to be, and the people are as friendly as they always have been.

A Scottish friend discussed the coming rugby season. I wondered whether the humiliation of being beaten by Italy last season had been assuaged by defeating England. "We wouldn't mind losing to the Faroe Islands if we got to beat England," he said, adding, "I imagine the same goes for the English."

But of course it doesn't. This is a one-way rivalry. On the whole, people who support England at any sport would like England to win, but the special edge of longing, resentment and hatred some Scots feel for us is largely absent from our feelings about them. I said I thought that, if anything, we are more competitive with France. Indeed, since the Channel Tunnel was built, people in southern England feel physically and, in some ways, emotionally closer to France than to Scotland. Almost as many trains go to Paris from London as to Edinburgh, and if you add flights, there's much more traffic south.

It's yet another reason why I am so keen that England should gain its independence from Scotland. After the last few weeks, many English people might feel that it's time to get rid of the tyranny of Gordon Brown and even the Scottish-educated Tony Blair.

 I hate quoting taxi drivers, but the one who took me to Bournemouth station was so pleasant about the Liberal Democrats that I felt I should. "They're the nicest by far," he said, "much more polite than the other lot, Labour or Tories."

And he should know. Since Labour has petulently stopped going to Blackpool and the Tories refuse to go to Brighton, in the manner of a small boy stalking off with his football, Bournemouth gets more political conferences than anywhere else.

"Mind you," my driver continued, "we gave them Liberals a try here. Useless, they were. See that building?" He waved at a hideous excrescence which now blights one of the better seaside views in Britain. "They allowed that to be built. Horrible, isn't it?" I wondered if bribery might have played a part in such a conspicuously crass planning decision. "Oh, no," he said, "they really thought they were doing some good for the town. Prats. Nice prats, but prats all the same."

That night I spoke at my daughter's school speech day, and the only thing I said which raised even a frisson of disagreement was a defence of politicians. We all love to abuse them, I went on, but they were better than the alternative, which is rule by unelected despots. So perhaps the Liberal Democrats shouldn't worry too much. Our genial contempt is the tribute we pay to those set over us. It's only when you have real power that people even feel the need to call you prats.

 Sir Richard Branson dramatically announces that he is about to launch an airship which will cruise over Kosovo looking for unexploded landmines. The news is reported absolutely straight in the newspapers, rather in the manner of the old court circulars, as if it was self-evidently true and needed no elaboration. But it has been an awful week for Branson. Camelot won the vital court ruling over the Lottery on Thursday, and in spite of legal sabre-rattling he was unable to prevent the serialisation of the highly critical book by the investigative writer Tom Bower in the Daily Mail this week.

It paints a picture quite unlike the genial, bearded, be-sweatered philanthropist which Branson presents to the world, and I look forward to reading his reply. His response to all bad news is, rather like New Labour, to produce a new publicity stunt, so I was not remotely surprised to see that he now has the spectacular chutzpah to re-brand himself as Princess Diana.

Perhaps we shouldn't repeat Posh 'n' Becks jokes, considering the stuff that gets shouted at David Beckham by the more loathsome football fans. But this one seems innocent enough: Posh 'n' Becks get into a cab. "Where to, guv?" asks the driver. "What's that station where you can get a train to Brighton?" asks Becks. "That'd be Victoria," says the driver. "Thanks very much," Beckham replies, turning to his wife. "Victoria, what restaurant are we supposed to be going to?"

 Twice in the past week I've had arguments with friends and family about this point of grammar: should one say "he is taller than me" or "he is taller than I" (or shorter or dafter or whatever)? I think that the first is fine. "They are richer than us" sounds right and is perfectly clear. "They are richer than we are" is pedantic; "richer than we" just silly. The "I am" ending is fine as an intensifier: for example, "my son is 14 and he's taller than I am."

However, lots of people think I'm mistaken and that saying "taller than me" is a solecism quite as bad as saying: "Me and Doug went to the pub." I'd be grateful to learn readers' opinions.

 Amid the sensational political books published this month, there's a much gentler one written by Joe Ashton, the Labour MP for Bassetlaw. It's called Red Rose Blues, it's sharp and funny, and it would have been even sharper and funnier if the publishers hadn't cut out some of the best anecdotes.

My own favourite missing story is about the MC in a Sheffield working men's club who announced: "We've got a young lass starting out in her career now, in my opinion she's being paid too much, but the committee over-ruled me, and before she comes on, I regret to say someone has been urinating outside the ladies' lavatory, here she is, give a big hand please for Miss Dusty Springwell."

Dusty Springfield was doubled up with laughter and unable to sing for almost five minutes.

webTitle: One man's salt is another man's  scum

fields.headline: One man's salt is another man's  scum
fields.trailText: Who was to blame for the great petrol crisis? The government, most people say. But a columnist in the News of the World had no doubt at all about whom we should really target. The villains, a hard-hitting piece by Sin Simon argued, were the "avaricious, colluding, nasty, spiteful, grey-suited bean counters at the heart of our fuel companies". "The rabid greed that runs through oil companies like a dirty petrol stain beggars belief," he added deftly.
fields.body:
Who was to blame for the great petrol crisis? The government, most people say. But a columnist in the News of the World had no doubt at all about whom we should really target. The villains, a hard-hitting piece by Sin Simon argued, were the "avaricious, colluding, nasty, spiteful, grey-suited bean counters at the heart of our fuel companies". "The rabid greed that runs through oil companies like a dirty petrol stain beggars belief," he added deftly.

But a columnist in the Daily Telegraph picked out a different culprit entirely. The British people, a hard-hitting piece by Sin Simon argued, had failed to note the disparity between the good-natured anarchism of the general public and the sinister, hypocritical self-interest of the so-called protestors - "terrorists would be a better word". Yet the public, he believed, was too canny not to perceive over time that such types were "more the scum than the salt of the earth".

Perhaps Sin had assumed that the scum read the News of the World and not the Daily Telegraph. The avalanche of complaint which has followed, complete with demands that he be sacked/keelhauled/dismembered with all possible violence/ excommunicated, will have enlightened him now.

Next week in Smallweed: why I blame Tranmere Rovers FC for this fiasco: a hard-hitting piece by Sin Smene-or-ther.

Having rescued one ailing TV station with a glove puppet, Greg Dyke is attempting to repeat the trick at the BBC. Political editor Andrew Marr's reports on Tony Blair's handling of the fuel crisis were delivered with all the gravitas of a knitted sock - Letter from R Oakley to Tuesday's Daily Mail. That's Richard of Luton, Beds, by the way, not Robin.

We may be a little closer to establishing the identity of the original white knight. My own modern edition of Brewer's Dictionary Of Phrase And Fable gives nothing between White House, an institution in Washington DC, and White Lady, a kind of spectre whose appearance was taken to signify death in a house. In Normandy, white ladies were said to lurk in ravines and floods or on bridges, awaiting wayfarers whom they invited to dance. Should the wayfarers refuse, they were thrown into a ditch. Since Smallweed will shortly be visiting Normandy and cannot dance, this information is timely.

Brian Robinson of Brentwood, however, has a different edition of Brewer, since his, when you look up white knight, refers you to Tirant lo Blanch, a romance written in Catalan and produced in Valencia in 1490, loved by Cervantes, but not published in translation in England until 1984. Tirant's story, says my informant, to some extent parallels that of Guy of Warwick. This Guy, it emerges, was a doer of doughty deeds, who among other triumphs slew the Dun Cow, a monster which lived in Shropshire. The Cow's milk was thought to be inexhaustible, but one day an old woman who had already filled her pail from this source attempted to fill her sieve as well, whereupon the Cow, uncannily prefiguring the forecourt rage of our own day, became so enraged that it killed her. Guy was later reduced to begging outside his own castle. Even that cannot convince me that someone like Tirant lo Blanch is the right man to ride to the aid of the London stock exchange.

A s to Gawain and the green giant, also aired here last week, that too is a tale too long to tell in full, but it boils down to this. A giant clad entirely in green challenged Gawain to a duel with axes. Gawain smote the giant's head from its body, which he thought should force a submission, but instead the body picked up its head and demanded a replay in 12 months' time.

On the eve of this shoot-out, the knight stayed in a castle and did a deal with its lord that what either acquired should be passed on to the other. So when the lord's wife turned up in his bedchamber and sought to seduce him with kisses, he passed the kisses on to the lord. When he and the giant eventually met, Gawain was duly smitten, but wounded, not killed. The reason for this, it emerged, was that the green giant was actually the lord in disguise. The wife had been sent to tempt Gawain, but, because he stayed chaste, his life had been spared.

It is understood that when the news reached Camelot, the rest of the knights were overjoyed, and celebrated as if they had just won a contract to run a national lottery. Though he was not around at the time, Mike Connelly thinks by email that the giant went by the name of Sir Bercelak de Hautdesert. Even his blood was green, as it emerged, you might say, when he was beheaded.

A drenched person coming out of the rain the other day claimed it was raining stair rods. The concept of raining cats and dogs is weird enough, but at least explicable in terms of legends which make the cat an agent of bad weather and links dogs with the wind. But why stair rods? All the stair rods in my house - yours may be very different - are horizontal. The rain at the time, as I carefully ascertained, was closer to vertical. There is also the expression "raining pitchforks" for which I can find no justification at all.

Sir Bercelak de Hautdesert writes: You modern folk down in t'soft south don't know you are born. It certainly used to rain horizontally when I were living in Stanningley.

A statistician writes: Smallweed has made repeated references over the past few months to Tranmere Rovers FC. Analysis by myself and my assistant, de Hautdesert, suggests this trend has now reached a level somewhere between boiling point and 80% heteroscedasticity, thus locating Smallweed in an area which we calculating folk like to describe as morbid. Try Partick Thistle next time.

Analysis by myself and my assistant, de Hautdesert, suggests this trend has now reached a level somewhere between boiling point and 80% heteroscedasticity, thus locating Smallweed in an area which we calculating folk like to describe as morbid. Try Partick Thistle next time.

fields.headline: Alas poor theatre critic
fields.standfirst: Another Cherry Orchard, another Hamlet...  Michael Billington  on the reviewer's battle to stay fresh
fields.trailText: Another Cherry Orchard, another Hamlet... Michael Billington on the reviewer's battle to stay fresh
fields.body:
'Another Hamlet - how on earth do you cope?" asked a colleague the other day, as I set off for the National Theatre. My distinguished predecessor Philip Hope-Wallace used to encounter the same query as he trotted off to another Tosca. But, in a week when Julius Caesar and The Cherry Orchard are on the agenda, it's a perfectly valid question: how does the critic stay fresh when confronted by constantly revived works?

Hamlet, for me, is not a problem: it is too pluralistic in method, too unpindownable in meaning ever to stale. Above all, each revival offers not just a revelation of the actor's soul but a reflection of society. Take an obvious contrast. Peter Hall's 1965 Stratford production was a highly political affair in which David Warner's bescarved prince was spiritually alienated by the complex manouevrings at Elsinore. Now John Caird's National Theatre revival strips the play of politics altogether: the assumption - though this was before the quasi-fascist revolt over petrol prices - is that we live in totally apolitical times and that our only interest lies in the individual sensibility. It's an overtly romantic reading that tells us a lot about Caird and even more about our self-preoccupied age.

Hamlet is a mirror that gives back a picture of ourselves. But what is fascinating about Shakespeare is the way certain plays acquire a renewed vividness at particular moments in time. Peter Brook compares them to planets that either swing closer to the earth in its orbit or drift away. For Brook the bitterness of Timon of Athens brings it into focus, while Othello's jealousy is out of our range: broadly true except that it just takes one exceptional revival - such as Sam Mendes's meticulous Othello - to rescue a play from temporary oblivion.

But the perennial danger with Shakespeare is that the plays get revived more out of civic duty than expressive need: I'd defy any director of the RSC not to admit there are times when they've put on A Midsummer Night's Dream or Romeo and Juliet not because of any commandingly fresh vision, but simply because of the Bardic equivalent of Buggins' Turn. And if critics occasionally sound weary in the face of another return to Athens, Arden or Verona, it is because they can detect the theatrical equivalent of crop rotation.

That is why I bang on about the need to expand the Shakespearean repertory rather than rely on a dozen-or-so box office certs. And I would argue there is a palpable excitement at Stratford this year about the exploration of the Histories. Even the deliberate discontinuity, whereby the plays are staged in widely differing styles on a variety of stages, becomes a comment on contemporary Britain. We live in a fragmented, possibly dissolving kingdom: instead of approaching the plays with the Victorian assurance that they deal with the restoration of order, we find in them an echo of our scepticism about power.

Given a strong directorial intention, I have no problem in staying fresh for Shakespeare: my only difficulty lies with particular spaces such as the Bankside Globe. But different questions arise with post-1880s naturalistic drama where the variations are more closely calibrated. No two King Lears or Tempests ever look or sound alike. But how many ways are there of doing Ghosts or The Cherry Orchard without violating the play? You update Chekhov at your peril: I remember a post- revolutionary Cherry Orchard in which the characters seemed to be survivors of a seismic social eruption which the text itself anticipates.

Chekhov, to come clean, is difficult for the critic. Of course, one loves the plays. Of course, in a great production, one constantly re-discovers them. Peter Stein represented the ravishing beauty of the white-blossomed cherry orchard in a way which made its destruction unbearable. Terry Hands in The Seagull, by placing the interval after the third act, devastatingly showed how Nina and Konstantin are bruised by time while the older characters remain impermeable. What I am dead against, which once led me to demand a three-year moratorium on Chekhov, is the kind of lazy, linen-suited revival which simply swathes the plays in sentimental atmosphere: fortunately there are fewer of those around than there used to be.

I find myself constantly refreshed by what Jonathan Miller calls the "afterlife" of a classic, its possibility of successive re- creation. But the job of a critic would be much easier - and the vitality of the theatre much greater - if we widened the existing repertory. You'd be astonished how many great and not so great plays still go unperformed.

It was a shock this week in Halifax to realise I'd never before seen Euripides' Alcestis on stage: in a sense one still hasn't - since this is a radical Ted Hughes adaptation. The Greeks, the Germans, the French: there are still large tracts of unexplored territory. Even Ibsen we know only in part: I once saw Love's Comedy in rep and The League of Youth at a drama school but I suspect that's it for my lifetime.

Critics themselves are part of the problem: they trot out the old phrase "deservedly neglected" when confronted by anything less than a mainstream classic. Audiences too are wretchedly conservative. But the real problem lies with managements who, with a few notable exceptions, stick with winning formulae with the commercial myopia of a Hollywood mogul.

It has struck me lately, for instance, that we are staggeringly ignorant of British drama from 1900 to 1950. Barrie's Dear Brutus is coming up at Nottingham and Maugham's The Circle at the Oxford Stage Company. But we know next-to-nothing of Pinero, St John Ervine or Monkhouse, not to mention Galsworthy, Bridie or Priestley, aside from An Inspector Calls. If I sometimes get critically testy, it is not with the revival of another Hamlet or The Cherry Orchard, these are great plays one can go on rediscovering all one's life. It is with the debilitating narrowness of the British repertory and with our failure to realise that, outside the accepted masterpieces, lies a wealth of undiscovered plays. Exactly the kind of work we built the National Theatre to explore. But that's another story.

 The Cherry Orchard is at the National Theatre, London SE1 (box office: 0207- 452 3000) till 2001. Michael Billington is the Guardian's chief theatre critic

fields.headline: Incomprehensible
fields.standfirst: Billy Budd is in English. It will be sung in England. So why give it surtitles?  Andrew Clements  is outraged at Covent Garden
fields.trailText: Billy Budd is in English. It will be sung in England. So why give it surtitles? Andrew Clements is outraged at Covent Garden
fields.body:
There is a story, possibly apocryphal, that when Benjamin Britten was composing Billy Budd, he showed the libretto to Michael Tippett, who had one suggestion: that in a work in which homoeroticism is so pervasive, the line "Clear the seamen from the deck" might be misconstrued.

Britten changed his text, yet the news that the Royal Opera, in its apparently fast-evaporating wisdom, has introduced surtitles for its revival of Billy Budd half makes me wish the composer had ignored his friend's suggestion; the prospect of the audience at Wednesday's first night sniggering as they read that line in what is one of the bleakest, least forgiving works in the repertory would have shown up the company's decision for the crass insensitivity it is.

The idea that an English-speaking audience - listening to a predominantly English-speaking cast singing English words set by the greatest English opera composer - needs the text projected above them so that they can understand what is going on is an insult to either the performers involved, implying they are incapable of getting the text across, or to the intelligence of those who go to see the show. The whole notion is so incredible that when the Royal Opera first announced the performances, labelling them as "sung in English with English surtitles", it was natural to assume there had been some mistake.

Whoever took this bizarre decision apparently did not bother to tell the cast. The performers did not know until after the first night and, in an interview this week in the Daily Telegraph, the leading British baritone Simon Keenlyside, who is singing the title role, made clear how much he was looking forward to singing an English- language opera to an audience that would understand the words without "surtitles or translations getting in the way. That sort of immediate communication is not something you can often achieve in opera."

But communicating with the audience, or at least with a committed opera-going audience that understands the way the medium works musically and dramatically, seems to have become a very low priority for the new, improved Royal Opera House. It becomes more important, by far, not to alienate the corporate lobby who fill so many of the stalls seats. Expecting them to actually listen to what is being sung rather than just being able to read the story as the music washes over them, is a challenge they are not prepared to risk. Not boring the rich punters matters most these days in Bow Street - more, it seems, than presenting opera seriously and professionally.

If the battle against English surtitles for foreign language works has to be conceded now - there's no doubt comprehension is increased for non-linguists - introducing them for works sung in the vernacular is another matter. When opera ceases to be a medium in which the drama is presented through the symbiosis of the music and words, and instead is turned entirely into an exercise in reading, with the addition of some more or less engaging background music, then the medium is devalued, and it really will become museum art of a vacuous and purely decorative kind.

 Billy Budd is at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (box office: 020 7304 4000) on September 25 and 28, and October 3

fields.headline: Old cheese and stinkers
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
Hard not to lie awake in the wee small hours this week, troubled by women's low expectations of themselves. Mostly this was prompted by the rather less than lovely offering Jo Brand's Seven Ages of Man (Radio 2), which kicked off this week. Stumbled might be a better word.

Because her heart and sexual politics appear to be in the right place, I've never actually typed these words before, though they have long presented themselves to my mind: Jo Brand is a one-trick comic pony, and not a wildly funny one at that. But, given the provocation of her seven-week recharting of Jacques's Seven Ages of Man speech, the time has come.

Yes, it's on Radio 2, and on a weekend lunchtime slot at that, and yes, it's a stringing together of thematically linked clips, so it's never going to be avant garde. All that said, this men-are-crap-and-women-eat-cakes series is as woolly and rancidly stiltonesque as any Radio 2 show of old, with a mixed bag of clips (ranging from fairly amusing to painful) on manhood, held together with the lamest jokes from Brand. I'd sit down before you face the soul-destroyer that is, for example: "Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms? That sounds like me on my holidays in Ibiza" or "Bet you didn't think I could move that fast without the aid of a curry." If those haven't got you reaching for the Complete Works of the Bard and a stiff drink, perhaps this one will do it for you: "Is there a Fathercare? Yes, it's called the pub."

Have we nipped back to 1975 and nobody thought to tell me? This stagnant men-bashing stuff is from another planet, especially when there are real bad meanies out there (see below) who are rather more complicated creatures than Brand would have us believe. I know it's an act, love, but that's really no excuse.

Come at this manly business via the excellent It's My Story: Loving Men, Living Lies (Radio 4) and you might well reach the same conclusions as Brand, but at least you would have several broken hearts and shattered egos as evidence. Two women, both bright, smart and seemingly alert to cad-detecting, fell for romantic imposters peddling cheesy chat-up lines. Even though both had misgivings after initial meetings (always go with those, people), they entered into serious, near marital relationships with the philandering fibbers.

Rosie, 49, fell for the "size of the gesture" (I know, cue cheap Jo Brand gag) when a stranger stopped her in the street and remarked on her "staggering beauty". After that he stood her up, wasn't on the mobile number he gave her and wasn't who he said he was, but still she went for dinner with him. "It was intensely flattering," she said, even if it all felt unreal: he wanted commitment; he told her he loved her on their second meeting and no one had told her that for almost 20 years; he soon proposed. As scant credentials for him she had the fact that he knew the coach of the British Olympic rowing team and that he recognised a piece of obscure classical music. I wish that had been enough, but instead Rosie discovered she was only one of at least 15 women.

It all sounds silly, eh, and you would have sent him packing? The strength of this programme was that it unravelled the insecurity that leads women to take in these dodgy charmers in the first pace. In a genuinely spooky moment, Rosie played back an affectionate answerphone message from Ian. It sounded so ordinary, so everyday, so unremarkable, a bit naff ("Love-ya, byeeeee, missing you already!"). It sounded horribly real.

fields.headline: Gail force
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Family Day in the Platt house was, as Martin said in Coronation Street (ITV), an opportunity for everyone to be nice to one another and not argue. An intriguing concept - and a testament to enduring optimism even in the face of grim reality - it was never going to be anything other than disastrous. Like a disco in a minefield.

Still, it started well. Martin handed everyone orange juice, Gail did some brisk ironing while David watched telly. There isn't much else Little David does. He watches more telly than everyone else in the Street put together, probably more than anyone in all of Soapland. It's a wonder he has got time to stomp around complaining about "Beth'ny the buh-bey," what with a telly habit like his (though he may coincide his stomping with the ad breaks).

Anyway, such was the hope emanating from the Platt house on Family Day, there was even a little labrador puppy on the kitchen calendar, all bright eyes and floppy ears. Alas it wasn't to last, as we know only too well that the Platts follow the Manson family model as opposed to the Waltons one.

Quick as a quick thing, Sarah - who, having so spectacularly lost her virginity has now lost her Lou - and Gail started bickering about Bethany's welfare. "She's my baby," Sarah snarled, displaying at least a grasp of How Babies Are Made. How wise she is in retrospect. If only she'd worked it out earlier, she might still have been in a position to go to Candice's to watch videos without a care in the world. (Apart from the nagging doubt that the rest of the neighbourhood would soon turn up on her parents' doorstep carrying blazing torches and chanting "Burn the evil ones".)

As it is, she can't, though that didn't stop Spindly - but oddly paunchy - Martin saying it was okay. To no one's surprise, it wasn't okay with Gail. Gail, who has been exploding more frequently than a volcano with an overactive thyroid, wanted Sarah to act like an adult which, it would seem, doesn't involve watching videos (or indeed telly) but does entail arguing in the garden. And in front of Barney the rabbit too. It would be enough to make anyone pack their bags and leave - which is exactly what Sarah did, pitching up at Roy and Hayley's. You couldn't say for sure, but that labrador's eyes seemed a little bit dimmer.

Sarah, an unlucky girl from the core of her chromosomes to the tips of her pigtails, hadn't found her Lou, but she did have a collapsible cot which she planned to un- collapse in their spare room just round from the "Arthur Askey in The Love Racket" poster. (The Love Racket, incidentally, was written by Noel Gay who also wrote the song Run, Rabbit, Run, which may well be advice Barney would like to heed before he too gets dragged into the Platt's internecine squabbles). Roy wasn't too keen on Sarah's tenancy but Hayley was wetting herself with excitement at the prospect of having Sarah and Bethany under her roof. Well, it looked like excitement, but it might have been due to an unfortunate oversight on the part of her surgeons.

Some people will do anything to leave Coronation Street, but confessing to murder is a bit extreme. It seems Jim McDonald couldn't stand his stick-on pine dado rail and his floral and forlorn oven gloves any longer, preferring a jail cell with a thin mattress and a love heart scrawled on the wall. Strangely, to Steve at least, he seemed calm and collected and quite happy in a netball bib in prison. Compared to being married to Liz and going out with Grasping Gwen, it must seem like a holiday camp. But with nicer bedlinen.

Vera, meanwhile, had an even more desperate plan to escape Weatherfield: moving to Blackpool. And were that not enough, she's planning decamping to be near Gary Mallett and his devil children. No wonder Jack's lollipop is looking a bit wobbly.

Often, I find myself expressing empathy for Elle Macpherson. Whether I'm cleaning the loo or taking the bins out, queueing in the post office or wondering whether to have semi-skimmed or skimmed milk in my latte, I think "This is exactly like Elle's life. We are surely soulmates." And so in Friends (Channel 4), I find myself agreeing with her over the annoying aspects of the other friends. Especially Ross.
