(The Love Racket, incidentally, was written by Noel Gay who also wrote the song Run, Rabbit, Run, which may well be advice Barney would like to heed before he too gets dragged into the Platt's internecine squabbles). Roy wasn't too keen on Sarah's tenancy but Hayley was wetting herself with excitement at the prospect of having Sarah and Bethany under her roof. Well, it looked like excitement, but it might have been due to an unfortunate oversight on the part of her surgeons. Some people will do anything to leave Coronation Street, but confessing to murder is a bit extreme. It seems Jim McDonald couldn't stand his stick-on pine dado rail and his floral and forlorn oven gloves any longer, preferring a jail cell with a thin mattress and a love heart scrawled on the wall. Strangely, to Steve at least, he seemed calm and collected and quite happy in a netball bib in prison. Compared to being married to Liz and going out with Grasping Gwen, it must seem like a holiday camp. But with nicer bedlinen. Vera, meanwhile, had an even more desperate plan to escape Weatherfield: moving to Blackpool. And were that not enough, she's planning decamping to be near Gary Mallett and his devil children. No wonder Jack's lollipop is looking a bit wobbly. Often, I find myself expressing empathy for Elle Macpherson. Whether I'm cleaning the loo or taking the bins out, queueing in the post office or wondering whether to have semi-skimmed or skimmed milk in my latte, I think "This is exactly like Elle's life. We are surely soulmates." And so in Friends (Channel 4), I find myself agreeing with her over the annoying aspects of the other friends. Especially Ross.

fields.headline: Whipped into a frenzy
fields.standfirst: Dancing Bolero brings out the best and the worst in Maurice Bjart, says  Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: Dancing Bolero brings out the best and the worst in Maurice Bjart, says Judith Mackrell
fields.body:
Ever since Maurice Béjart created his signature ballet Bolero in 1960, it's been performed all over the world. But danced by his own company, on their first visit to London in five years, it acts as a handy checklist of everything that's most trashy, and appealing, about this man's work.

The appeal lies in its unblushing exploitation of the primitive charge of dance as its soloist (on Wednesday Elisabet Ros, though it can be danced by a man ) stands on a dias and whips herself into an erotic crescendo before a frankly gagging crowd of men. The effect is high-class table dance as Ros's stealthily predatory footwork accelerates into split crutch kicks and Medusa arms. But, vulgar as it is, it's a mischievous reminder that ballerinas and sometimes princes aim to wield a similar power over their public, albeit in more tastefully demurring ways. The dire thing about this work, which began Béjart's first progamme at Sadler's Wells, is the speed with which, like all cheap highs, it turns dull.

Part of the blame rests with Ravel's turgid score which delays its promise of climax way too long. But it's also a feature of Béjart's style that, by offering everything to the eye in terms of flashy posturing and revved-up steps, it leaves nothing to the imagination.

The chorus in Seven Greek Dances (music by Mikis Theodorakis) is far more decorous, arching in gentle rhythms to the sounds of the Mediterranean or clustering into politely folkloric circles and abstract dance patterns. The men muster a certain Greek-inflected vigour but the choreography for the women (a very young and somewhat vacant corps) looks almost prissy.

Béjart on his best behaviour is much less fun. In Adagietto, a solo extracted from a longer setting of Mahler's 5th Symphony, Béjart is plain obscure. In the context of the whole piece, it might become clear why this lone male dancer is so manically depressed but, despite Gil Roman's luminously detailed performance, his repertoire of cutely deranged gestures and suffering longeurs still looks like a comic case of over-reaction.

The other work in the programme, Elton-Berg, was created for London, which may explain why it's set to music by our very own Elton John. Or rather Béjart started out creating the work to music by Berg , then repeated the same choreography to a song of John's. Musically, Béjart has done odder things (witness the mix of Queen and Mozart next week) but this piece actually contains the best choreography of the evening - with long juicy phrases of dance wound into extravagently sculpted images. The audience loved it almost as much as they loved Bolero. However carping his critics, Béjart's fans just can't get enough.

 At Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020- 7863 8198). Till September 25.

fields.headline: Baby boomers
fields.standfirst: Babies are the best way to launder a sordid past. But why should we give Bowie and Douglas any more credibility than the Turner-Boveys?
fields.trailText: Babies are the best way to launder a sordid past. But why should we give Bowie and Douglas any more credibility than the Turner-Boveys?
fields.body:
Babies: are they the New Baguettes (Fendi, not Prèt à Manger), the New Sex or the New Salvation? Whatever, the Glossips (glossy gossip magazines: Hello!, OK! and Now) decided that something was in the air last week when all three starred on their front covers not a wedding, a scrummy chocolate bar - or even both - but babies.

In the week following the terminally tarnished nuptials of Turner-Bovey Inc, the babies acted as tiny John the Baptists, supposedly cleansing the cash-for-most -profound-moments racket of its tacky taste - though why selling the first pictures of your infant is better than selling your marriage, which at least involves two consenting, if not quite sentient, adults, I'll never understand. And exactly what is the difference between being poor and making your child beg on the street and being worth millions and selling photographs of your children for another half a mill - as Iman and Bowie and Catherine and Michael have just done in Hello! and OK!, respectively, if not respectably - except that, if you're rich, you've really got no excuse?

Babies are currently the best way to launder whatever you feel is a bit lacking in sparkle in your life. They will launder your money, your sordid past, your boring present, and make sure you come up smelling of Eau de Bonnepointe. We are more or less immune to the cooing of a thousand blonde TV presenter girls, but there is something peculiarly repulsive about middle-aged showbiz millionaires with exciting, squalid pasts (and I say this as someone with an exciting, squalid past myself) wearing sick on their shoulders as if it were the George Cross and expecting to be taken to the heart of Middle England/Middle America/the Middle Ages.

I'm talking about David Bowie, who regularly took his own weight in cocaine (admittedly, not difficult in the 70s), insisted that another woman shared the wedding night bed with him and his poor first wife, and said things such as, "Everyone's bisexual, man", and, "What this country needs is a really strong fascist leader". Now he says of his marriage and fatherhood, in the midst of an 18-page photospread, "There's a joy and contentment that's almost palpable to both of us; overnight, our lives have been enriched beyond belief."

And Michael Douglas - he of the substance abuse and sex addiction, whose wife once found him in bed with her best friend - now simpers in the middle of a 21-page feature (mine's bigger than yours, Limey!) that "I'm the official burper!" (Of the baby, one hopes.)

Of course, no one would turn down the chance of shacking up with Iman or Catherine Zeta-Jones, and goodness knows I'm not condemning dumping spouses and moving on in one's life - what, me, the Daily Mail's official Worst Mother in Britain? But there is something vile about men such as Bowie and Douglas, who are forever drawing attention to their own alleged integrity and liberal politics, not only cashing in on their private lives, but proclaiming them with such gluttonous gloating. Why should we give them any more credibility than we do to the Turner-Boveys? Yet, regardless of these grabfests, we undoubtedly will continue to read about Bowie's dedication to his art and Douglas's anti-Hollywood stance.

To my mind, you can't really blame a Turner or a Bovey for selling their souls: they are creatures only of and for the marketplace, with no resonance or responsibility in our culture. (No teenager ever sat sobbing in her bedroom, "Oh, I hate my life - only Anthea Turner understands me!")

On the other hand, the sex and drugs counterculture that both Bowie and Douglas enjoyed and exploited so flagrantly was, on balance, a far better thing than the joyless repression it replaced. But it did undoubtedly create many casualties. And it is these people - the single mother on methadone, the Bowie casualty nodding out in a toilet somewhere, still convinced that the Starman will save him - that I can't help but think of when I see these huge spreads of ex-counterculture icons enjoying all the spoils that mainstream success, monogamy and jogging bring.

More than anything, it's the same creepy feeling that hearing John Peel's Home Truths gives me. I know we're meant to genuflect before his portrait as though he was a hairy Queen Mother, but I find it filthily objectionable that someone who grew rich and respected from preaching the 60s mantra "if it feels good, do it!" can, when it suits them, come over so cosy and domestic that it would have Nigella Lawson reaching for the crack-pipe.

Like his friend Bowie and their contemporary Douglas, Peel advocated ceaseless shagging and substance abuse as the road to the palace of wisdom. Yet because they had money, and lots of it, they managed to survive the 70s and thrive in the decades that followed. For the young working class swept away by this message, however, the road of excess led to madness, alienation and incarceration.

I don't blame Peel, Bowie and Douglas for changing their minds. But I do blame them for rubbing our collective noses in the fact that the rich and famous can walk on the wild side and still return to the domestic fold when it suits them, whereas the young and poor need only stray off the straight and narrow once to be trapped in a cul-de-sac of sorrow.

And the third magazine, Now? Well, that featured babies, too - but not the beloved bartered little bundles of joy who have already proved so profitable to reformed roués and their young trophy wives. No, Now featured grim shots of Meg Mathews and Patsy Kensit pushing prams, with the headline "Poor babies: Victims of the rock'n'roll lifestyle". It was amazingly consistent, if nothing else. Though a million miles and pounds removed from some inner-city sink estate, Meg and Patsy got the blame simply by sticking around. Their globe-trotting husbands, on the other hand, were painted as the innocent victims.

Patriarchy invariably finds a way of making all the nicest things in life into a stick with which to beat women: food (you'll get fat), alcohol (you'll get infertile), sex (you'll be a slag). Now, apparently, it even uses babies to beat their mothers with, while celebrating the spawning of old, rich men, regardless of their promiscuous pasts.

Like Angela Bowie and Diandra Douglas, who have been effectively written out of their husbands' shiny new lives, the message to Meg and Patsy is clear: go on, clear off, and leave the field clear for your famous husbands to get married to someone younger, cleaner, fresher, with no stretch marks on their minds or bodies. Just like we wanted poor Paula Yates to. But, somehow, I think girls today are made of sterner stuff.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Ken Russell
fields.trailText: Ken Russell
fields.body:
Ken Russell was born in Southampton in 1927. After service in the navy, he worked as a ballet dancer, actor and photographer before securing a job at the BBC, where he made documentaries. In 1963, he made his feature film debut with French Dressing, and in 1969 he directed the Oscar-winning Women In Love. He has staged operas, directed pop videos and written a novel, Mike & Gaby's Space Gospel. He has been married three times, has eight children and lives in Hampshire.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Breathing.

What is your greatest fear?
A puncture.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Oliver Reed - he was a saint.

Which living person do you most admire?
My old English black-and-tan toy terrier - he is a saint.

What vehicles do you own?
A wheelbarrow and a lawnmower.

What is your greatest extravagance?
A second cup of tea.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Not sticking stamps on charity envelopes.

What is your favourite smell?
The first fart of the day.

What is your favourite building?
My outside loo.

What is your favourite journey?
Going to it.

What is your favourite fantasy?
A trip in Mike and Gaby's spaceship.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
Zapped!

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Capital.

For what cause would you die?
Heart failure.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Can't find my dictionary.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My progeny.

Which living person do you most despise?
Myself. How many hours do we have?

When and where were you happiest?
Last Saturday in the back garden watching my son Rex hit his first six.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
A power failure.

What keeps you awake at night?
Something in the attic.

How would you like to die?
Walking the dog.

Do you believe in life after death?
Only when I'm listening to Bruckner.

How would you like to be remembered?
Reverently.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya  gets ready for Christmas (and hopes that the world doesn't end before December).
fields.body:
Call me restless, but I have already started to think about Christmas. I hate rushing at the last minute in search of inspiring gifts (which usually means baring fangs and claws in some overcrowded shop to argue with some excitable blonde over the last bottle of scented olive oil), so I was delighted to find www.buyagift.co.uk. The site is divided into zones (Adrenaline, Chill, Gadgets, etc), with gifts such as a wine-tasting day for £11, a hot-air balloon flight for £139, a micro-telescope for £19, or a European Formula One Racing Experience at a top track for £2,899.

At a more utilitarian level, I was utterly thrilled to find www.undercoverexperience.co.uk, a lingerie emporium. Finding good bras can be a chore, and this site stocks La Perla, Rigby & Peller, Aubade, and others. It carries sizes up to 56J, and there are also instructions on self-measurement and sizing. The choice is impressive: there are 12 categories of bra, from budget to glamour, padded to minimiser. For those with figures less perfect than mine, they also sell water-filled bras.

'How can you write about lingerie when the world is coming to an end, child? Repent!' Mum shrieked, peering into the screen over my shoulder; I must ask her to return her spare key. She's so predictable: her affair with the young Spaniard came to an end, so she's taken up religion again.

Still, I humoured her, and keyed in 'repent': up came www.raptureready.com. I'm always ready for rapture, so I inspected the site. It has a Rapture Index, where events are rated on their catastrophic possibilities (so, Occult is up because of the success of Harry Potter). In the light of recent difficulties, maybe Downing Street should check it out.

www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: Roll on world war three

fields.headline: Roll on world war three
fields.standfirst: Having all the petrol I wanted, my hatred turned against those who hadn't - bloody fools, I thought. What do they need it for?
fields.trailText: Having all the petrol I wanted, my hatred turned against those who hadn't - bloody fools, I thought. What do they need it for?
fields.body:
The fading petrol crisis - fading for the people of Britain if not for the government - now feels like something of a missed opportunity. The fuel shortages caused disruption and hardship across the whole country, and united its people in resentment against high petrol taxes. But where was the Dunkirk spirit that is supposed to envelop us at times like this?

Perhaps if the blockade had lasted longer - if the country really had been brought to its knees - it would have made its appearance. Perhaps then people with just a little petrol left would have been moved to share it with the more needy, would have used up their remaining supplies to drive old people to hospital or other people's children to school. Perhaps they would have cheerfully made way for others in any remaining petrol queues. Perhaps they would have done the shopping for their neighbours at Tesco or have volunteered to drive doctors on their rounds to visit the sick. But I could detect no sign of such a spirit last week. It was the same old bloody-minded, me-first, fuck-you Britain that we have become accustomed to in these prosperous, materialistic days.

I was only just born at the time of Dunkirk, so I didn't consciously experience the coming together of the nation in a mood of self-sacrifice in our darkest hour. But even then little pockets of traditional bloody-mindedness remained. My late mother recalled how, one day in 1940, she was having a cup of tea in a cafe on the south coast just before 5pm when it was due to close. The cafe-owner was already pulling down the shutters when a group of exhausted and bedraggled British soldiers in muddy uniforms appeared at the door, begging for something to eat or drink. The lady said firmly that they were too late, but then my mother told her that she would punch her on the nose if she didn't shut up and went behind the counter herself to serve them tea and sandwiches. It subsequently transpired that they were some of the first British soldiers to escape from Dunkirk.

But that incident clearly wasn't typical. We pulled together then. We were united in a common cause - the defeat of the Nazis - and the unfamiliar solidarity between British people of all classes and backgrounds made us feel happy and proud of ourselves. Since the war, there have been occasional efforts to revive such national solidarity and appeals by political leaders to the Dunkirk spirit, but they have never really worked. There have been plenty of crises, but never one quite profound enough to wean us from our selfish ways. The petrol crisis seems to have made us, if anything, more self-centred than usual.

I, certainly, thought only of myself. I wanted to drive to the country last weekend, so I got up early to go out in search of an open petrol station in London that wasn't giving priority to worthy people such as nurses and doctors. I was lucky. I found one quite quickly, and got to the front of the queue in only half an hour. But driving home complacently with my full tank, I had to make a left turn beside a much longer line of motorists waiting for petrol on Shepherd's Bush Green. There were hundreds of them, and they all looked at me with hatred and suspicion as I sneaked past them on the left-hand side in an effort to get to my turning. It seems to have occurred to none of them that I wasn't trying to jump their queue.

I made excellent progress, but was finally prevented from turning left by a single car which blocked my path and refused to move out of the way, although it had plenty of room to do so. I hooted and gesticulated to indicate my intention, but the driver was steadfast. It was only after I got out of my car and shouted at him through his closed window that I only wanted to turn left that this furious man grudgingly edged forward to make this possible.

Having all the petrol I wanted, my hatred turned against those who hadn't. Bloody fools, I thought. What do they need it for? I was heavily delayed on the way out of London by two petrol queues on each side of a road, causing a major traffic jam in the middle of it.

As the radio informed me, celebrations marking the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Britain were being held that weekend, and - who knows? - there might have been war veterans in those queues. But who cared? I was only interested in getting on my way. It clearly takes rather more than a petrol crisis to turn us into decent human beings again. Roll on world war three.
fields.bodyText: The fading petrol crisis - fading for the people of Britain if not for the government - now feels like something of a missed opportunity. The fuel shortages caused disruption and hardship across the whole country, and united its people in resentment against high petrol taxes. But where was the Dunkirk spirit that is supposed to envelop us at times like this? Perhaps if the blockade had lasted longer - if the country really had been brought to its knees - it would have made its appearance. Perhaps then people with just a little petrol left would have been moved to share it with the more needy, would have used up their remaining supplies to drive old people to hospital or other people's children to school. Perhaps they would have cheerfully made way for others in any remaining petrol queues. Perhaps they would have done the shopping for their neighbours at Tesco or have volunteered to drive doctors on their rounds to visit the sick. But I could detect no sign of such a spirit last week. It was the same old bloody-minded, me-first, fuck-you Britain that we have become accustomed to in these prosperous, materialistic days. I was only just born at the time of Dunkirk, so I didn't consciously experience the coming together of the nation in a mood of self-sacrifice in our darkest hour. But even then little pockets of traditional bloody-mindedness remained. My late mother recalled how, one day in 1940, she was having a cup of tea in a cafe on the south coast just before 5pm when it was due to close. The cafe-owner was already pulling down the shutters when a group of exhausted and bedraggled British soldiers in muddy uniforms appeared at the door, begging for something to eat or drink. The lady said firmly that they were too late, but then my mother told her that she would punch her on the nose if she didn't shut up and went behind the counter herself to serve them tea and sandwiches. I wanted to drive to the country last weekend, so I got up early to go out in search of an open petrol station in London that wasn't giving priority to worthy people such as nurses and doctors. I was lucky. I found one quite quickly, and got to the front of the queue in only half an hour. webTitle: Dulcie Domum: The weak shall inherit...

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: The weak shall inherit...
fields.standfirst: 'I can now hear fairies farting in Finland, but can't recall Fred's face'
fields.trailText: 'I can now hear fairies farting in Finland, but can't recall Fred's face'.
fields.body:
The divine Fred has not phoned during the 18 days since I got back from Umbria. I must distract myself with ear-syringing. Against all instincts to let someone inject liquid into your head. Nurse approaches with huge, heavy syringe, looking big enough to anaesthetise a rhinoceros, and shoots warm water into my right ear. Horrible sloshing sound as if I am underwater. Wonder if, by some treacherous malfunction of an aural-nasal passage, I could drown while sitting in a treatment room. Or would I be rescued by pneumatic maidens in Lycra? Baywax.

Nurse smiles as lump of earwax "pops out nicely". You can always trust a nurse to congratulate you on something vile. Wish she could also syringe out thoughts of Fred. Earwax looks a bit like a sultana. I suppose that is what my memories of Umbrian dalliance would look like. I did burst joy's grape against my palate fine, but now it has withered into a sultana.

Stand up, rather giddily, and am deafened by the roar of my own clothes rustling. I expect, when I get home, the phone will not ring more loudly than ever. On arrival, I plunge key into lock with sound like car crash, and am greeted by Aunt Elspeth who whispers, "I'd like a prrrivate worrrd with you, if you can sparrre a moment, dearrr."

Make excuse and lock myself in the bathroom. Cannot, for a moment, face any further details of aunt's geriatric malaises. Now I have had my ears syringed, I can almost hear her arteries hardening. But I don't want to get lumbered with all that again. I want to stare deep, deep into Fred's peerless eyes. Alas, though I can now hear fairies farting in Finland, I am having difficulty recalling Fred's face.

I know he was something like Michelangelo's David's dad, but the edges are getting a little blurred. Long to go back to Italy again, though the sound of cicadas and Catholic bells would now be unbearably poignant, as well as loud. Recall that, when I first met Fred, he used the word "poignant". Since our dalliance everything seems poignant. He has impoignated me.

Aunt ambushes me in the kitchen.

"Dulcie, dearrr, therrre's something imporrrtant..."

Harriet bursts in and demands to know why there are no acrylic paints or peanut butter in the house. A buoyant economy offers so many opportunities for disappointment.

"If we were living in Bulgaria," I snap, "you'd be a waitress on your feet all day just for bed and a meal - no wages. You'd have to live on tips."

"Oh, bugger Bulgaria!" cries Harriet, deftly uniting the Wombles and the deathbed of George V.

Somehow, her exclamation also makes me wonder whether, since I left, Fred has turned with relief to impoignating the milkman.

"Dulcie, dearrr..."

Must, as the saying goes, be there for aunt, although I would rather be elsewhere for me, frankly. But I am lumbered. My ex-spouse, his great-aunt and our teenagers can just about make ends meet in this, the post-nuclear family from hell. My dreams of a flat in Panicale are pie in the sky.

Follow aunt into her bedroom. Trust she does not want to show me anything that needs syringing.

"Look, dearrr..."

Even as she launches into her lowest, most indecent whisper, I hear the phone ring in the kitchen and Harriet answering it. With my new, clean ears I note every modulation in Harriet's voice, while almost excluding aunt's. "Yeah, it wuz a wicked holiday."

"Dulcie, dearrr, I've come to a decision."

"Yeah, Mum'z around. D'you wanna speak to her?"

"I'm going to change my will, dearrr. I'm going to make you my heirrr, Dulcie - afterrr all, you'rrre the one who's looking afterrr me."

"Mum! Mum!"

Transfixed by the possibility of Fred on the phone at the very moment when aunt seems to be offering me big bucks, I can only goggle and gape like a fish out of Baywatch.

"Mum!" Harriet appears in the doorway. "Alice is on the phone. She wants to come and stay next week. Tell her she can't. We don't want smoking in this house, even if she is a lesbian."

fields.headline: How to be a student
fields.trailText: When you first become a student, you have to decide whether your life is going to centre around coffee or alcohol.
fields.body:
There are two types of students: mature students and normal students. Normal students are not mature. When you first become a student, you have to decide whether your life is going to centre around coffee or alcohol. If it's alcohol, then you drink yourself stupid on a regular basis. This is a vital part of the education process - the first year has to be spent in the student bar, where beer is cheap; the second year is spent between the off-licence and your evil-smelling digs; and the last year is spent in rehab, or the library, as it's sometimes known.

Alternatively, you can meet other like-minded students for a coffee and conversation. Occasionally, these groups will really whoop it up and pass round the chocolate Hobnobs. Some people meet their spouse here in the first term at university, and do their essays holding hands. If a coffee-type student tells you that they're dropping a lot of acid, you can safely assume they're studying chemistry.

One of the most liberating experiences of being a student is that you escape the oppressive tyranny of your parents (after they've dropped you and all your stuff off at college, that is). Most people take the opportunity to chill out, but others make the mistake of taking themselves seriously. This means they go into either student politics or student religion: student politics is alcohol with anger, and student religion is coffee with praying.

Poor students have to live on baked beans on toast, although if they were slightly richer they'd still be living on a diet of beans on toast because that's the only thing they can cook. The name of this meal is 'fresh fruit and veg', when they speak to their mothers once a term to ask for money. Asking for money is a fine art for students. They have to choose their moment right, and then adopt a heroin-chic look so that their mothers will be appalled to see how close to death they are.

The golden rule for students is not to get too friendly with anybody in the first week, because if they turn out to be the coffee-drinking nerd from hell, you won't be able to shake them off for the next three years. Similarly, if you can look back and clearly remember what you did in your second year, then you probably wasted it. Third year is different. This is when you do exams and job interviews, where you claim to have done nothing but study and organise impressive things for three years. Jobs are all too much for some people, and they go into hiding, otherwise known as doing a doctorate.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Go big on figs
fields.trailText: Go big on figs
fields.body:
The subject
Ficus carica, a fruit with many extraordinary features (Oxford Companion To Food). Native to somewhere in Asia, and cultivated all over the Mediterranean since antiquity. Now in its second crop all over the Mediterranean, and at a greengrocer's stall near you.

The basics
Figs are the ultimate sensual fruit, and an enduring symbol of abundance: the Odyssey and the Bible are full of them. They are also a truly miraculous addition to our edible repertoire. For the full story, read the enthralling entry in the wonderful Oxford Companion. Here's a starter: a fig is not a single piece of fruit but a sac (syconium) containing many individual fruits, the so-called seeds. And it gets better...

The details
It's a fruit of many colours, our Miss Figgy: off-white, green, violet, purple or black - sometimes a combination. It's invariably best in the place where it's grown, because its softness makes for uneasy transport, but you can still get good 'uns over here. Warning: there's no guaranteed test to distinguish fig ecstasy from fig agony. Basic point: squeeze gently before buying, and cast away if hard to the touch. Cooking point: some people do do this, giving the fruit a brief engagement with heat from a grill, oven or BBQ. The Knowledge, however, prefers the following (far simpler) procedure: wash fig quickly, pinch off stem, peel (if desired), eat really messily. Repeat with a second fig. And a third, if you want. Fancy figgers: serve with prosciutto or Serrano ham; or ricotta, or crème frache, or balsamic vinegar and a squeeze of lemon. Literary figgers: DH Lawrence's suggestive poem about eating figs. Dried figgers: don't let the Knowledge stop you, but don't make me eat a dried fig, please.

Where to buy
A greengrocer where they don't mind squeezers.

The easy way out
Balsamic fig vinegar, anyone? Better than it sounds: £9.50 from FifthSense (0289 2606870).

fields.headline: The Alchemist
fields.standfirst: Brian Lewis is a compulsive decorator whose paintbrush magic has transformed his ordinary London flat. It is a dazzling sight, says Lesley Gillilan, inspiring in its own extravagant way - but could you live here?
fields.trailText: Brian Lewis is a compulsive decorator whose paintbrush magic has transformed his ordinary London flat. It is a dazzling sight, says Lesley Gillilan, inspiring in its own extravagant way - but could you live here?
fields.body:
When measured merely by the square metre, Brian Lewis's London flat is a modest space. "It's really very small... only one bedroom," he reminds me, as I follow him up the staircase of the mid-Victorian townhouse in Holland Park, where he has lived for 25 years. But, as soon becomes clear, when we reach the first floor, it's a small space with big ideas.

"Ah yes, the door," says Lewis, as we pause on the landing to admire the silvered fantasia of fretworked hardboard that frames the entrance. "That was inspired by a visit to Egypt. The stained glass above the door is fake, of course, but it spells my name in real hieroglyphics."

The hall is in the Art Deco style, he continues, as we step into a weeny inner vestibule. Indeed, it includes an "interpretation" of the lift doors in the Chrysler Building in New York. I would have stayed and had a closer look (it's all done in cut cork, gold card and picture-framing offcuts), but I am drawn inwards by a tantalising glimpse of living-room decor - a bit of "faux" marbling, a baroque trompe l'oeil landscape and a throne-like gilded chair with leopard-print upholstery, crests and tassels entwined with Victorian plasterwork.

"Wow!" is all I can think of to say as we enter the room, where I am instantly supplied with a helpful leaflet (entitled Private Residence Of Brian Lewis) explaining that the decor is "pure fantasy... not intended to be taken too seriously, but enjoyed for what it is - a dream, an escape from the outside world".

The text also gives a brief resumé of the room's furnishing highlights (the 1935 Bechstein piano attributed as the property of Captain Cheshire "of Battle Of Britain fame"; the animal-print couch by architect-designer Ettore Sottsass "of the Italian Memphis style"). But there are so many things, and so much going on, it's hard to know where to look first.

Lewis will, no doubt, be handing out leaflets to more dazzled and, indeed, dazed visitors when he opens his flat as part of this weekend's London Open House - the annual "celebration of architecture" that invites the public into some of the capital's most intriguing inner spaces that are closed for the remainder of the year.

Of the hundreds of participating buildings, only 40 are private residences and, of those, the majority are the homes of architects (or clients of architects). For them, it's a chance to flaunt new projects or, in the true spirit of the event, to engage in a dialogue with the public about "the quality of the spaces we inhabit". What they tend to show is cool, white, contemporary spaces in sparsely furnished, glassy houses. So, Lewis's flat is a bit of a one-off.

Lewis is not an architect, but a muralist and decorative painter (gilding, sponging, staining, stencilling, etc). He doesn't do white spaces (the decoration, he says, "is the absolute antithesis of the current vogue for minimalism"). And he is certainly alone among Open Housers to claim Ludwig II - the "mad king of Bavaria" - as his mentor. Ludwig not only did themed rooms at least a century before Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen was born, but he indulged his passion for over-the-top interiors by creating the extravagant German castles, Linderhof and Neuschwanstein - each a jangling confusion of the Byzantine, the baroque, neo-Gothic and Romanesque.

"He has had a great deal of influence on me," says Lewis, adding that he "loves the idea of a house where every room is a surprise and you can move from one to the other, depending on your mood". He is influenced, too, by his own world-wide travels, and the tradition of the Grand Tours (in which 18th- and 19th-century travellers returned from the Ancient world with marble columns, classical statues and wild ideas for garden temples and grottoes). He is also driven by a compulsive decorating habit. Decorating, he says, is a kind of therapy; something he can't help doing.

The flat, therefore, is in a constant state of transformation. The bedroom used to be an "arboretum" - a wood with trees and branches reaching over the bed - until a visit to southeast Asia inspired a mini Thai temple, complete with sacred elephants, lotus blossoms and the sweet smell of incense. "At one time, the living room was very white and Deco-ish," says Lewis. "But I just got fed up with it. I'm not very good at cleaning, you see, so if something gets dirty, I just paint it."

He doesn't, of course, just paint any old thing. The richly emulsioned murals on his living-room walls represent a "very personal diary" - a kind of pictorial album of buildings and monuments he has seen and loved in places he's visited (Salzburg, Beijing, Istanbul, Prague, the Bavarian Alps). It also features a lot of memorabilia - such as his childhood dog (Montgomery Hector Oscar Lewis), the pasted newspaper cutting of his mother's obituary (she was a novelist), the painting of Brian and friends in a hot-air balloon rising towards the ceiling, where clouds float alongside winged Renaissance cherubs across a duck-egg blue sky.

Sounds ghastly? Well, yes, it could be - and it's certainly a hellish place for obsessive modernists. But Lewis's skilful trompe l'oeil effects (pillars, loggias, statues, romantic Arcadian landscapes) give this mad, chaotic ensemble a sensible, architectural framework. And though he is the first to admit that much of what he's created is as ephemeral as a stage set ("you are not supposed to look at anything too closely"), there are some genuinely good pieces among his amazing collection of props.

During this weekend's tours, Lewis will no doubt point out that the living room's black Corinthian rug (partially obscuring his mock-flagstone, paint-effect floor) is a limited edition by Spanish designer Esteban Figuerola. The gold thrones, he will say, are identical to chairs seen in the television version of Brideshead Revisited and Kenneth Branagh's film of Hamlet. The chrome-and-glass coffee table is "in the style of Eileen Gray" and could be the real thing. He will show off engravings by Paula Rego; a Victorian jardinière that once belonged to Elton John; and Art Deco-style curtains ("with tasselly bits") made by Lewis after visiting the Prague concert hall.

"Then we've got the Empire clock and matching alabaster vases," he continues. "I put lights in them, and they look quite spectacular when lit up." Lewis thinks nothing of, say, sticking brass candlesticks to the frame of a French crystal mirror. Or attaching a sequined elephant to the original Verner Panton wire chair in his bedroom. "I imagine Verner would be very upset, if he was still alive," he admits.

Aside from elephants, the Thai bedroom features a home-made four-poster bed crowned with lights, a ceiling of stick-on stars and two parallel walls of mirrored tiles. The latter reflect one of those infinite sequences of fractured images. For me, it's a bit scary - but it's not until we enter the "black magic" dining room that I start to worry about Brian Lewis.

You have to admire the painstaking ceiling mosaic (all made from tiny squares of cut card), but Lewis's dining room is a creepy mix of Hammer horror, science fiction and esoteric symbolism - Tarot cards, astrology (he's an Aquarian), serpents and devilry. The table is suspended on chains and set with a little tableau of skulls; there are nasty looking spikes on the set of metal chairs, each of which is decorated with a hideous mask and a writhing snake.

"Some people are very uncomfortable with this room, particularly with the snakes," he says. "But I like to get a reaction... and I'd rather people said they hated it than said nothing at all. Anyway, they are only rubber snakes, like the ones you buy in joke shops." Beyond a relatively normal kitchen, there is another joke to be shared: a bathroom in the form of a Ludwigian grotto, dressed from head to foot in rock-look papier-mché and plaster, and hung with trailing plastic foliage. There are weird test-tube taps, a cracked-mirror floor, a television set into a craggy recess in the wall, a fake frog in the sink (it covers up a hole in the porcelain), a spooky little skeleton fountain that comes on when you switch on the light.

"Nothing's meant to be taken seriously," says Lewis. "I'm experimenting with techniques, but I'm also having a laugh - and it's not meant to be good taste."

Still, there is a serious side to the Brian Lewis style of interior design. Among numerous private commissions, he's just completed a mural in the surgery of a Holland Park dentist, who wanted something to distract his patients ("I painted a lot of animals and the odd toothbrush"). He has also lectured in design history at the London Institute. And though his own environment is a little unorthodox, some of his Open House guests are sure to come away with a few ideas: such as how to turn "a crappy little apartment", as he calls it, into a palace of treasures; or to create an illusion of space without fiddling with the fabric of the building; plus a swift guide to imaginative bodging with cheap materials (such as decorating power sockets with gold or silver paint).

Personally, I liked the idea of hiding an iMac in a paint-treated Ikea wardrobe ("the cheapest one they had"). Ditto the little loo with its peacock feather throne, Arabic flooring and wrapping-paper decor. The bathroom? No, that particular bit of Lewis alchemy is pure theatre, a bit of entertainment - and though you might want to applaud it as such, perhaps it's best left at home where it belongs.

 Brian Lewis's home is open today and tomorrow, from 1-5pm, at 1st Floor, 155 Holland Park Avenue, London W11. For Open House details, visit www.londonopenhouse.org
fields.bodyText: When measured merely by the square metre, Brian Lewis's London flat is a modest space. "It's really very small... only one bedroom," he reminds me, as I follow him up the staircase of the mid-Victorian townhouse in Holland Park, where he has lived for 25 years. But, as soon becomes clear, when we reach the first floor, it's a small space with big ideas. "Ah yes, the door," says Lewis, as we pause on the landing to admire the silvered fantasia of fretworked hardboard that frames the entrance. "That was inspired by a visit to Egypt. The stained glass above the door is fake, of course, but it spells my name in real hieroglyphics." The hall is in the Art Deco style, he continues, as we step into a weeny inner vestibule. Indeed, it includes an "interpretation" of the lift doors in the Chrysler Building in New York. I would have stayed and had a closer look (it's all done in cut cork, gold card and picture-framing offcuts), but I am drawn inwards by a tantalising glimpse of living-room decor - a bit of "faux" marbling, a baroque trompe l'oeil landscape and a throne-like gilded chair with leopard-print upholstery, crests and tassels entwined with Victorian plasterwork. "Wow!" is all I can think of to say as we enter the room, where I am instantly supplied with a helpful leaflet (entitled Private Residence Of Brian Lewis) explaining that the decor is "pure fantasy... not intended to be taken too seriously, but enjoyed for what it is - a dream, an escape from the outside world". The text also gives a brief resumé of the room's furnishing highlights (the 1935 Bechstein piano attributed as the property of Captain Cheshire "of Battle Of Britain fame"; the animal-print couch by architect-designer Ettore Sottsass "of the Italian Memphis style"). But there are so many things, and so much going on, it's hard to know where to look first. Lewis will, no doubt, be handing out leaflets to more dazzled and, indeed, dazed visitors when he opens his flat as part of this weekend's London Open House - the annual "celebration of architecture" that invites the public into some of the capital's most intriguing inner spaces that are closed for the remainder of the year. Of the hundreds of participating buildings, only 40 are private residences and, of those, the majority are the homes of architects (or clients of architects). For them, it's a chance to flaunt new projects or, in the true spirit of the event, to engage in a dialogue with the public about "the quality of the spaces we inhabit". What they tend to show is cool, white, contemporary spaces in sparsely furnished, glassy houses. So, Lewis's flat is a bit of a one-off. Lewis is not an architect, but a muralist and decorative painter (gilding, sponging, staining, stencilling, etc). He doesn't do white spaces (the decoration, he says, "is the absolute antithesis of the current vogue for minimalism"). And he is certainly alone among Open Housers to claim Ludwig II - the "mad king of Bavaria" - as his mentor. Ludwig not only did themed rooms at least a century before Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen was born, but he indulged his passion for over-the-top interiors by creating the extravagant German castles, Linderhof and Neuschwanstein - each a jangling confusion of the Byzantine, the baroque, neo-Gothic and Romanesque. "He has had a great deal of influence on me," says Lewis, adding that he "loves the idea of a house where every room is a surprise and you can move from one to the other, depending on your mood". He is influenced, too, by his own world-wide travels, and the tradition of the Grand Tours (in which 18th- and 19th-century travellers returned from the Ancient world with marble columns, classical statues and wild ideas for garden temples and grottoes). He is also driven by a compulsive decorating habit. Decorating, he says, is a kind of therapy; something he can't help doing. The flat, therefore, is in a constant state of transformation. The bedroom used to be an "arboretum" - a wood with trees and branches reaching over the bed - until a visit to southeast Asia inspired a mini Thai temple, complete with sacred elephants, lotus blossoms and the sweet smell of incense. "At one time, the living room was very white and Deco-ish," says Lewis. "But I just got fed up with it. I'm not very good at cleaning, you see, so if something gets dirty, I just paint it." He doesn't, of course, just paint any old thing. The richly emulsioned murals on his living-room walls represent a "very personal diary" - a kind of pictorial album of buildings and monuments he has seen and loved in places he's visited (Salzburg, Beijing, Istanbul, Prague, the Bavarian Alps). It also features a lot of memorabilia - such as his childhood dog (Montgomery Hector Oscar Lewis), the pasted newspaper cutting of his mother's obituary (she was a novelist), the painting of Brian and friends in a hot-air balloon rising towards the ceiling, where clouds float alongside winged Renaissance cherubs across a duck-egg blue sky. Sounds ghastly? Well, yes, it could be - and it's certainly a hellish place for obsessive modernists. But Lewis's skilful trompe l'oeil effects (pillars, loggias, statues, romantic Arcadian landscapes) give this mad, chaotic ensemble a sensible, architectural framework. And though he is the first to admit that much of what he's created is as ephemeral as a stage set ("you are not supposed to look at anything too closely"), there are some genuinely good pieces among his amazing collection of props. During this weekend's tours, Lewis will no doubt point out that the living room's black Corinthian rug (partially obscuring his mock-flagstone, paint-effect floor) is a limited edition by Spanish designer Esteban Figuerola. The gold thrones, he will say, are identical to chairs seen in the television version of Brideshead Revisited and Kenneth Branagh's film of Hamlet. The chrome-and-glass coffee table is "in the style of Eileen Gray" and could be the real thing. He will show off engravings by Paula Rego; a Victorian jardinière that once belonged to Elton John; and Art Deco-style curtains ("with tasselly bits") made by Lewis after visiting the Prague concert hall. "Then we've got the Empire clock and matching alabaster vases," he continues. "I put lights in them, and they look quite spectacular when lit up." Lewis thinks nothing of, say, sticking brass candlesticks to the frame of a French crystal mirror. Or attaching a sequined elephant to the original Verner Panton wire chair in his bedroom. "I imagine Verner would be very upset, if he was still alive," he admits. Aside from elephants, the Thai bedroom features a home-made four-poster bed crowned with lights, a ceiling of stick-on stars and two parallel walls of mirrored tiles. The latter reflect one of those infinite sequences of fractured images. For me, it's a bit scary - but it's not until we enter the "black magic" dining room that I start to worry about Brian Lewis. You have to admire the painstaking ceiling mosaic (all made from tiny squares of cut card), but Lewis's dining room is a creepy mix of Hammer horror, science fiction and esoteric symbolism - Tarot cards, astrology (he's an Aquarian), serpents and devilry. The table is suspended on chains and set with a little tableau of skulls; there are nasty looking spikes on the set of metal chairs, each of which is decorated with a hideous mask and a writhing snake. "Some people are very uncomfortable with this room, particularly with the snakes," he says. "But I like to get a reaction... and I'd rather people said they hated it than said nothing at all. Anyway, they are only rubber snakes, like the ones you buy in joke shops." Beyond a relatively normal kitchen, there is another joke to be shared: a bathroom in the form of a Ludwigian grotto, dressed from head to foot in rock-look papier-mché and plaster, and hung with trailing plastic foliage. There are weird test-tube taps, a cracked-mirror floor, a television set into a craggy recess in the wall, a fake frog in the sink (it covers up a hole in the porcelain), a spooky little skeleton fountain that comes on when you switch on the light. "Nothing's meant to be taken seriously," says Lewis. "I'm experimenting with techniques, but I'm also having a laugh - and it's not meant to be good taste." Still, there is a serious side to the Brian Lewis style of interior design. Among numerous private commissions, he's just completed a mural in the surgery of a Holland Park dentist, who wanted something to distract his patients ("I painted a lot of animals and the odd toothbrush"). He has also lectured in design history at the London Institute. And though his own environment is a little unorthodox, some of his Open House guests are sure to come away with a few ideas: such as how to turn "a crappy little apartment", as he calls it, into a palace of treasures; or to create an illusion of space without fiddling with the fabric of the building; plus a swift guide to imaginative bodging with cheap materials (such as decorating power sockets with gold or silver paint). Personally, I liked the idea of hiding an iMac in a paint-treated Ikea wardrobe ("the cheapest one they had"). Ditto the little loo with its peacock feather throne, Arabic flooring and wrapping-paper decor. The bathroom? No, that particular bit of Lewis alchemy is pure theatre, a bit of entertainment - and though you might want to applaud it as such, perhaps it's best left at home where it belongs.  Brian Lewis's home is open today and tomorrow, from 1-5pm, at 1st Floor, 155 Holland Park Avenue, London W11. For Open House details, visit www.londonopenhouse.org

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck takes up a challenge.
fields.body:
Recently challenged by a wine-obsessed visitor to these shores to nominate drinkable white wines costing less than £3.50, I was able to offer him not only a selection from our three leading lights - Asda, Morrisons and Somerfield - but also a quaffable white for less than £2. True, he gagged on the latter wine (it was German, see below), but then this was entirely predictable. What was not was that I would be able to find such wines; wines that would contradict his assertion that it was impossible to create drinkable white wines for this kind of money. I also threw in a more expensive white and a couple of interesting reds, since they also stood to prove that British retailers possess a unique nose for bargains.

Asda's wine department has needed no lessons from its new masters, Wal-Mart, about pricing, which is why this retailer is breathing hard on Sainsbury's heels and is even giving Tesco something to think about.

Chardonnay Jardin de la France 1999 (14 points out of 20, £3.23) is admittedly light, but this is due to the genteel nature of the fruit, which recalls under-ripe ogen melon, rather than a shortness of finish, for it ends refreshingly and crisply. Asda's Chenin Blanc Loire 1999 (14 points, £3.29) is a similar construct, but has a suggestion of more vegetality as it slips charmingly down the throat.

Karalta White 1999 (14 points, £2.99) must be the cheapest drinkable Aussie white wine in the world, and whatever corners have been cut to get it to this price (massive yields of grapes for a start) are not so evident on the palate that it prevents it from being a quaffable party wine. Badger Hill Hungarian Sauvignon 1999 (14 points, £2.99) is very herbaceous and crisp, good with fish cakes and crustacea, and finishes impactfully and dryly.

Asda Cape Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, £3.47) is also a food wine - for anything from tuna salad to roast chicken. It has considerable fulsomeness, an urgency to please, and depth on the finish. Last at Asda (and widely elsewhere), there is the Spanish stalwart non- vintage red, Don Darias, which in its latest blend rates 15.5 points. This £3.49 wine has decent tannins and some real character to its well-developed fruit.

Morrisons' prices match anyone's, so if there isn't a convenient Asda near you, there might well be a Morrisons, especially now that - after decades of staunch northern residency - this retailer is suddenly popping up all over the place. Verdicchio di Jesi Classico 1999 (15.5 points, £3.49) is a classic Italian wine, and this one is a scrumptious bargain - it has lovely teasing fruit: dry, faintly peachy and nutty.

Wente Johannesburg Riesling 1997 (16.5 points, £4.99), on the other hand, parades richly engaging spice and lime-sherbet fruit, not wholly dry, to be sure, but the wine bounces with life and would be terrific with Thai food. I included this wine in my selection even though it costs £4.99, for it demonstrates that it is possible to find mature American white wine of genuine character for less than a fiver.

On Morrisons' red shelves, Vina Albali Tempranillo 1999 (15.5 points, £3.45), from Spain, is slightly creamy, very subtly vanillary and has assertive tannins. This is an excellent roast meat or savoury vegetable casserole wine. I had to include Fairview Malbec 1999, from South Africa, in spite of its £5.99 price tag, simply because it is so 16.5-point marvellous. There is a juicy overture to the fruit, but Fairview's wines always achieve an elegance and purposefulness on the finish, as this red does, and so what begins with pace ends with panache. Safeway also has this wine.

At Somerfield, meanwhile, there is the UK's cheapest drinkable white wine, the own-label Hock at £1.95. Rating 14.5 points, this makes a totally charming aperitif in warm weather or a lush ingredient in a spritzer. Also at this enterprising retailer (where wine is concerned) is Chteau Valoussière Cteaux de Languedoc 1997 (16.5 points, £4.49), which has gorgeous spices and tannins combined with balanced fruit and acids. A really stylish red wine of depth and deliciousness, it has a beautiful, gently ruffled texture. It proves, once again, that the Languedoc can be a more exciting place than Burgundy or Bordeaux.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
I'm grateful to Tom Fort for the information that flowerbeds are 'terra incognita' for men (Garden, September 16). I had naively assumed that gardening (as opposed to lawn-mowing) was a popular pastime among men. Presumably, their potting sheds actually contain nothing but grass seed and engine oil. Either that, or - if we are to believe Fort's 'eminent' psychologists - they're all homosexuals. I don't think I'll be buying the book. As any eminent scientist will tell you, reading's a bit poofy.
Harry Campbell
Glasgow

Either that, or - if we are to believe Fort's 'eminent' psychologists - they're all homosexuals. I don't think I'll be buying the book. As any eminent scientist will tell you, reading's a bit poofy.
Harry Campbell
Glasgow

I was shocked and disgusted by the theories put forward in your article about grass-cutting. I will not abide the gardening again.
Andrew Carroll
Brighton

Ms Burchill (September 16) asserts that, in preferring the UK to the US, you are tolerant, kind and do not judge people, whereas preferring the US to the UK makes you a dirty, clammy-minded, cowardly little traitor who is a disgrace to the human race. I can only assume that she is hitting the town in New York with Mart, Salman and Jeanette as we speak.
N Barclay
London SE24

Capitalism is capitalism, and it operates across the divisive national boundaries it chooses to reinforce. Julie Burchill should know that, but instead she bleats on about the merits of 'British' attitudes over 'American' ones, implying that the capitalism that exists on the island 'Britain' is somehow different from that on the continent 'America'. The concept of 'national citizenship' is a false one: who gives a toss where someone lives? We're human, and some of us are socialists.
Phil McNally
Bolton, Lancs

Once again, Julie Burchill's over-the-top article has given me a good laugh and, no doubt, reinforced my prejudices. Saturdays would not be the same without her. More power to her elbow.
George Lawrence
Cheltenham, Glos

Alexander Chancellor performed us a service by quoting politicians' hubristic statements on the Dome in the run-up to the millennium (September 16). It's now clear that the Blair-Mandelson millennium had a political purpose: the manipulation of mass emotion to springboard New Labour to a second term. Thankfully for democracy, 'the people' refused to buy into this exploitation of public sentiment. But at least the Dome has succeeded in one of its objectives: it perfectly embodies the priorities and spirit of millennial 'New Britain' - even Schadenfreude at the folly of politicians cannot mitigate the bleakness with which the Dome's question, 'What does it mean to be British in the year 2000?', has been answered.
Mike Diboll
London SE16

If Richard Ehrlich (The Knowledge, September 16) wants to spread knowledge about pesto, he should at least try and not forget one essential ingredient, which is garlic.
Chiara Ghiron
Oxford

Congratulations on the splendid Slow Down issue (September 9). I finally found time to start reading it today (September 19).
Gordon Bird
gordon.bird@infrasoft-civil.com

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
